DEBATE.TITLE: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 3 June.
FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986
Proposed new clause 57b (Provision of benefits to employers of scientific, charitable or public educational institutions to be exempt).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been debating over several days the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill which the Hawke Labor Government has introduced. Amongst the many aspects of this legislation that the Opposition is objecting to is the proposal that is now before us in the Committee stage-that those few bodies exempted from the legislation's effects should not include the employees of scientific or public educational institutions. It is the view of the Opposition that these bodies, which should not be subject to tax, are non-profit, public beneficial organisations. Although Senator Haines has already brought into this debate a definition from the Elizabethan era of charitable organisations which, in its quaint words includes schools amongst beneficial or charitable organisations, the amendment which the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have already gained with respect to those charitable organisations which are assisting what the public understands as charities does not include educational bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is beyond belief that the Hawke Government wants to impose additional costs on public education institutions in this country, whether they be secondary schools or tertiary education institutions. I raise a couple of instances. The Australian Parents Council, for example, which is a federation of parent groups in all States of Australia which includes parents and friends associations connected with non-government schools, has written to senators saying that its legal advice is that the Bill will require non-government schools to pay a fringe benefits tax in respect of the value of money involved where teachers attend various dinners that may be provided at functions held by non-government schools. Let me quote from the letter I have received:

Examples of school functions at which suppers and other meals are served and at which teachers must be present are: parent/teacher nights, concerts, prize givings, committee meetings, end of year activities, excursions, fetes and other well-known and accepted school activities designed to provide better education for children.

Whilst section 54 of the Act gives exemption to the consumption of small amounts of food in some company premises it specifically does not include in that exemption food or drink that is provided, other than in very limited circumstances and in limited amounts. In our view this Bill means that, where teachers are required to attend such functions, those non-government schools will be required to pay a fringe benefits tax to the Australian Government. We do not believe that this is right. We believe that it is rightly being resisted by parents and friends associations all around Australia. More importantly, boarding schools will also be taxed for the provision of accommodation to live-in teachers and supervisors. This will create additional burdens on public education institutions and non-government institutions and will divert scarce resources from the teaching of children. It is partly with this in mind that we have moved that there be a general exemption from the fringe benefits tax for all employees in such educational institutions. The same case can be made for the employees of scientific institutions.

I raise a second example in the tertiary education area. For more than 50 years all universities in Australia have had associated residential colleges. These residential colleges have separate foundations. Some are religious and some are not religious. The students live in and gain tutorials in an educational environment. They then attend courses at universities. These days students of colleges of advanced education, institutes of technology and some technical education and further education students also live in these residential colleges. At the end of this year the rather small direct subsidy to these tertiary colleges, the Commonwealth benefit, will be stopped. In addition to the stopping of the decades long Commonwealth subsidy to these tertiary education colleges there will be the penalty of their being required to pay a fringe benefits tax.

I instance the case of one university college in the city of Adelaide. Because the college is a non-profit body-it is a public educational institution-it is exempt from all tax. No tax is now paid by that college. It seems particularly anomalous that, for the first time, it has become liable as an educational institution to any kind of tax. The tax arises because of the failure of the Bill to exempt the tutorial staff of the college who are resident at the college and who give direct supervision to the students who are resident in the college. It will be taxed 49c in the dollar on the value of the accommodation provided. The Bill says that this is to be the market value, but there is no market in this matter. The public at large cannot go there as if to an hotel or a boarding house and live in a room which is integrated in a corridor with the students resident in that college who attend universities and colleges of advanced education. There is not a market. It is an essential function of the university college for the staff to live in. I use this college as an example. There are 140 male and female students, 96 per cent of whom come from homes which are in the country, interstate or overseas. Only 4 per cent of the students are from the metropolitan area. An additional cost of $15,000 for that college alone will have to be paid in fringe benefits tax. This amounts to $3.57 per week for each of the 140 students who are resident at the college.

It is widely known that tertiary students are under a great deal of cost pressure to be able to stay at university or college. Even if they have a tertiary education allowance or very generous parents, they will still have to go without a great number of purchases and activities which would be regarded as normal at any other stage of life. In order to meet the fringe benefits tax these impecunious tertiary students would be forced to pay an additional $3.50 a week to stay in the college. Where else would the college get its money? The Commonwealth benefit will finish at the end of this year. This is a direct barrier being placed by the Government on the otherwise reasonable access that students from rural areas have to tertiary studies.

For all the rhetoric surrounding this legislation regarding the chasing of non-cash income of rather wealthy Australians-for example, the fringe benefits tax on car allowances and so on that was spoken of in earlier debate on this legislation in the Senate-does the Government deliberately want to impose that penalty on tertiary students in Australia? It is the view of the chairman of the finance committee of the college whose example I was citing that these two additional charge elements, that is, the cessation of the Commonwealth benefit and the penalty of this fringe benefits tax, will force access to this college out of the reach of many of its present students-especially those of low to moderate means. It would be a great pity if residential colleges became the preserve of a socio-economic elite.

I have put very clearly to the Government our reasons for moving this specific amendment to the legislation. Although we are opposed to the whole legislation-and it appears to have the numbers to be passed in the Senate because the Australian Democrats are supporting the Government on this legislation in general-I ask whether at least the Government can consider our argument that the fringe benefits tax not be levied on public educational and scientific institutions. Even at this stage we urge the Australian Democrats and Government senators to support us in this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not support the Opposition's amendment to exempt scientific organisations and educational institutions from the fringe benefits tax. I must say that I am rather astounded by the somewhat sanctimonious rhetoric used by Senator Teague to defend the residential colleges from fringe benefits tax because of the impact of $3-odd on their students when he is a member of a party that has talked for years about charging students tertiary fees-something which would cost them far more than $3-odd a week extra and something that would deny far more students access to tertiary institutions.
—That is an absolutely untruthful statement.

—The honourable senator is one of those who brought forward tertiary fees as an issue. That is on record. Do not talk to me about the likely damage that a fringe benefits tax will have on some students because it might increase their residential charges by something like $3 a week. I have every sympathy for them but I also have every sympathy for students who at the moment are very concerned that a Liberal government might get back into power and who might find, as a consequence, that their tertiary courses are cut very short because of the likely proposal to introduce fees. I can remember the days when fees were charged at universities. It was not much fun for those people from the country or for those people who could not afford the fees.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the general fringe benefits tax on schools and so on is concerned, the Opposition is picking up some kind of populist issue among the wealthy private schools, and that is as far as it is going. I have had no approaches at all from Catholic schools on this issue, although I have had approaches from other people on other issues with regard to the fringe benefits tax. If the Catholic schools generally were concerned about the impact of the fringe benefits tax on them, I am sure that knowing their lobbying potential they would have done something about it. The fact is that these taxes are far more likely to affect the Timbertops of this world than they are to affect the little local Catholic primary school which has a few students who pay very limited fees. The fact that schools such as Timbertop are classified as non-profit-making organisations for the purpose of paying income tax is no grounds at all for exempting them from a fringe benefits tax on the perks that they are in the position to give to some of their staff-certainly not all of their staff-because of the extraordinary fees which they charge. If those schools are feeling a little troubled by paying the tax, they can either stop providing the fringe benefits or they can use the money which they get in to cover the tax instead of pouring it back into the sorts of benefits, some of which are rather esoteric, that they provide to the privileged students who attend those schools.

I understand that the impact on live-in teachers, those house masters and house mistresses who presumably are on call 24 hours a day, will be limited partly because those who are on call 24 hours a day get a special benefit, and partly because the Australian Taxation Office, I understand, quite rightly defines living in a school environment as somewhat less than salubrious and will be judging the market rental accordingly. There is no reason for exempting these sorts of schools from paying the fringe benefits tax. The money which they get from the fees that they charge is quite sufficient. I am aware of that from having had my two children at a private school for something like 10 years. While I certainly appreciate the benefits that private and very wealthy schools provide to their students, I do not see any reason at all for them being exempted from this sort of tax in the same way that charitable organisations, for example, were last night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will oppose this amendment for the basic reason which has been stated many times, that a fringe benefit is something of value to the employee and, therefore, it should be taxed somewhere or other. The value of equivalent benefits received by employees of different employers is not diminished by the fact that one of those employers is a scientific or public benevolent institution. While the Government, in the interest of getting the Bill passed, conceded the earlierextension moved by Senator Siddons, I think, it will not concede this one because it would provide a vast potential increase in the scope for exemptions which could be claimed by employees of organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to the sanctimony which we heard from Senator Teague, one thing that would not have occurred to him is that it would probably be a simple matter for trade unions to call all their paid employees education officers. They could be given a free house and a free car and escape the tax. That is something which would not have occurred to the Liberals because their ideological blinkers are such that they would not foresee the extension of this sort of loophole and potential rort to people whom they do not want to receive it because they can concentrate only on those whom they do want to receive it.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be inserted (Senator Peter Baume's amendment) be inserted.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 58 to 142-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask a question in respect of clause 66. Will the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) advise the Committee of the way in which the additional holiday pay loading of 17.5 per cent and workers compensation, which are both compulsory, will be treated under the fringe benefits legislation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Minister is addressing the question put by Senator Brownhill, I would like to address myself to clause 67. This legislation is supposed to be simple so that people can understand it. A tax is to be raised against the employer rather than the employee who is his beneficiary because of the existence of the phenomenon of the so-called fringe benefit. Clause 67 deals with the way in which the avoidance of the fringe benefits tax can be combated by the Government. Sub-clause (2) is of real interest because it seems to me that one of the Government's fundamental objectives with this tax may well be frustrated by this sub-clause.

SPEECH.PARA: As we heard during the debate at both the second reading stage and this stage, it is the obvious intention of the Government to force employers to give up the practice of giving fringe benefits to their employees and, rather, to cash up the payments which would then become taxable in the hands of the employees. We pointed out to the Government in debate earlier this week that this will have an impact insofar as there will be a definite tax incentive for employers to move to cash up the benefits for low income earners. This will not be the case in respect of high income earners. The Government's action will result in low income earners, who, of course, are the most numerous, paying the tax imposed on that cashed up benefit. Those at the higher end of the income scale, whom the Government is supposed to be chasing, will not have their benefits cashed up because in fact there will be a positive disincentive for employers to do so. As I have pointed out previously, there is no tax advantage in doing so; in fact, there is a tax disadvantage to the employer company to do so. So the low income earners will suffer the increased tax as a result of cashing up the benefit. That may well be the Government's intention.

As I said, clause 67 (2) seeks to wipe out the avoidance of taxation. The clause more or less defines-and here I am paraphrasing-a tax benefit as being a taxable amount not included as a fringe benefit which could reasonably be expected to have been so included but for the arrangement. In other words, it appears to me that the clause could apply where an employer had rearranged a package of fringe benefits available to an employee to increase the cash salary component and thereby reduce the fringe benefit component.

It appears to me that there is a catch-22 situation in regard to this clause. On the one hand the Government is saying that it wants employers to cash up the benefit, to pay out the benefit in cash to employees rather than provide fringe benefits. However, if one reads the anti-avoidance clause of the Bill-clause 67 (2)-one can see that the action that the employer takes to cash up the benefit is in itself a rearrangement which would be caught as an avoidance device by the very clause of this Bill which aims to stamp out avoidance. So the Government is being hoist with its own petard. The stated purpose of the legislation is being frustrated by this clause.

It seems to me that clause 67 could have other ramifications. Whereas the equivalent anti-avoidance sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act-particularly Part IVa of that Act-make exception in regard to income, no exception is made in this piece of fringe benefits legislation for ordinary family or business dealings. Therefore, the fringe benefits tax legislation is certainly a more draconian approach in terms of the ordinary business dealings that are carried on among family members. Therefore, this le-gislation will obviously have a greater impact than Part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act. It seems to me that it would be unfortunate if the clause were construed in such a way as to impose a higher anti-avoidance requirement than do other parts of the tax law, especially that relating to income under Part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I really do not understand why the Government sees the need to do that in the case of this fringe benefits tax but does not see that need in respect of the ordinary income tax law.

It seems to me that clause 67 would catch the innocent employer who, in the knowledge that the fringe benefits tax was to be introduced, simply sought to reorganise his employees' wages and packages to exclude non-cash benefits. That employer might increase the cash component of, for example, a company director who might be repaying a company loan. The employer might have made the arrangements following the announcement of introduction of this legislation which, of course, was made only recently but which we have had knowledge of since 19 September last year. I am trying to make the point that there is an element of retrospectivity in respect of this anti-avoidance clause. Take the case of a family company or family business which, prior to 19 September last year, gave a loan to its employee directors. Those loans would become subject to fringe benefits tax after 19 September because concessional rates of interest would apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a continuing benefit.

—Hold on. After that date, by the application of the anti-avoidance clause, clause 67, the directors, having repaid that loan during the period since September last year, would now find that that would be overridden by clause 67 because it would have had an anti-avoidance purpose; that is, to reduce the impact of the fringe benefits tax. If that is so, the legislation is retrospective, in the sense that no notice was given of that impact in the announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 19 September 1985. Those three elements together lead us to have great concern about the impact of this particular anti-avoidance clause, clause 67, as it appears to go far further than the income tax law generally and certainly goes further than Part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to the first point, it seems to me that the silliest part of the whole proposal in clause 67 is that it appears to frustrate the Government's own intention. That intention has been stated to be that it wants to encourage employers to cash up the benefits for employees-that is, pay out the benefits in cash-rather than to provide them in kind. If that is the Government's intention, it appears to me that that will be frustrated by clause 67.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask the Minister for Finance one question regarding clause 59 and the supply of power to stations. How does the Minister determine the fringe benefit applicable to an employee of the power supplied where the station's lighting plant also supplies the workshop? Is this a fringe benefit on power supplied in that way? If it is, it would seem to me that this is really a discrimination against the rural sector for providing minimal facilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brownhill asked me about holiday pay loading and workers compensation. The fact is that holiday pay and workers compensation are already taxable as income. I thought that would have been known fairly widely, but apparently it is not. Therefore, it has no relevance to this.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner made a string of assertions which are not correct. He can go on asserting anything, just as that self-serving charlatan, David Barnett, asserts in the Bulletin today that people using company cars will be required to keep log books and farmers also will have to record each trip. There is nothing much the Government can do, short of the laws of libel. Just a simple misstatement of fact is not grounds for an action for libel to stop charlatans such as Barnett printing that sort of rubbish, any more than we can stop people such as Senator Messner asserting in the Committee what is wrong; although at least there is a qualitative difference between the straight-out lies Barnett is writing and the possible genuine misunderstandings or misinterpretations from which Senator Messner suffers.

I add in respect of this creature Barnett that when he was Malcolm Fraser's Press secretary he was on a salary, updated into present dollars, of about $38,000 a year and in one year he picked up $63,000 in overtime payments because he rorted the overtime. He stuck his snout so far into the public trough that the system had to be changed to put all ministerial staffers on a fixed overtime allowance because Barnett had fraudulently claimed-except the fraud was not provable-an overtime allowance which was about 165 per cent of his salary. This is the sort of odious creep who is going in to bat in the Bulletin to defend the rorts of which he and his odious contemporaries are beneficiaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I challenge the Minister to stop using coward's castle and to make his accusations outside the House.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked how the electricity supplied to rural workers would be valued when it was generated on a property. I am advised that the Australian Taxation Office accepts the reasonable estimate by the employer based on broader costs of generation and in those situations the 40 per cent remote area concession would almost certainly apply.

—The question regarding workers compensation was in regard to the premium that is paid by the employer which then becomes a protection for the employee. That amount of money is not taxed because the employer definitely gets a tax deduction for the insurance premium.
—Premium on what?
—Workers com- pensation.

—I am advised that the answer is no; that the premium on the workers compensation insurance would have no relevance to this legislation, but of course it is deductible from normal income tax liability.

—It is more out of sorrow than anger that I rise to answer the points made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in response to my remarks. He seemed to wipe aside the points I had made without any attempt to answer them. While he may regard me as being misguided, I would appreciate hearing from him in what way I am misguided so that I can get a better understanding, as can the taxpayers of the country, as to what is intended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose Senator Messner has seen the explanatory memorandum. I confess that I have not turned my mind to this question before, but I am advised that page 91 of the explanatory memorandum covers the point Senator Messner has made. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: It should be noted that . . . clause 67 would not apply merely by virtue of a benefit being terminated (e.g., `cashed-out') or a different benefit (i.e., an alternative benefit or a diminished benefit) being provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we assume, on that last point I made, that the Commissioner of Taxation will interpret the law as it is in the explanatory memorandum and that past payments or payments in the repayment of a loan in order to avoid the effect of the fringe benefits tax would not be classified as an avoidance device? Is that the interpretation of the Commissioner of Taxation and the Minister; and the intention of the legislation?
—That is my advice, conveyed from the Commissioner.

—That answers, hopefully, the retrospective aspect of the question. The other point on which I would like to have the Minister's comment is the earlier point about the cashing out of benefits. As the Minister might appreciate, at present many employers are very concerned about their options in the area of rearranging their employee packages. One of the options that is being put forward by many organisations, such as the Confederation of Australian Industry, is that employers ought to be encouraged to cash out the benefits. I understand that it is the Government's intention to seek to encourage people to do so.
—Preference.

—That is the Government's preference. But the point is that if they do that, will they be caught under clause 67 in that, if they cash out the benefit, the benefit would then become taxable in the hands of the employee. There might or might not be a tax deduction available to the employer for the payment thus made. But because of the provisions of clause 67, it would not be seen as a valid transaction and, consequently, the fringe benefits tax would still apply. In other words, it would be a three time whammy. Could the Minister make that point clear?

—If the employer substitutes cash in lieu of the formerly provided fringe benefit, I cannot imagine any circumstances under which that would not be deductible from income tax on the part of the employer. That would not be regarded as an avoidance practice. I think the point Senator Messner made previously was that, depending upon the marginal rate of tax paid by the individual taxpayer, it may or may not lessen the joint or cumulative tax liability of the employer and the employee. Whether or not it did that would depend on the marginal tax rate of the taxpayer and whether that rate is lower than or different from that paid by the employer. That is possible, but I think it is highly unlikely for two reasons. Firstly, as from 1 July 1987 the individual and the corporate maximum tax rate will be the same. Secondly, the personal rate under the published rate scale will cut in at $35,000 of personal income. Very few people on incomes below that level receive fringe benefits of the type or magnitude that would trigger the fringe benefits tax because the first $300, I think, of benefit is exempt. There are as well some other less specific exemptions. So in practice the situation to which Senator Messner is drawing attention, I believe, would rarely occur. But if it did occur, the answer is that cashing it out in that form would not be regarded as a tax avoidance practice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a bit concerned that if an employer, particularly a rural employer, does not or cannot make an assessment or, in the opinion of the Commissioner of Taxation, makes an assessment of the value of the rented accommodation with which the Commissioner then disagrees, the Commissioner will then make the determination. In regard to the assets test, last year the Commissioner did revalue some rural properties. In the meantime people were very unfairly treated. An indication of the unfairness is that many have fought the assessments and won the arguments, and the valuation of their rural land has been reduced. I hope that the same situation does not occur in relation to clause 124.

SPEECH.PARA: I want also to make a point about clause 72. This clause provides that where the employer has not made an assessment the Taxation Commissioner, as I have already said, will do so. Also, clause 74 refers to the fact that the Commissioner may amend his assessment up to three years after the year in question. Surely, this in effect means that if the Commissioner decides he has been too lenient and he sees a chance to grab a bit more money, the reverse of what I have already said could apply. Obviously a terrific amount of paper work will have to be kept by employers while this is going on. Would the Minister like to comment on that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the Commissioner of Taxation will issue guidelines on the imputed rentals for these rural properties. If the employer is not willing to accept the Commissioner's suggested value, he will have the option of getting an independent valuer to place an alternative value on the house. But the Commissioner will not necessarily accept that alternative valuation. I think it ought to be pretty obvious why that is the case. The Tax Commissioner cannot give open-ended assurances that somebody else's valuation will necessarily be accepted by the Australian Taxation Office.

SPEECH.PARA: In practice, leaving aside that small minority-I would have thought a minuscule number-of farm houses occupied by the employees of the farmer which are within reasonable distance of a substantial country town and therefore for which some sort of a rental market not related to being part of the employee relationship does exist, the reality is that the rest of the houses have a commercial rent value which is extremely low. If a house is 100 miles or even 50 miles from any town which has a population of 1,000 or more and which has a housing shortage, its market value for rental purposes is likely to be negligible. Although one cannot quantify it, the rental value for the purposes of this Bill is also likely to be pretty low and in remote areas it is defined, anyway, that were will be an automatic 40 per cent reduction.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope the Minister will forgive me if this point is not immediately applicable to the clauses to which we are referring, but I suspect that it is in some respects. In looking at the remote area provisions, the calculation that is arrived at and the extent to which a pastoral property could fall within that definition, the definition at present refers to the 1981 census. Is there any intention on the part of the Government that, following the 1986 census, it will amend the provisions so as to accommodate the new statistics that will be available as a result of the new census?

—I would say yes, without any qualification, were it not for the fact that when this point was last looked at two or three years ago, prior to which the census base had been 1976, there was one town-Port Hedland, I think, was the town in question, but do not hold me to that-which had grown to the point where properties within the radius of a centre, whatever that radius was, which had a population above 10,000, would have been by the previous formula no longer defined as a remote area. I am not sure whether amending legislation was required, but I remember the issue. But the effect of that last review when more recent census information became available was that nobody who had previously been defined as being in a remote area was zoned out of the remote area definition. But, if I recall correctly, some were included in the definition because the population of the relevant town had declined between the time when the two censuses were conducted. Given that piece of history, I am reluctant to say that there would be an automatic and strict application of the formula when more recent, and therefore more accurate, census data became available. My expectation is that when the new census data becomes available, it will be used as the basis for a definition of a remote area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask three more questions. I think the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has already said that the Commissioner of Taxation will let tax agents have a lot more information. A lot of accountants are very worried about the provisions in clause 120. I can understand the need for penalties and the control of tax agents, but I am concerned about the lack of information that they have at this stage. Obviously the Commissioner will need to give tax agents a lot more information than they have had in the past and I think the Minister has already stressed that in the debate. I hope that the agents will get that information pretty quickly because at this stage they are greatly worried.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 133 states that if a deemed state of hardship is proved, the Commissioner may-and I emphasise the word `may'-release the employer from the payment of the tax. The Australian Taxation Office does not have a very good record of releasing people from tax, so I remain rather sceptical about whether people will be relieved of tax or whether they will be hounded to pay it. The Minister claims that at the moment there is no rural crisis, so it will be very hard for people in the rural community to claim financial hardship and to prove that they are unable to pay the tax. I am worried that the Commissioner may well argue that, if an employer cannot afford to pay the fringe benefits tax on his employees, perhaps he cannot afford the employees. That will cause some problems in the rural community.

My third question relates to clause 136 on page 107. Accountants to whom I have spoken are very concerned about the wording of the clause and they regard it as being very poor. They have suggested that the words `secure or maintain' be added so that the line reads `in relation to secure or maintain employment of an employee'.

TALK.START.PARA: —What line is that?

—That is line 30. Otherwise the interpretation becomes difficult when it relates to children who are also employees. It brings up all sorts of inconsistencies. I mentioned this yesterday when the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) was the Minister in charge of the Bill. Does one give the use of a motor car to one's son because he is one's son or because he is an employee? Similarly does one give the use of one's house to one's son because he is a son or because he is an employee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of these are minor matters. There is some room for judgment, but the preface to the lines quoted by Senator Brownhill is `in respect of'. I am advised that it is quite common in Commonwealth legislation for those words to preface some definition, and that is believed to be adequate. Past experience has shown it to be adequate.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of clause 133 and the provision for hardship, I must point out that a similar if not identical clause is contained in the present Income Tax Assessment Act. The judgment will not just be made by the Commissioner of Taxation, but by a board consisting of the Secretary to the Department of Finance, the Comptroller-General of Customs and so on or such appropriate substitutes. This provision is not new; it is in the existing Act and the Commissioner will not have sole responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about my question on clause 120 and the provision of information to tax agents?
—As Senator Brownhill expected, I am advised that substantial information will be forwarded to tax agents subsequent to the passage of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to mention a number of matters that are covered by this particular group of clauses. First, there is the question of lodgment of returns in the forthcoming financial year. We spoke earlier about the problems faced by the accounting profession and others who are engaged in helping taxpayers meet their obligations. They will be under severe pressure during September and October of next financial year as they are forced to deal not only with the requirements of the income tax law of that time, which has been a long-standing obligation, but also with the brand new set of laws under the fringe benefits legislation. That appears to me to be something that may not have been thought through properly by the Government. Has it considered the impact of this, especially in the light of the very complicated nature of the legislation that we are discussing? It would seem a reasonable proposition to consider extension of the time for lodgment of returns certainly beyond the due date, as set down in the Bill, of 28 October this year. Perhaps the whole thing should be put off for three months so that it can be dealt with, say, by the end of January. This would give accountants and those who will be required to advise taxpayers time to deal with the great deal of paperwork that will ensue from the introduction of this legislation. We discussed this earlier, but obviously there will be problems about penalties for taxpayers not lodging their returns on time because of the additional work load. Quite clearly there will be problems associated with this.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to raise a point in respect of clause 68 which requires every employer who grants a taxable fringe benefit to lodge a return even if all the tax is paid through instalments. With income tax of course, no return is required if the income is below $4,595 and consequently that exemption applies. However, in the case of the fringe benefits tax there will be a requirement to lodge an annual return, whatever the situation and whatever the level of fringe benefit payable. Surely it would be sensible for the Government to provide the Commissioner of Taxation with the power of exemption to taxpayers lodging returns where there is no tax payable or no further tax payable, otherwise people will need to keep records for a long time for future audit purposes. That seems a sensible proposition in the light of this situation. Because of the very heavy paperwork load that will flow from the introduction of this brand new tax, quite clearly assistance will be needed from accountants, lawyers and registered tax agents.

One point to which I draw the Government's attention is that currently no tax deduction is available to taxpayers who incur fees with registered tax agents under the ordinary income tax law. It seems to me that this means that accountants and lawyers who are required to help and advise in the preparation of this brand new system of taxation will be charging fees which their clients will not be able to deduct. That seems to be inequitable in light of the fact that expenses are normally deductible for the preparation of income tax returns and obviously are related to the carrying on of the taxpayer's business.

Another point relates to the actual preparation of the returns of the taxpayers under this fringe benefits legislation. Obviously the obligation will be imposed on the employers of keeping records for their employees. It must be seen that in many cases, such as where cars are taken home or where fringe benefits accrue to employees from special expense allowances or reimbursements or whatever they might be, the proper record keeping of the employee as distinct from the employer is relied on very heavily. I wish to know what plans the Government has in mind if the situation occurs wherein if an employee loses those records or perhaps leaves the employ of the employer and at some future time when audit is undertaken by the Government and returns lodged maybe years before are being checked it is not possible to trace the employee or lay hands upon the records kept by him which are basic to establishing the case of the employer in substantiating his earlier returns. I hope some relief can be provided if an employee has destroyed the records. I note that there are some safeguards in respect of an employer having lost records, but it seems to me that the other situation is likely to cause undue trouble and concern to the business community if it is allowed to apply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the question of difficulty in complying with the 28 October deadline-we went through that a couple of days ago too-the Commissioner of Taxation will grant reasonable extensions, as I think the Commissioner habitually grants reasonable extensions. The Government does not believe that there is a case for a blanket deferral. I can remember the same sorts of points that Senator Messner has just made being made in 1983, although they were exaggerated about tenfold on what Senator Messner just said, about the provisional payments system and the alleged impossibility of complying with the introduction by a certain date. There were demands for deferrals, and so on. As far as I know, there were no great problems involved in introducing the provisional payments system, because once the lobby group accepted that the political campaign that it was mounting would fail, it compiled with the requirements without any great difficulty or, as far as I know, any great confusion.

SPEECH.PARA: Two more points should be made that are relevant to that issue. After the introductory period of the first three quarters, the system which will apply will be a provisional tax payment type of system and, therefore, quarterly returns will not have to be lodged. A quarterly assessment based on the previous year's payments will be issued. Also, the financial year-I am sure Senator Messner knows this, but he has not mentioned it-for this tax will end on 31 March instead of 30 June. So there will not be the bunching effect of the normal income tax administration and the administration of this tax at the same time.

On the question of exemptions and records, I have forgotten which is the relevant clause, but we went through some of this question the other day. There is a provision in the Bill whereby any employer who, while exercising reasonable care, has lost or destroyed records will not be held liable for those records. I think similar provisions exist in the Income Tax Assessment Act. On the question of exemptions that Senator Messner raised, if no benefit is being paid, there is no need to grant an exemption because there is no liability.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exemption to lodge a return.

—I do not think one can accept the proposition that there be a blanket exemption to lodge a return because there may be no liability at that stage or at any other time. Unless a return is lodged, the employer could well have commenced paying fringe benefits and the Australian Taxation Office would have no knowledge of their having been paid. If the knowledge subsequently became available the Taxation Office would be in at least a morally weak position to issue an assessment if the Commissioner had previously granted that employer an exemption. I know it is not the practice in all business, but in business generally it is a practice to keep records for seven years and, in many cases, for longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just two short questions to ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). I do not wish to trespass back to clause 57; I think the issue is covered under clause 66. There is some confusion in my mind as to whether or not a residence provided at a subsidised rent to a priest or a minister in the form of a manse or accommodation attached to a church will attract a fringe benefits tax. The other matter I wanted to raise relates to clause 58 (2) in which a `disadvantaged person' is defined as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a person who is intellectually, psychiatrically or physically handicapped or is in necessitous circumstance.

Would the definition of necessitous circumstances embrace the Jesus people or Salvation Army people who may be required to be on 24-hour call at a hostel because it may be related to the providing of assistance to people with a drug or drink problem and therefore these people require attention for the full day?

TALK.START.PARA: —Strictly speaking, we have passed these clauses. The first question of the honourable senator was about a priest or a minister occupying a manse or a presbytery. In the Bill as it has been presented to the Senate that is clearly exempt. A question was also raised with regard to clause 58. For example, a Salvationist working at an alcoholics home or an alcoholics night refuge, or whatever one wants to call it, and who is required to live in at the night refuge, would not be affected by the tax. It is not limited to that, but that is as good an example as I can think of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a very small problem relating to clause 134, which problem is to be found throughout the taxation assessment Acts. Can the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) inform me about the process of service of documents or notices upon people? Clause 134 deals with:

SPEECH.PARA: Service . . . of a notice . . . on a member of a partnership or on a member of the committee of management . . .

The clause goes on to state other things. One of the considerations in that clause is that the service may be by post. During the course of the Estimates committees and the Supplementary Estimates committee hearings I got some assessments of the performance of Australia Post which suggested that a number of documents did not actually reach their destination or that they reached their destination late. I would like to know what class of post is intended to be used here. What type of guidelines are being set up either by the Department or the Minister or are intended to be set up to make certain that documents sent through the postal system are delivered if this provision is going to be used in any type of legal proceedings?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, the provision is very similar, if not identical, to the relevant section in the Income Tax Assessment Act. I would expect that the same postal services that are used for that would be used for this liability. On the point that Senator Vigor has raised, while it is possible, maybe even probable, that some assessments posted are not received by the taxpayer, as a practical necessity I do not believe that there is any alternative other than for the Australian Taxation Office to assert that, because it has posted an assessment, the taxpayer has received it. If the Taxation Office were to say anything less than that there is the danger of massive tax evasion because half the taxpayers in the country might say `I did not get my assessment; it did not arrive', and who can prove that it did not? I think the onus of proof has to reside with the taxpayer and the Commissioner of Taxation because there is no practical alternative to it, while acknowledging that there might be a very occasional case where a taxpayer might have a legitimate grievance.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 143 (Remote area holiday transport).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 130, omit paragraph (k), insert the following paragraph:
`(k) either of the following conditions is satisfied:
(i) the benefit is provided pursuant to the provisions of an industrial instrument relating to the employment of the employee;

(ii) it is customary for employers in the industry in which the employee is employed to provide benefits of the same kind as the benefit provided to the recipient and to provide such benefits in similar circumstances to those that applied in relation to the provision of the benefit to the recipient.'.

During the last few weeks the media have stuck doggedly to the car fringe benefits tax issue, even though the problems of people in remote areas have been drawn to their attention on a number of occasions. One of the problems that I see is an inability of a number of our media sources to look beyond their own circumstances. Unfortunately, this is a real problem because I have been getting a large number of calls from country and remote areas where they have had misunderstandings concerning the fringe benefits tax. I believe that fringe benefits taxation should be structured actually to fall upon benefits and not upon the removal of disadvantages. If we stop caring about those in the remoter parts of Australia because there are `no votes in it', we will help to dig the nation's economic grave. I have had a number of representations from the local government associations of Queensland and New South Wales about their particular problems. Those problems are ones which refer to and fall very heavily upon rural and remote area councils. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from the Shire Council of Ilfracombe in Queensland which refers to these problems. I have shown the letter to the Minister.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Mr D. Vigor,...23rd May, 1986.
C/o Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T.
Dear Sir,
I am writing to express Council's concern over the effects the proposed Fringe Benefits Tax will have on our Shire.

You may or may not know that the Ilfracombe Shire is a small Shire in the Central West of Queensland. As such, the rate base is small, there is no area in which expansion of the rate base could take place.

The proposed Fringe Benefits Tax would cost approximately 1% of the Shire's rate revenue. As rates are the major portion of the Council's revenue any loss due to the tax would have to be offset in some other area.

As Council do not undertake any activities which could be termed as frivolous, cutbacks would be felt most strongly within the community. In a community of this size, any cutbacks in services has a most adverse effect.

A major portion of the tax would be in the area of subsidized housing rental. Council workers number over one half of the Ilfracombe population and subsidized rental is essential if we are to attract a qualified workforce. Should the proposed tax be passed into legislation, this Council would have to seriously consider a reduction in the permanent workforce. This alone would have serious ramifications for the community.
I trust you will see the concerns of Council are based on concern for this community and will have their viewpoint in mind when you are called upon to vote for the legislation.
Yours faithfully,
Richard Britain,
Acting Shire Clerk.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. The letter points out that the shire has a very small rate base which does not offer any scope for expansion, particularly under the current economic climate and situation. A severe fringe benefits tax would force the council to cut back services and that would have disastrous effects on the community which the council services. The Acting Shire Clerk points out that the council workers number over one half of the Ilfracombe population and that a housing rental subsidy is essential if the council is to attract qualified staff. Those who are used to all the facilities of metropolitan life may not think about these disadvantages at great length.

SPEECH.PARA: If we do not lift a finger to equalise opportunities and services we will have structural discrimination in our nation between those people living in cities and those people living in remote areas. The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill takes account of this remote area benefit but, in the course of discussions, I noticed a particular disadvantage with respect to holiday travel or to people travelling for their holidays from these remote areas to the nearest centre of culture, education or entertainment, which traditionally has been a benefit which has been granted to those employees. Unless the amendment which I have moved is passed, this benefit will be covered by the fringe benefits tax. I believe that if we actually disadvantage these remote areas we will lose a valuable part of our national heritage and identity.

I would like, firstly, to pay tribute to the excellent, detailed work of Mr Ted Chown, Secretary of the Country Shire Councils' Association of Western Australia. He has devoted an enormous amount of time and energy to specifying and quantifying these problems for me. In our discussions with the Government we have achieved amendments and changes to the legislation in a number of areas which have been accepted. However, this one came in fairly late. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from the Country Shire Councils' Association of Western Australia commenting on the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill and particularly on this problem.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator D. Vigor
C/- Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Sir,
FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986
The Country Shire Councils' Association of WA has examined the above Bill, and asks that the following anomalies be corrected-
1 Remote Area Holiday Travel

Free or subsidised travel provided under an award or industrial agreement for employees in remote locations will be taxable at 50% of the cost less any employee contribution. Generally, this type of provision exists in order to remove the disincentive of high travelling costs that accompany taking positions in remote locations. Return air fares to the capital city (or another equivalent) are provided by employers, including shire councils, north of the 26th parallel. By meeting such expenses employers are removing a disadvantage and not providing a benefit. Therefore, it is considered that the tax of this item does not fall within any fundamental principle of taxing fringe benefits. Even if it could be sustained that this item should be subject to FBT-

it is unfair that the same discount should apply to the north-west (of WA), where there are disabilities of both isolation and extreme climatic intemperance as in other remote areas: the taxable value for areas north of the 26th parallel should be no more than 10% of the cost.

there is no principle that would justify treating the same type of expense differently for employees under an award or industrial agreement to employees not subject to awards or industrial agreements. If the stipulation that ``the benefit is provided pursuant to the provisions of an industrial instrument relating to the employment of the employee'' is retained, the four shires in the Pilbara, for example, will be faced with an FBT bill of $142,348 on 100% of the cost of holiday travel, as none of the awards applying to Local Government provide for such benefits.
2 Housing Fringe Benefits-Remote Area Discount

The arbitrary definition of what is and is not a ``remote area'', for the purpose of assessing the taxable value of subsidised housing, would be good enough under the present Income Tax legislation where only 10% of the market rental value is assessable to the employee, but discriminates heavily against shires (and employers) north of the 26th parallel, if 60% of the market rental value, less rent paid, is to be assessable to employers.

The Treasurer said in his Second Reading Speech that the 40% remote area discount is in recognition of the cost disadvantages of constructing accommodation in remote areas. This percentage discount would generally satisfy employers with staff housing in the south of Western Australia, but as the attached tables indicate, an average building index for housing north of the 26th parallel is 1.56.

The particularly high indices for some localities north of the 26th parallel, see Table 2, are caused by such factors as a need to build to withstand cyclonic conditions (wind pressures up to 250 km per hour) and extreme remoteness from supply of building materials and building labour.
Because of the high indices of a significant number of these Local Government areas, the remote area discount on rentals north of the 26th parallel should be not less than 60%.
3 Car Fringe Benefits

Local Governments nation-wide are particularly concerned about the level of taxable value applicable to car fringe benefits, especially when travelling to and from work is classified as private running, and while Local Government personnel receive some benefit from taking a car home, they are also allowed the privilege because they are liable to call-out, and to save the employer garaging and security costs.
There are grounds, therefore, for arguing that running to and from work is business mileage.

The high level of tax payable under the statutory formula method of assessing taxable values will lead some employers to withdraw private car use, and this regrettably will cause a decline in goodwill, and therefore productivity, and the ultimate losers in Local Government will be the employees and residents of the municipality.

CSCA submits that the automotive industry, other Government revenue sources (income tax, sales tax, payroll tax, etc.) and employer/employee/consumer interests, would be better protected if car fringe benefits were calculated, in a full year, on the following statutory formula-
Total Kilometres Travelled
Taxable Value as %
of Base Value
Less than 25,000...
More than 40,000...

It has been explained to CSCA membership that the objective of FBT is to close the loop holes whereby many Australians are currently avoiding or evading tax through taking fringe benefits from their employer other than cash. One cannot argue with this objective, but the fact remains that councils which have to provide fringe benefits in order to attract staff, often at very considerable cost to the ratepaying community, will now be taxed on the cost of this disability, at further expense to the ratepayer. An endeavour to pass on all or part of this tax to the employee will mean in some cases it will be more difficult to acquire employees for the district, and in other cases the employees will want penalty and overtime payments for concessions which they would otherwise provide. The worker and the community will be the loser.
The Executive Committee of CSCA strongly believes-
that the 50% discount on holiday travel to areas north of the 26th parallel is insufficient: such travel should either be exempt or taxed on 10% of the cost;
holiday travel discount at the applicable rate should apply to all `remote area' employers, not just those providing holiday travel under an award or industrial agreement;
the remote area discount on housing rentals north of the 26th parallel should be not less than 60%; and
the proposed taxable value of car fringe benefits as a percentage of base value should be halved.
CSCA would be most grateful if you would exert your influence to have changes to the Bill made, accordingly.
Yours faithfully
A. BLAKENEY
E. L. CHOWN
Secretary
The Country Shire Councils' Association of WA (Inc)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. The letter makes the point very strongly that the provision of yearly travel entitlements to those in remote areas is not a benefit; it is the removal of a disadvantage which people have. This disadvantage applies both to employees and to employers. Employees do not have access to facilities which most Australians can take for granted. Employers have no hope of attracting top-notch staff, such as shire engineers and people of this nature, in the face of stiff competition from elsewhere unless some travel is part of the employment package.

SPEECH.PARA: Taxing such travel is a great disadvantage to this country as we must utilise our people's talents to the full. The amendment that I have moved seeks to equalise employment opportunities around the nation. Basically, the Government had allowed only a deduction of holiday travel if that was built into an industrial instrument. What we are doing with this amendment, which I believe the Government will be accepting, is extending this process to travel which is offered customarily by employers to members of their staff. The wording that I have used in my amendment is exactly the same wording as has been used in the housing area and I believe that it should apply also to holiday travel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the spirit of ecumenism the Government is accepting the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I put it on record that the Opposition was opposed to clauses 40 to 143 that we were discussing earlier although it chose not to divide on them. I address my remarks to clause 148, which has been the subject of some debate in the Senate. I merely want to put on record some interesting remarks that have been made about this clause of the Bill by the Law Council of Australia and, in particular, its Taxation Committee under the Chairmanship of Mr Kevin J. Burges. Earlier in the debate the Opposition spoke about what it sees as being the problems arising from the fact that, having established that there is an employer-employee relationship, that a fringe benefit is provided and that it is the prerequisite for the establishment of the imposition of the fringe benefits tax, clause 148 of the Bill appears to broaden the whole idea of the meaning of the words `in respect of employment'. Indeed, it seems that this can be extended to almost any situation. I instance the situation of a child working on his father's farm and occupying accommodation provided by his father. That might be thought to be being provided as part of the ordinary family arrangements but, because of the apparent breadth of clause 148, that could indeed be seen as being related to the employment of the son in the farming business. That is just one instance, but there are numerous others that we could put forward as examples of what we see as the apparent breadth of that clause and the interpretations that we believe will probably be put upon it by the Commissioner of Taxation and others at some later time when assessments flow into the Taxation Office. For that reason, I would like to record in Hansard the advice of the Law Council of Australia. I quote from the letter I mentioned earlier:

SPEECH.PARA: Hence, to take the case of a private company director, the link with employment comes in at two stages. Firstly, in the definition flowing from section 221a of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the amount paid to the director must be `by way of remuneration'. Secondly, under the definition of fringe benefit the benefit must be `in respect of the employment'.

Thus, the provisions quite properly seek to limit the tax to something relating to employment. In other words the benefit must be a true `fringe benefit' or part of an `employee remuneration package', which was the original evil this legislation was said to be aimed at.
However, this is virtually nullified by the provisions of section 148 (1).

That section reads down the essential link of the fringe benefit being provided `in respect of the employment' to the extent that the connection is virtually eliminated. This appears from the sub-clauses (a) and (h) especially of section 148 (1). These provide that a reference to the provision of a benefit to a person in respect of the employment is a reference to the provision of such a benefit whether or not it is also provided in respect of some other matter or thing, and whether or not the benefit is provided as a reward for services rendered by the employee.

I make the point again that the Law Council supports the point we were making in earlier debate on this matter. It seems that the extension by virtue of clause 148 will make it so that, even though something may be provided in respect of some other relationship existing between two people, if there is some connection, be it past, future or current, that relates to the employment of that person by the other, it could be overridden by virtue of this clause so as to bring it within the total aegis of the law and treated as a fringe benefit. As an example, I spoke of a son working for his father or for the family business, which happens to be an incorporated company, and receiving some kind of remuneration in cash and then receiving wedding presents or some other kind of gain or benefit as a result of his family relationship with his employer.

Having debated this matter at length for some time, I wanted merely to put the opinion of the Law Council of Australia on the record. Hopefully, that will lead to the interpretation of the law in the way in which it has been explained by the responsible Minister during the debate over the last few days.

TALK.START.PARA: —I place on record the fact that the Australian Democrats also received lawyers representing the Law Council of Australia yesterday. They drew our attention to a possible conflict in clause 148. We did not have time to get any legal opinion on their contention and, as such, the Democrats are not in a position to state firmly one way or the other whether we believe there is a problem with clause 148. Prima facie it appears to us that there is very likely a conflict in the clause. I believe that at this late stage all the Democrats can do is join with the Opposition in drawing the Government's attention to a potential problem in the legislation. I hope we will get an assurance from the Minister that this matter will be looked at. It does seem to be quite serious.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any reasonable request to look at any clause will be acceded to. Like Senator Siddons I would not make any pretence to making any judgments about whether all the claims that have been made have any validity. But I want to observe for the record that a lot of lawyers make a lot of money out of nitpicking and speaking at learned seminars.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a day of shame for the passage of this legislation which will obviously impose considerable hardships upon the Australian business community at a time when investment is called for, when a commitment to develop the Australian economy is called for, and at a time when we have had the worst economic results for many years which have clearly resulted from the management of this Hawke Labor Government. It comes at a time when we need more incentive in business and more incentive to create jobs, yet this Government persists in introducing a measure which will destroy jobs in the car industry, the rural community and across the broad spectrum of the Australian economy. Why the Government is so persistent with this measure fails all understanding. We, on this side, as we have demonstrated consistently throughout this debate, stand clearly for the repeal of this ridiculous legislation which will impose further costs not only on the Government and through that on the taxpayer, but also directly on business in such a way as it will destroy jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: I will return in a moment to one or two points in that respect, but I will correct firstly some of the assertions made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) earlier in the debate a couple of days ago when he reported the remarks of Mr Joseph O'Neill who is the Director of the Catholic Family Welfare Bureau of Adelaide. The Minister quoted Mr O'Neill as being supportive of the fringe benefits taxation. However, Mr O'Neill has now contacted the Opposition and wishes it to be known that he had been misquoted and misinterpreted by the Minister in this regard. While it is true that he believes that there is inequity in the taxation system-and nobody would disagree with that-he believes that the Government, in deciding to tax the employer rather than the recipient of fringe benefits, avoids confronting the inequity and social injustice issue. The scandal of an inequitable tax free area for lowly paid, as well as highly paid people, remains. Taxing the employer compounds the injustice, since employers are obliged to pay the additional tax, which inevitably will be passed on to the consumers, who are most likely to be the lower paid earners in the community. Quite clearly, the result of this stupid taxation measure will result in further impositions not only by way of direct tax costs, but also by inflation in the supermarket and in the cost of living for ordinary Australians. That will be the result of this taxation measure, and the Government stands condemned for it.

During the debate we drew attention to the fact that the Government is plainly wrong in its assumption as to the real effects of the legislation. The impact of the new system will be to encourage employers to cash up and pay out the benefits which have otherwise been provided up until now in cash. That will mean that those employers will obtain a tax deduction for that amount, and that means that the received amount in cash by the low income earners, by the employees, will be taxed in their hands. So the net result of this measure will be to tax the employee not the employer. It is quite clear, if one reads the Hansard, that my argument shows quite clearly that the top income earners who are on fringe benefits will not be in that category of workers who find that their benefits are cashed out. It will be those at the lower end of the income scale, those who are paying less than 29 per cent taxation, who will find that they will have to pay tax on the cashed out benefits. That is the Government's intention. It is the intention of those opposite to encourage employers to do that, and it will mean that the employee will end up paying the tax, not the employer. That will be the end result of this most ridiculous and stupid measure which will also have the effect of destroying jobs on the way through.

Finally, I would just like to test this legislation against the criteria set down by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) regarding tax reform. We spoke earlier of the nine taxation commandments which Prime Minister Hawke laid down before the National Taxation Summit which proved so disastrous last year. There are three in particular to which I draw the Senate's attention. The first is: `Any reform must simplify the system so that all Australians can understand it more easily, and therefore make avoidance and evasion more difficult'. If anything is going to perpetuate avoidance and evasion it is this measure; people will be encouraged to avoid it because it is a greater imposition. How can we possibly claim that this fantastically convoluted and complicated piece of legislation simplifies the tax system in Australia? It simply does not. It will require hundreds of public servants to administer it; it will impose huge workloads on the business community to keep individual records of what every motor car they run is doing in the way of mileage, how many gallons of fuel it is using, how many nuts and bolts being applied to it, and so on. This will add incredibly to the cost of employing people in the community which in the end means that jobs will be destroyed.

The second commandment is that any reform must provide the best possible climate for investment, growth and employment. Clearly, this tax will destroy all of those things and will work in exactly the opposite way to the Hawke so-called commandments. The third commandment is that any reform package must have widespread community support. I cannot imagine a tax measure that has less community support than this one has. Clearly, as a result of the detailed information to business put out by the Government, a widespread understanding of this legislation is sinking in and people are realising that it is going to destroy jobs in this community. It is a sad tragedy for Australians that we cannot take a stand right here today to defeat this measure. I make a last call to the Australian Democrats to join with the Liberal and National parties and vote against this legislation at the third reading stage and thereby destroy this iniquitous and ridiculous measure which can only destroy the potential for investment and recovery in this economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly on the motion for the third reading of this legislation. The debate has been long and tedious. However, I believe that I should draw attention to the contrast between the Australian Democrats' point of view on this legislation and that of the Opposition. Members of the Opposition have opposed this legislation outright at every possible stage and spoken at length on the clauses at every possible opportunity. It would have been easy for the Democrats to have joined with the Opposition. Such action would have destroyed this legislation. However, it would have destroyed a very significant attempt to crack down on widespread tax avoidance and rorts in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Something had to be done about fringe benefits being used as a blatant means of tax avoidance. The Australian Democrats recognised that. We recognised the inequity of the system. Therefore, we discussed the matter with the Government to see whether the worst aspects of this fringe benefits legislation could be altered to lessen its impact. At no stage have we agreed with the general thrust of what the Government has done. We believe that the legislation is too complicated and that it could have been simplified. However, the fact remains that there is a need for such legislation. The Democrats are not in the business of standing flat-footed, blocking a very important Government initiative and leaving the way open for the Government to call a double dissolution on this matter if it wished to do so. I believe that the approach by the Opposition was very simplistic.

As I mentioned during the Committee stage, the Democrats' negotiations and discussions with the Government have resulted in a $200m saving on the fringe benefits tax on motor cars alone. When I stated that during the Committee stage, the Opposition would not believe that there would be a $200m saving. Let me do the simple arithmetic. Only three lines are needed to show the way in which that saving can be achieved. Let us assume that the average price of a motor car is $16,000. Our tax breaks will result in an average reduction of 5 per cent in the taxable price of a car.

TALK.START.PARA: —Big deal!

—The honourable senator says that it is a big deal. I will explain why that is so. This 5 per cent reduction translates into 2.5 per cent reduction in tax payable by companies. This equals-I am sure the simple arithmetic is obvious even to the Opposition-$400 a car. If we multiply that amount by the 500,000 motor cars involved in respect of this tax the answer, believe it or not, is $200m. This is not an insignificant concession by the Government as a result of the Democrats' efforts in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: We also discussed with the Government the problems of welfare organisations. We pointed out that the fringe benefits tax could apply to welfare organisations in an unfair way. In September and October last year the Government gave us an assurance that genuine existing welfare organisations would not be disadvantaged. In fact, when the legislation came forth we found that the Government had not really honoured its promise as far as welfare organisations were concerned. We discussed the matter with the Opposition, and last night an amendment was moved to take account of genuine welfare organisations. As a result, those organisations will not be disadvantaged. These two very significant and important changes to the legislation have been made since debate first took place on the fringe benefits tax.

At no stage have the Democrats been prepared to block important legislation which attempts to make a fundamental tax reform in an area that has been crying out for reform. Senior executives and people in the top echelons of business have been getting all kinds of fringe benefits on which they have not been paying tax. That situation is unfair and inequitable. Something had to be done about this situation which had been escalating at a dramatic rate year by year. At least this legislation is now in a form that will not affect dramatically jobs in the motor car industry. The amended fringe benefits tax on motor cars will save, as the industry itself says, between 10,000 and 20,000 jobs. This is a very, very significant factor. For that reason we are proud of the stand that the Democrats have taken. At least it is far more imaginative and far more constructive that the attitude of the Opposition which is: `We will block the legislation; we will use this as an excuse to go to the people in an early election'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply wish to respond very briefly to the point made by Senator Siddons on behalf of the Australian Democrats.
—Labor rats.

—I point out that the disgraceful role of the Democrats, in allowing this destructive and disastrous legislation through, resulted in the convenor of the Hawkesbury branch of the Australian Democrats ringing me this morning and saying that he is resigning his position in disgust at the Australian Democrats' performance. I might also mention that a representative of a major Australian-wide construction company rang my office seeking assistance with the fringe benefits tax booklet. The representative rang the New South Wales telephone number listed in that booklet but the people he talked to could not answer the simple questions he put relating to the use by construction firms of four-wheel drive vehicles on remote sites. He also rang the Melbourne inquiry number but could get no answer to his question.
—It sounds like the assets test again.
—Exactly. The people in Melbourne did not know the answers.
—He would not have got the answer from the Democrats either.
—That is the important question. That is exactly what happened when he did ring the Australian Democrats.
—He would probably get two different answers-both of them wrong.

—The answer he did get was that they did not want to enter into discussions on the fringe benefits tax with someone who was vitally affected in this way. They did not want to know. The Australian Democrats did not want to talk to a person who was experiencing a major problem which would do immense damage to his business and his capacity to employ people basically because he would say things to them which would be totally contrary to the arrant nonsense that we have heard in this chamber from these people. As my good friend Senator Puplick said a little earlier by way of interjection, `the Australian Democrats' may be their title, but they are the Australian Labor rats in this chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, will be absent from the chamber during Question Time today. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Grimes in relation to his portfolio or to those he represents should be addressed to the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan. Any questions concerning the management of Government Business in the Senate should be directed to me.
