—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to reports that the Government is considering ways in which it might stimulate the level of private sector investment. I refer the Minister also to criticism of investment performance, particularly from the trade union movement, and note that there has been little attempt to address the reasons for the slump. Can the Minister explain why he believes that we have now experienced three successive quarters of reduced private capital investment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The simple answer to the question is largely because of high interest rates. That is my interpretation of why there has been a lower level of investment in the past three quarters. Also there has probably been a little uncertainty in some sectors of the business community about the value of the dollar. I think those things have been factors which have probably influenced the matter. The honourable senator referred to the slump in private sector investment. Let me remind him that in the middle of last year private sector investment was running at quite a better rate than the Government had expected. Private sector investment until quite recently was running at a better level, particularly in the area of manufacturing, than the Government had expected.

ANSWER.PARA: Further, I make the point that many of the problems of the manufacturing sector, particularly at the moment, are related most strongly to the appalling level of private sector investment in manufacturing during the 1970s. I saw a report recently by a bank or some other organisation which made the point that private sector investment had increased by a level of one per cent each year during the 1970s, which was not comparable with private sector investment in other countries. It is that very low base which is of most concern to the Government and should be of most concern to thinking commentators in looking at the question of the trade difficulties with which this country is currently bedevilled.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs will be aware of calls by the Australian Medical Association for its member doctors to scrap wholesale bulk billing of disadvantaged patients, such as the unemployed, pensioners and low income earners. Will this decision have any impact on Veterans Affairs' beneficiaries? Will the Minister outline his response to the AMA's call?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Childs's question, I confirm that my Department has been having discussions for quite some months with the Australian Medical Association over the question of fees. However, the latest statement from the Australian Medical Association does not acknowledge that point. Therefore, I think it is fair to assume that veterans are to be caught up in the latest proposal of the Australian Medical Association to discontinue the principle of bulk billing, upon which the Department of Veterans' Affairs has operated since World War I.

ANSWER.PARA: My Department pays local medical officers-there are close to 11,000 of them-85 per cent of the schedule fee plus a 60c surcharge per patient as an added bonus for treating repatriation patients. The Australian Medical Association for the last couple of years has suggested that that 60c surcharge per patient is inadequate. In November last year the AMA served notice on the Department that if the 60c surcharge were not increased, it would consider directing doctors to withdraw services to veterans. I find it somewhat disconcerting as well as alarming that the medical profession fails to appreciate the current economic conditions or to respond to the pleas that have been made by the business community generally for a degree of restraint. It appears that it is not prepared to apply the principles of restraint which many commentators and economists have suggested that all sections of the Australian community should take on board.

I do not know of any medico who is losing money, going bankrupt or living in straitened circumstances. In fact, doctors who have repatriation patients have a steady clientele. They can ask the patient to come back as often as they wish. The Department's commitment to the payment of LMOs is very considerable. The Commonwealth, of course, would be billed through Medicare for 85 per cent of the schedule fee in regard to veteran patients. If the AMA's proposition was adopted, the individual patient would then be billed the difference between that figure and 100 per cent of the fee. I find this completely unacceptable, as doctors' incomes through Medicare are subsidised to the extent of $2.6 billion a year. One can only say that it is an avaricious attempt by a well-heeled section of the Australian community to take advantage of the current situation in order to create even further difficulties for the Government, which is taking a responsible attitude to health services, including veterans' affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Science confirm that in the last three years Commonwealth funding for the Bureau of Meteorology re-equipment program has fallen $1.3m short of the Australian Science and Technology Council recommendations, despite the fact that ASTEC warned that these funding levels should be regarded as an absolute minimum? Will the Minister give an assurance to commit $33.5m to the Bureau over the next five years, in light of the dire warnings from the meteorology policy committee that without such action a major breakdown in the Bureau's fragile warning infrastructure, with serious implications for safety of life and limb, is a real possibility?

—I cannot confirm any of Senator Archer's dire forebodings. Let me say that I take it that what the honourable senator said is correct. I always try to be charitable and understanding in regard to the veracity of questions asked in this place. In regard to the second part of the question, it is a matter which must be addressed in the Budget context. I have heard noises to suggest that it is high on the agenda for consideration in the budgetary process. I guess an announcement will be made at the appropriate time.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware of criticism that spending on the national road system is slowing down? How much is the Federal Government spending on the development of Australia's national highways? How much of the system has been completed to date? What progress is being made in New South Wales?

—The Government's record on road allocations is well recognised by the States and the Northern Territory as being reasonable considering the general economic climate of Australia. For example, in 1985-86 the Federal Government has allocated a record $1.245 billion to the States and Northern Territory for roads. This is an increase of 82 per cent over the amount provided in 1981-82, the second last year of the previous coalition Government. The major priority that the Government has set itself is to upgrade the national highway system to provide for the safe, efficient and reliable carriage of traffic between Australia's mainland capital cities, between Brisbane and Cairns and between Hobart and Burnie. The Government accepts the need for an efficient highway system, not only for the purpose of the carriage of passengers, but also for the carriage of goods because we recognise the importance of that to the nation as a whole. Therefore, the Government accepts the full construction and maintenance costs of the national highway system. Most of the $560m which the Federal Government has allocated for roads in the 1985-86 Budget will be spent on national highways and that represents a considerable increase on the projects that were approved by the previous Government under the national highway program for the Bicentenary. I think it can be said without any doubt that this Government has accepted its responsibility for improving our national highway system and has put its money where its mouth is.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Does the Dibb report on the Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities agree that self-reliance is the most sensible and effective defence for Australia? Does the Government accept this idea and does it believe that, if it is able to convince the Australian public that defence self-reliance is possible for Australia, the electorate will question the use and need for the American alliance and will reject ANZUS because it does not serve this nation's defence needs but is part of the United States' military planning and thinking?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that the Minister for Defence indicated yesterday in his statement on the Dibb report that there is no contradiction whatever between a self-reliant Australia and the maintenance of our alliance relationship with the United States. That point is dealt with in considerable detail by Mr Beazley in his statement and I refer Senator Chipp to it. In fact, I seek leave to incorporate the relevant paragraph of the statement in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
A self-reliant Australia is an expectation both of the Australian people and of our allies. It has been required by our principal ally, the United States since the early 1970s.

This requirement has been reiterated by successive United States administrations. In a major policy statement in November 1984, Secretary of Defense Caspar Weinberger said `We have learned that there are limits to how much of our spirit and blood and treasure we can afford to forfeit in meeting our responsibility to keep peace and freedom. So while we may and should offer substantial amounts of economic and military assistance to our allies in their time of need, and help them maintain forces to deter attacks against them we cannot substitute our troops or our will for theirs.'
The previous government recognised the relationship between self-reliance and a sound contribution to alliance relationships when it said in its 1976 white paper:

`This self-reliant posture derives essentially from our own national interests and responsibilities. It also accords with our status as an ally of the U.S., for by accepting our local responsibilities we can contribute to the alliance relationship and to the U.S. global effort.'

The ability to defend itself is the absolute minimum that any self-respecting country should contribute to an alliance. Australia can scarcely pretend to contribute to the defence of broader western interests if it cannot even defend itself. Indeed, as U.S. Secretary of Defense Weinberger said at the National Press Club in April,
`Defence of a country's own borders and own airspace and the sea around it, obviously, is a prime attribute of sovereignty and, of course, has to be one of the first priorities of any country.'

So a policy of self-reliance contributes to the strength of the alliance. And Australia makes a further substantial contribution to western security, as well as to international stability, by hosting the joint defence facilities and through a range of other cooperative activities, such as regular visits by ships of the U.S. navy.

Equally, the alliance with the United States contributes to Australia's ability to defend itself. Mr Dibb concludes that a self-reliant defence of a continent the size of ours demands access to intelligence, high-technology sensors and military equipment. For much of this the United States is the best source by far, and for some it is the only source. This is an important conclusion, and one which should not be overlooked in our thinking about the defence relationship with the United States.

Our U.S. alliance will remain a significant deterrent to any potential aggressor. Any nation contemplating the use of force against us would have to reckon with the help-including possibly the direct military assistance which the U.S. might provide to Australia. That possibility would inevitably be a major complication in the plans of any would-be attacker, and thus it serves as a powerful deterrent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also refer Senator Chipp to page 46 of Mr Dibb's Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities which spells out in some detail the practical benefits of the ANZUS relationship to Australia's independent defence interests. These benefits in short include access to the highest levels of military technology and intelligence, without which it would be impossible for a population the size of Australia's-only one-half of one per cent of the earth's population-to attempt to exercise military control over 10 per cent of the earth's surface as the Dibb review recommends. Indeed, a self-reliant defence posture is impossible without the kind of technological assistance which the United States gives us. On a broader level again, the United States alliance remains a powerful deterrent to any would-be attacker. Lastly, it should be pointed out that our hosting of the joint facilities under the alliance-although not, of course, ANZUS itself-contributes to the security of all Australians by strengthening deterrence in the short term and improving prospects for arms control in the longer term. Once these points are fully appreciated-as I am sure they are already by most Australians-there will be no question whatever of the use and need for the United States alliance being questioned.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CANBERRA COLLEGE OF ADVANCED EDUCATION: COURSE APPROVAL DELAYS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I refer her to a report in today's Canberra Times which alleges that there have been course approval delays at the Canberra College of Advanced Education which have affected student graduation. These delays are said to have been caused by `hitches in administration' and call into question the whole process of accreditation. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether these claims are correct and can she explain who is responsible for the delays in accreditation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the report in today's Canberra Times claiming delays in accreditation of Canberra CAE courses. The report is wrong factually in several ways and before I point those out I wish to explain to the Senate that accreditation and national registration of advanced education courses are part of the system nationally agreed between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory. Canberra College of Advanced Education courses undergo the same accreditation processes as courses in the States with the exception that CCAE courses do not have to be accredited before being introduced. Accreditation is the public certification that the course meets agreed standards. Because it is the assurance of course quality for students, employers and the community, it is important that it be undertaken properly. It is my responsibility, and not that of the assessment panels, to approve the accreditation and reaccreditation of courses. I am advised in this matter by a part-time committee-the Commonwealth Institutions Accreditation Committee for Advanced Education.

ANSWER.PARA: The number of assessment panels convened by the Committee has increased from nine in 1984 to 23 in 1985 and some 30 are expected to be convened in 1986. As a result, my Department has restructured the accreditation secretariat and provided additional staff increasing the number from only one in 1985 to three at present. These increased staffing resources have been provided at the expense of other areas of the Department. I have been reviewing accreditation procedures and have recently approved new procedures which would allow the college to take more responsibility for the administration of course assessment. In addition, the whole matter of accreditation procedures was discussed by the Committee and the CCAE last month and agreements were reached about measures to streamline accreditation processes from both ends.

The newspaper report contains a number of inaccuracies which need to be corrected. Delays in accreditation which may have affected graduations are generally the responsibility of the college where courses have been submitted late. There have been instances where the college has taken up to three years from the date of the first intake into the courses to put forward a submission. However, I understand that the new arrangements discussed by the college and the Committee will avoid such problems in the future. The claim that there are 88 courses awaiting approval by the Department of Education is nonsense; 54 have not yet been submitted by the college. The CIACE, the accreditation committee, will have arranged panel visits by the end of this year for all courses so far received. I reject the notion that the whole process of accreditation has been called into question. Accreditation is an important assurance of quality to the community, employers and students. The accreditation process is nationally accepted and all Ministers for Education have recently agreed to include the technical and further education sector in the process through the establishment of the Australian Council on Tertiary Awards. I am confident that the new procedures and arrangements agreed by me and discussed between the Committee and the college will minimise delays in the accreditation process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move that the Senate take note of the paper.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that the honourable senator should do that at the end of Question Time. However, he may seek leave if he insists.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave not granted.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CANBERRA COLLEGE OF ADVANCED EDUCATION: COURSE APPROVAL DELAYS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and also concerns this extraordinary confusion that has arisen for the Canberra College of Advanced Education, to which Senator McKiernan has already pointed. It also concerns the Minister's failure, or that of her Department, to administer the cumbersome bureaucracy required for the accreditation of advanced education courses. The explanation that has been given that accreditation is important still leaves these questions open. Is it correct that there are courses which have been submitted to the Minister or the Department for two years and which have not yet been accredited? Is it true that there is confusion in that graduation ceremonies have been held when diplomas have been granted with the undertaking that the correct name and content of the diploma would be inserted when the course became lawful-that is, when the Minister's accreditation had been administered? Do the partial remedies that the Minister has offered here today meet fully the requests of Dr Parfitt, the Principal, and Dr Overheu, the Pro-Principal? Finally, how many other colleges of advanced education in Australia are free from this kind of disarray?

—I thought I gave a very long and adequate answer to the matters raised by Senator Teague in my answer to Senator McKiernan's question. Because I endeavoured to be as comprehensive as possible I had some objection to the form of my answer from Senator Lewis. Nonetheless, Senator Teague has seen fit to rise and ask in very garbled terms a question similar to Senator McKiernan's. I have given the information in answer to those questions. If Doctor Parfitt is responsible for the media reports in the Canberra Times I am sorry to say that Dr Parfitt is seriously wrong. The delays, as I have been pointing out, are delays at the college end. There have been cases of students being in courses for three years without a submission having come from the college to the Commonwealth Institutions Accreditation Committee for Advanced Education for approval. If there are any other outstanding matters, I do not have information about them yet. If Senator Teague had listened to the answer instead of getting himself into a state of excitement about asking the same question again, I think he would have been much better off.

—I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that although she is responsible for this confusion, and she admitted it clearly, she is not able to say that she has met all of the requests of the Canberra College and that she is involved at the moment in a dispute with the Canberra College of Advanced Education? I also asked the Minister a specific question. If she cannot answer them now, will she undertake to give answers in due course?

—I must make it clear that I have not said that I am responsible for the delays and confusion and I have not said that my Department is responsible; I have said that the Canberra College of Advanced Education is responsible.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to an article by David Barnett in this week's Bulletin which makes claims about the effects of the Government's tax reforms on the tourist industry, the restaurant industry, farmers, shopkeepers and consultants. Will the Minister indicate whether the figures contained in the article and the views expressed therein are accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be surprised if anything that Barnett has written were accurate-it would be purely by accident. The purpose of the article is clearly a desperate last ditch attempt to scare the wits out of the Australian Democrats with regard to the fringe benefits tax legislation and an equally desperate last ditch attempt to preserve rorts and rip-offs-an area in which David Barnett has a long and undistinguished history. Among other things he quotes an organisation with the acronym BAND-which is Business Against Non-Deductibility. That is the same organisation which, just before Christmas, advertised that, as a result of the ending of the businessman's free lunch, the breweries and the wineries would suffer grievously. I drew attention to this in answer to a question in the Senate and said that BAND was the organisation that was implying that executives were in the habit of getting on the booze at lunchtime at taxpayers' expense instead of going back to their offices and doing some work. After I said that, the organisation dropped the reference to the breweries and wineries from its advertisements. Nevertheless it is continuing its campaign.

ANSWER.PARA: David Barnett, completely uncritically, quotes this organisation as having conducted what he calls a survey of restaurants in Brisbane and Adelaide, which showed that in Brisbane there has been a 15 per cent decline in turnover. He went on to say that 11,000 jobs had been lost in the restaurant industry. As far as I can tell, he did not even attempt to source that statement to BAND.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did Barnett work for Fraser?

—He did. I will say something about that later on. That figure of 15 per cent can be compared with another figure quoted by Len Evans, with whom the Chairman of the Liberal Party's Waste Watch Committee has had a long and intellectually incestuous relationship. Mr Evans, in one of his recent self-indulgence columns, regurgitated some of the shonky figures which Senator Michael Baume has presented on this issue and then claimed that his restaurants had lost 23 per cent of their trade, which, I would have thought, is a comment more on the quality of Mr Evans's restaurants than on the ending of the free lunch. If 23 per cent of their trade was dependent upon the tax deductible lunch, and Mr Evans has lost 23 per cent, and on any objective evidence that is available other restaurants in the country, on balance, have lost no trade at all, I think something is being said about the quality of Mr Evans's restaurants.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Clearly the Minister is debating the question. I am sorry that the Standing Orders do not permit me to take a point of order which would remind you and honourable senators that the Minister is simply traducing anybody who dares say anything against this Government. It is the most pathetic abuse of this chamber. I take the point of order on the basis that the Minister is clearly debating the question. He should be made to give a straightforward answer and then have to sit down.

—Order! I remind the Minister of standing order 100 which clearly says that in answering a question a senator should not debate the matter. I ask the Minister to bear that in mind in the completion of his answer.
—Certainly, Mr President. I shall stick to questions of fact. In the article to which Senator Bolkus referred, Barnett asserts:

ANSWER.PARA: A farmer who drives into town to buy spare parts and takes along his wife so she can visit the supermarket will incur fringe benefits tax.
Wrong! He continues:
A shopkeeper who buys his child a birthday present and then subsequently puts him to work behind the counter will retrospectively incur fringe benefits tax . . .
Wrong! David Barnett states:

People using company cars will be required to keep log books with a daily record showing the date of each journey, the odometer readings at the beginning and end, the number of kilometres travelled . . .
Wrong! The article continues:
Farmers also will have to record each trip out into the paddocks and whether it was to, say, deliver hay to their stock or to fix a fence.

Wrong! That is not an exhaustive assessment of the errors of fact in the article. Ironically in the very same issue of the Bulletin, there is a letter from Mr Wrigley, the Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, in which Mr Wrigley responds to a previous and equally false argument from Mr Barnett about ASIO. Mr Wrigley says, among other things:
I had heard from the ASIO officer with whom he spoke--
`he' being Mr Barnett--
on the telephone a few days previously that Mr Barnett had called, ostensibly to ``check some information'', but that he seemed to have been singularly unresponsive to advice on that information.
Moreover, when my man offered to have me call him back, Mr Barnett's anxiety to go into print with what he had already written evidently overcame any temptation the offer may have presented.
That is typical of Mr Barnett's journalistic style. He rang--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister is now clearly getting into the area to which standing order 100 relates. I ask him to bring his answer to a conclusion.

—Certainly, Mr President. The evidence was incompatible with the predetermined conclusions, so it was ignored. Finally, as Senator Bolkus's question suggests, Mr Barnett has a long history of being a defender of rorts and ramps, which is probably related to the fact that he was the greatest rorter of the lot. Indeed, in the first year that he was Mr Fraser's Press Secretary, he stuck his snout so far into the public trough that he nearly poked a hole in it.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. The information which we are about to cop has already been put down once in the Senate. Again, I think the Minister is being totally self-indulgent to the detriment of Question Time and in breach of the Standing Orders, which require him to answer questions or to desist.
—Order! I ask the Minister to bring his answer to a conclusion.

—I wish to speak on the point of order, Mr President. In this article, this journalist, if one can use the term loosely, has abused a great number of individuals and organisations. He has done this on occasions totally without any basis of fact at all. I do not know how many readers he has, but we have no way of responding to those vile allegations except in this place. I suggest that the credibility of Mr Barnett is severely under question and that the Minister is quite entitled to report to the Senate some of the background of this gentleman.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bolkus asked Senator Walsh a question. Standing order 100 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: In answering any such Question, a Senator shall not debate the matter to which the same refers.

It is my responsibility to see that the Standing Orders are adhered to. It is my opinion that Senator Walsh is getting well into the realm of debate. I therefore ask him to bring his answer to a conclusion. As to Senator Chipp's point of order, I suggest to him that there are ample opportunities other than Question Time for honourable senators to raise any matter in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am just finishing. In that year he drew a salary of $38,743 and $63,584 in overtime making a total in excess of $102,000 which was more than the Prime Minister drew.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Bolkus having addressed a supplementary question to the Minister representing the Treasurer-
Senator Chaney-Mr President, I ask you to stop this farce and to rule that that is not a supplementary question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I rule the supplementary question out of order.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the dramatic decline in world prices for orange juice and the threat to the Australian industry through the cheap importation of Brazilian orange juice concentrate that has fallen approximately 44 per cent in price since last June. When will the Government respond to the industry's request for special assistance to help the industry adjust to this dramatically changed market situation? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry is to be held? If so, can he ensure that this proceeds with the utmost urgency?

—I try to cover the 78-odd industries that fall within my portfolio but I must say that I have not given a high priority to orange juice. Nonetheless, from the point of view of orange juice producers and orange squeezers who are employed in various establishments, no doubt it is a very important question. I am fully aware of the increased market share of the Brazilian orange juice industry, if that is how the honourable senator described it, and the dramatic fall in prices of orange juice. I am not aware at this stage of any request for assistance having been made by the industry but I will look into that. The industry has a couple of options. Whether it seeks an IAC inquiry in search of temporary assistance or whether it alleges that the product in question has been dumped are two of the avenues open to it. I am certainly not aware of either of those steps having been taken, but if they have been taken I will try to provide a more detailed response to the honourable senator as soon as possible.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs seen the article in this week's Catholic Leader headed `Aboriginal land threatened by Cairns deep-port plan'? Can the Minister report on what action the Federal Government will take to protect the Aboriginal community at Yarrabah in far north Queensland where the State Government has betrayed promises of secure land tenure by proceeding with plans to develop an access road and deep port on Aboriginal land? In view of the assurances of two Federal Ministers of Aboriginal Affairs to give unequivocal guarantees that land rights interests will be protected, will the Minister ask Mr Holding to move quickly to honour those commitments to ensure that deeds of grant in trust cannot be manipulated by an opportunistic State Government that has no regard for Aborigines?

—I am aware that my colleague the Hon. Clyde Holding has had discussions with his counterpart in Queensland the Hon. R. C. Katter Jr on this and other matters relating to Aboriginal land in Queensland. I also understand that Mr Katter has held extensive discussions with the Yarrabah Council and community. I gather that both Mr Holding and the Yarrabah people have received assurances from Mr Katter that there is no cause for concern and that no excision will proceed. Nevertheless, the Commonwealth will be watching developments closely and working to ensure that Commonwealth policy principles are satisfied. To assist the Council in its deliberations the Commonwealth has provided funds to retain independent legal advisers.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister advise whether that guarantee has been received by Mr Holding in writing?
—I do not have information available to answer Senator Reynolds's precise question. I will endeavour to get that answer for her before the end of Question Time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, follows that asked by Senator Reynolds. I refer to Senator Reynolds's assertion that the Queensland Government has betrayed the promises it made to Aboriginal Queenslanders. I ask the Minister: Did she, as shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, promise that the first legislative act of a Labor government would be to pass legislation which would take these matters out of the hands of the Queensland Government and to vest them in this Parliament and the Federal Government? I also ask her whether she has seen the article which was referred to by Senator Reynolds which includes this paragraph:

QUESTION.PARA: Then came a Federal Labor Government which promised much more than the unequivocal guarantee. It is now history that the promises of Mr Clyde Holding, the present Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, were smashed on the rocks of political expediency and economic rationalism.
When does the Minister expect to keep the promises that she made to the Aboriginal people of Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that, when our Government came to office in March 1983, we had a very firm commitment that Aboriginals all over Australia should be able to get secure title to land. Indeed, I believe that it was one of the first acts of our Government that Mr Holding, who became the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the Hawke Government, immediately undertook discussions and consultations with a view to developing uniform land rights legislation. The history of that exercise is very well known in this place. The exercise was often the subject of questions and debates. Honourable senators will know that, after proceeding in a very thorough and dedicated way to try to get an agreed piece of legislation-legislation which will have the support of the Aboriginal community throughout Australia-Mr Holding was not able to get that agreement. Consequently, he decided that, for the time being, the matter of land rights should be pursued at State level. That is not to say that our existing platform on land rights has been changed nor do I believe that it will be changed at our Federal conference in June. But it is to say that because of the unsympathetic political climate that was created mainly by the efforts of Senator Chaney's colleagues and cohorts in Western Australia and their red-neck supporters in the mining and pastoral industries, it was not possible for Mr Holding to proceed in the way in which we had intended to proceed, which was by way of national, uniform, land rights legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: Nonetheless, it is the case that, since we have been in office, Aboriginal people are to get secure title to a considerable portion of land in Western Australia, which is a lot more than can be said for what happened during the period the Fraser Government was in office and particularly the period when Senator Chaney was the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, when one of the greatest acts of desecration of Aboriginal land in Noonkanbah took place. I think it is very important, when considering the current achievement of land rights by Aboriginal and Islander people throughout Australia-an achievement which we do not think has yet reached its fulfilment-to bear in mind the history of our efforts to achieve that and the particularly negative and destructive role played by the Liberal Party of Australia in Western Australia.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Chaney having addressed a supplementary question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition is extending the question beyond a supplementary question. I rule it out of order.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the Minister believe that tension spots in the Middle East are undermining people's confidence in peace, disarmament and future security? Does the Minister accept that existing peacekeeping forums are the only means to resolve these conflicts? If not, does the Minister believe that Australia could play a more important role in encouraging middle power nations to adopt positive initiatives by sensible and responsible settlements rather than military settlements in bringing peace to the area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has frequently expressed its deep concern over the serious tensions and conflicts which afflict so many of the nations of the Middle East. We have been particularly concerned over the Gulf war, the conflicts in Lebanon, the tensions which persist over the Arab-Israeli dispute and, of course, the increase in terrorist incidents emanating from the region. The tensions and conflicts which continue to plague these nations are indeed a threat, as Senator Elstob says, to international as well as regional security and do demand the urgent efforts of all nations.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to Senator Elstob's question so far as the Government is concerned is that the most useful role that Australia believes it can play as the kind of nation we are is, essentially, through the United Nations. As a member of the United Nations Security Council we played an important role in recent times in the deliberations of the Council on many of these disputes, and most recently in the efforts over the Gulf war and the situation in Lebanon. We continue to believe that it is through international efforts that solutions to many of the problems of the Middle East can be found. Certainly we will be maintaining our efforts in that respect.

The Government continues to believe that the United Nations peacekeeping efforts provide an important element in the maintenance of international peace and security. United Nations peacekeeping forces are stationed in many of the world's trouble spots. UNIFIL, the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon, is attempting to bring greater calm to that troubled country. The United Nations Disengagement Observer Force, UNDOF, in the Golan Heights is undertaking the critical task of separating Israeli and Syrian forces. UNTSO, the United Nations Truce Supervision Organisation, is performing a valuable observer function in both Lebanon and in the Gulf war. The United Nations Force in Cyprus, in which Australia participates, is discharging its responsibilities in Cyprus, as is the United Nations Military Observer Group in India and Pakistan in the Kashmir region. The Government believes that it is important to maintain the existing structures and to make them more effective.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Education in her capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to an article by Father Frank Brennan in the Catholic Worker of April 1986, entitled `The End of Mr. Holding's Dreaming'. Mr President, I refer to the passage which I quoted in the supplementary question which you ruled out of order where, referring to the Labor Party's promises, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The broken promises are the greatest breach of faith committed by any Government towards Aboriginal people since white settlement.
Their votes having been bought, they have been betrayed . . .
Why were the promises ever made? At no time did Federal Cabinet resolve to honour them.

I ask the Minister: When is she going to keep the promise she made to the Aboriginal people and introduce the legislation that she so boldly introduced when she was in Opposition and when she was powerless?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read the article by Father Frank Brennan that Senator Chaney quoted. He is entitled to his views. He is a very passionate worker in the interests of Aboriginal land rights and I believe has contributed a great deal to raising the consciousness of the community, particularly the church community in Queensland, about land rights. I suppose he, like our Federal Labor Government, has had to contend in that campaign with the deliberately racist and mischievous exercises that we have seen in the State of Queensland and in the State of Western Australia. I suppose I can best answer Senator Chaney's question about when our Government will be prepared to revive the measures set out in the private member's Bill which I introduced in this place several years ago by asking him when he will be able to assure the commitment and support of his Party at the Federal and State levels for these very same principles.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen a pamphlet produced by the Scotch College Foundation, which I believe is the Melbourne Scotch College, in association with the National Australia Bank, seeking funding through what it refers to as an interest accumulation program, known as the cash deposit plan, enabling friends of Scotch College to assist the school without donating capital? The pamphlet-I think it is important to quote this-states:

QUESTION.PARA: The School needs a large capital base, the income of which can be used by the School to contain fees, provide further scholarships and achieve its goal of financial independence by the year 2000--
By law, tax deductible donations to the Building or Library Funds cannot be used for these purposes.
The interest earned on a donor's money--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator is giving far too much information. I ask her to confine her question to a question.
—I am nearly finished. I just wanted to make it clear what the plan was.
—I request the honourable senator to confine her question to giving as little information as possible. Far too much information is being given in questions being asked.
—This plan claims to create a maximum cash advantage for the school at a minimum loss of income to the donor. I ask: Is this scheme lawful? If so, is it consistent with the Government's tax strategy?
—Order! In future when lengthy questions of that nature are asked, I intend to direct that the questions be put on notice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may comment on Senator Zakharov's interpolation, if the school is self-supporting by the year 2000 that will be good news, I suppose, for the government of the day, but one would have to question whether the means by which it seeks to achieve self-supporting financial status are acceptable. I have seen the pamphlet and also a covering letter which were apparently sent out to old boys of the Scotch College in Melbourne. The covering letter cynically describes the scheme as `an Irish tax deduction'. The scheme is that an amount of money is lent by an old boy-there are not any old girls-or possibly by anybody else to the Scotch College Foundation and the interest received on that amount of money is then credited to the investment fund, whereas if the so-called donor was to invest the money himself and receive the interest himself, he would have to pay tax on the interest received. If he subsequently donated an equivalent amount to the College it would not be tax deductible if it was donated for recurrent purposes. The pamphlet also makes it clear that donations paid to the building or library funds are tax deductible, but it is not permitted that those donations then be used for recurrent expenditure. The pamphlet says:

ANSWER.PARA: By law, tax deductible donations to the Building or Library Funds cannot be used for these purposes.

Taking that at face value it demonstrates clearly that the purpose of the scheme is to get around the spirit, if not the letter, of the taxation law. Senator Zakharov asked me whether the scheme was lawful. That is not a matter on which I feel I can give a definitive opinion. However, I just say that taken at its face value-as it is described by those who have set it up-it would have to be a breach of the spirit, if not the letter, of the taxation law. For a more definitive ruling I will refer the matter to the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question follows that asked of the Minister for Finance, who seems to be suggesting that there is something sinister about interest-free loans to non-profit organisations. I ask: Did his Government make an exception or exemption for interest free loans made to old people's homes when it implemented its assets test arrangements as an acknowledgment of the very common practice of having such loans to assist in the running of organisations of a non-profit nature?

—I cast no moral aspersions on the practice of people making interest-free loans. What I have said is that, if the purpose of the scheme is to get around the taxation law and if the scheme is as described in the pamphlet, which says that by law tax deductible donations to the building or library funds cannot be used for this purpose-that is, for recurrent expenditure-but the people who devised the scheme have worked out arrangements under which they can be used for those purposes, there is clearly a breach of the spirit, if not the letter, of the law.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MEMORIAL COMMEMORATING LINKS BETWEEN SOLDIERS OF AUSTRALIA AND GREECE

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of a proposal by the Returned Services League to build a memorial in Canberra commemorating the historic links between soldiers of Australia and Greece? Is it a fact that Turkish authorities have approached the Australian Embassy in Turkey over this matter? Can the Minister inform the Senate of current developments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some confusion has arisen and concern has been expressed about the Prime Minister's announcement on his recent visit to Greece that we would assist in the proposal to establish a memorial at an appropriate site in Canberra near the Australian War Memorial to commemorate the Australian-Greek involvement in World Wars I and II. The purpose of the memorial is to pay tribute to the co-operation that existed between our two peoples in those wars. It is to be funded by Australian veterans of the Greek campaign as well as the Greek community in Australia. Australia wants to have firm and friendly relations with both Turkey and Greece. In fact, it was in that context that I was directed by the Prime Minister to proceed to Turkey last year in respect of the seventieth anniversary of the landing on Gallipoli when the Turkish Government established a memorial to Australia's involvement in that campaign. Simultaneously there was a dedication of a memorial area here in Canberra. There is no suggestion in the Australian Government's agreement to participate in the request by the Returned Services League and prominent Australians that there is any offence intended in regard to our relationships with, or in regard to the way we approach our friendship with, the Turkish people and the Turkish Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The memorial will commemorate those Australians who fought and died in the Greek campaign, particularly in World War II, with special emphasis on the support they received from our Greek allies during the battle for the island of Crete in 1941. The memorial will also honour those Australians in World War I who were buried on Greek soil. The battle for Crete was a major engagement for Australian forces during World War II. There is a substantial monument on Crete testifying to the deep feeling of gratitude which the Greek people have towards the Australians who fought in that battle. I was honoured to be present at that commemorative service last year. I assure Senator Sibraa that the erection of the proposed memorial is not politically motivated but flows from a genuine community concern to commemorate important events in Australia's military history. In no way is it to be construed as an unfriendly act to any other nation. It is a recognition of the special relationship that exists between the Australian people and the Greek people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Education accept responsibility for, firstly, the overseas student office in Malaysia informing one and a half thousand students studying for Australian matriculation that admission to tertiary study in Australia will be based on matriculation grades; secondly, that office reversing its decision to one of admittance based on earlier local examinations, only three weeks before the matriculation results were to be published; and, thirdly, a further reversal of that decision after students had already been admitted to Australian tertiary institutions, to the detriment of many other students who had passed matriculation? If the Minister does not accept this responsibility, who is responsible?

—I will have to have the allegations made in Senator Macklin's question checked out before I can discover whether they are the case and who is responsible for them. I am aware that there was a mistake in advice given. By the way, there is not an overseas office in Malaysia. At the moment the program is being handled by officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The transfer to the Department of Education is virtually complete now. However, in January this year some information was given out through our High Commission to the effect that only Australian matriculation results would be accepted for entrance to Australian universities. This was wrong. Subsequently, and I think quite quickly, it was corrected. It was made clear to all the relevant authorities that the results of the local Malaysian examinations would also be accepted by tertiary institutions in Australia. I had the opportunity to explain that to the Malaysian education authorities when I was in Malaysia shortly after the mistake had occurred. That mistake occurred. It was corrected. I certainly have no knowledge that there was any reversal of that matter. I cannot see why there should be, since that is the policy. I will have to ask Senator Macklin to provide me with the information on which he has based his question and will have the matter checked out. To the best of my knowledge that initial mistake was quickly clarified and students were then accepted into institutions according to their tertiary entrance scores, which could be based either on the Malaysian examination or on Australian matriculation examinations.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the latest Australia-wide figures on industrial disputes produced yesterday by the Australian Bureau of Statistics? If so, can the Minister confirm that, even after making allowance for the effects of the South East Queensland Electricity Board strike in Queensland last year, Queensland has the worst industrial relations record of any State in the Commonwealth?
—Again?
—Yes, again. Does this in turn show that the approach to industrial relations by the Queensland Government is, to say the least, less than reasonable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a summary of the statistics. They do indeed confirm that Queensland has the worst industrial relations record of any State in the Commonwealth. For the 12 months to February 1986-the most recent figures available-in Queensland 270 working days were lost per 1,000 employees, the highest for any State, compared to the national average of 208. It may be recalled that even more horrendous figures came out of Queensland last year as a result of the SEQEB strike. The comparable figure for the 12 months for the year before those to February 1985 was 452 working days lost per 1,000 employees in Queensland. Although the figure has declined from 452 to 270, that is substantially as a result of the one-off effect of the SEQEB strike. Of course, in both years those figures represented the worst industrial relations record of any State.

ANSWER.PARA: The figures released yesterday cover the first rolling period which starts to get clear of the cause of the horrendous past figures, which were the result of the SEQEB strike. Seventy per cent of the working days lost as a result of that strike were in February 1985. There is no doubt that the Queensland Government's approach to industrial relations is less than subtle and less than successful. One wonders how much more of the Liberal's industrial relations policy at Federal level is born out of admiration for those activities in Queensland. One would certainly hope that that is the case and that the Liberals will not get a chance to apply those sorts of attitudes nationally and reproduce in every other State the appalling record which has been established in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate concerns the proposed inquiry into claims of migration of nazi war criminals to Australia. I think there was a Press report today about this inquiry. Will the report of this inquiry be made public either in full or in a sanitised form? In particular, will full details be made public to allow judgment by Australians of several claims, the first of which is that resettlement was sought in Australia for Mr Klaus Barbie, and the second of which, to quote an official document, is that `some nazi war criminals may have slipped into our system'.
—And into your Party.
—I missed that interjection, Mr President.
—Order! Will the honourable senator ask his question.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I ask that that very offensive remark of the Minister's be withdrawn.
—There is no point of order. It was a remark made in the generality and not in respect of any individual.
—It was not a generality; it was directed to Senator Peter Baume's party. The allegation was very clear.
—It was not made in respect of the parliamentary Liberal Party. There is no point of order.

—Will a judgment be made as to whether or not the United Kingdom Government sought to discourage any new trials of nazi war criminals after August 1948? Will details be given of whether any people thought to be nazi war criminals are currently in Australia? Are claims about any particular people made in the Parliament of New South Wales by Mr Frank Walker based on any good evidence of nazi war criminal behaviour by those people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am able to provide Senator Peter Baume with some information about the question he asked, but not in replete detail; I may be able to get further information for him. An informal inquiry into claims that war criminals entered Australia after World War II is to be conducted by a former senior public servant. The appointment and details of the inquiry have yet to be announced. The inquiry would have full access to all government files and United Nations documents. The Special Minister of State will have ministerial responsibility for the inquiry. An examination by officers in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs of available records has so far failed to disclose evidence of the involvement of those named in war crime.

ANSWER.PARA: After the Second World War membership of the nazi party was sufficient grounds for rejection of entry into Australia. In 1955 that policy was changed. Membership of the nazi party was no longer a reason in itself for rejection. Membership of other organisations under the umbrella of parties such as the SS and the Gestapo and certain concentration camp staff as well as convictions for war crimes remain reasons for rejection. In 1955 the change to policy was made public. A list of the names of former nazis are not kept, but under government policy of past days some former nazis did enter Australia. It would not be prudent to give an unequivocal guarantee that no war criminals came to Australia. Records indicate former nazis did migrate. The possibility of war criminals acquiring false papers and identities or of providing false information to gain entry into Australia cannot be ruled out. Until investigations are concluded it is not appropriate to speculate about particular individuals. Allegations abound. Evidence of involvement of individuals in war crimes is lacking.

In relation to the call for a royal commission which was made in some circles, the Government is not convinced that a royal commission is justified at this time. I conclude by saying that present policy on entry includes provision that all individuals are assessed on any threat they may pose to the Australian community. At the start of this question Senator Baume asked me particularly about whether the findings would be made public. As I indicated in my answer the appointment and details of the inquiry have yet to be announced. I will draw Senator Baume's request-I take it to be a request as well as a question-to the Special Minister of State and I will ask him to have that matter addressed when the details of the inquiry are being considered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coates yesterday asked me a question yesterday about Press reports of a dangerous radioactive substance being imported into Australia in very unsafe circumstances. I undertook to investigate the matter. I am now able to advise the Senate of the results of that investigation. My answer, Mr President, is a long one but because of the public interest this matter has raised I think I ought to read it in full.

ANSWER.PARA: Americium, the substance in question, is used in a variety of industrial applications in Australia, including smoke detectors, permitted quantities of activity being specified under State legislation; demonstration alpha sources in educational establishments where, again, permitted quantities of activity are also specified; and as a neutron source in combination with beryllium for research purposes, and for other applications such as the measurement of moisture content in soils for geological surveys and road constructions. Americium is not itself produced in Australia, so all supplies are imported, mainly from Amersham International Pty Ltd in the United Kingdom. Americium-241 is produced by neutron irradiation of the plutonium-239 target with subsequent beta decay. Some 15 companies import americium-241 into Australia.

Imports of radioactive materials including americium are controlled under the customs prohibited imports regulations. Under these regulations anyone who wishes to import radioactive material for use in industry, as in the case of lightning-arresters, the matter in issue here, requires Australian Atomic Energy Commission permission. The applicant must show that he has a State licence permitting him to use the radioisotope for the purpose specified in the application.

With regard to the Tasmanian lightning-arresters, the subject of yesterday's report, I understand that the company involved, E.F. Australasia Pty Ltd, makes a variety of products, including some lightning arresters with no radioactive components. I understand that the particular arresters in question here make use of a gold-silver foil sensor coated with up to 10 millicuries of americium. The company is licensed by the Tasmanian Radiological Council to manufacture lightning-arresters using americium. I understand that the conditions of that licence do not permit sales of these items in Tasmania. The use of such lightning-arresters is not permitted in Australia, consistent with a recommendation of the National Health and Medical Research Council in November 1977 that:

In the light of available evidence, the use of radioactive material in lightning conductors for the nominal purpose of increasing their efficiency should be discouraged in the interest of public health.

the protection of workers and the public in connection with the manufacture of goods containing radioactive materials is covered by State legislation. While exports of certain radioactive materials are controlled under the customs prohibited exports regulations, these regulations do not apply to americium and hence export of these lightning-arresters does not presently require an export permit.

In regard to the shipment and handling of these lightning-arresters, both within the State and overseas, the manufacturer is required to conform to Commonwealth and State regulations governing the safe transport of radioactive materials. These regulations, which incorporate the International Atomic Energy Agency's regulations for the safe transport of radioactive materials, set out strict packaging and labelling requirements. The consignor is also required to complete documentation setting out details of the particular radioisotope in the package to be shipped. Within Australia, the transport of radioactive substances by road and rail comes under the control of each of the States involved. Air transport and interstate marine transport is controlled by the Commonwealth under the Air Navigation Act and the Navigation Act respectively.

In the case of these lightning-arresters, I understand that all shipments of radioactive components have been exported in accordance with the relevant Commonwealth and State transport regulations. However, when two damaged arresters were returned from Singapore by air to Hobart via Sydney last February, they were not packaged or labelled as containing radioactive material. When this was discovered I understand the Tasmanian Department of Health informed the Singapore Radiation Protection Inspectorate, as the competent authority in Singapore, expressing its concern and seeking an explanation for the consignor's lack of compliance with international requirements. The Health Department also informed Singapore Airlines, the international carrier for this package.

It concerns me that this type of lightning arrester is still being manufactured for export nine years after the NH and MRC had clearly indicated their use should be discouraged on health grounds. As I have indicated, Commonwealth approval is required to import americium, and I have asked for the situation to be reviewed. I would also hope the Tasmanian Government would reconsider whether the manufacture of lightning conductors using americium should be permitted in that State.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sir John Carrick asked me a question yesterday about allegations by the United States of America of Soviet non-compliance with the Strategic arms Limitations Talks II. I have a full answer for him which, again, is very long. I understand that Senator Sir John Carrick would prefer me to read it so, under the circumstances, I am afraid that I will trespass again on the Senate. Obviously this, again, is a matter of some importance.

ANSWER.PARA: The most recent United States Administration reports on Soviet non-compliance with arms control agreements address seven issues concerning Soviet compliance with the SALT II Treaty. In four cases a firm violation of the Treaty provisions is alleged. These are as follows: First, flight testing and deployment of a prohibited second new type of intercontinental ballistic missile, that is to say the SS25; secondly, encryption of ballistic missile telemetry; thirdly, exceeding the number of strategic nuclear delivery vehicles or SNDVs, which the Soviet Union possessed on signing the Treaty in June 1979; and fourthly, concealment of the association of an ICBM and its launcher.

In the other three cases the American conclusions are less categorical. These concern: First, the possible deployment of the SS16, and a probable violation only is alleged by the United States in this respect; secondly, the production rate of the Backfire bomber, and the United States noted that the evidence is ambiguous; and thirdly, the international operating capability of the Backfire bomber in respect of which the United States regarded some Soviet actions as inconsistent with a political commitment given by the Soviet Union on signing the Treaty.

The centrepiece of the United States allegations in relation to SALT II are the issues of encryption of ballistic missile telemetry and the deployment of the SS25 ICBM. The United States has concluded that deployment of the SS25 violates the prohibition in the SALT II Treaty on each side flight-testing or deploying more than one new type of ICBM.

The United States has advised the Soviet Union that the MX is its one new type of ICBM permitted under SALT II. According to United States sources the Soviet Union has in turn advised the United States that a new multiple-warhead ICBM it began flight testing in late 1982, which is designated the SS-X-24 by the United States, was its one permitted new type. Deployment of the SS24, which has not yet commenced, would not therefore be a violation of SALT II. I mention that specifically because I think the SS24 was mentioned by Senator Sir John Carrick in his question.

Subsequently, in early 1983, the Soviet Union began flight testing another ICBM, designated the SS-X-25 by the United States. In response to United States queries the Soviet Union claimed that this ICBM is a permitted modification of an existing ICBM, the SS13, first deployed in 1969. The United States does not accept this assertion. It believes the throwweight of the SS25 exceeds by more than 5 per cent the throwweight of the SS13, and that it cannot therefore be a permitted modernisation of the SS13 as the Soviet Union claims. In a Press conference in Moscow on 23 May, the Chief of the Soviet General Staff, Marshal Akhromeyev, took issue with the way in which the United States had apparently arrived at its conclusions concerning the throwweight of the two missiles.

The issue of whether the SS25 is a new ICBM as defined by the SALT II Treaty clearly involves complex technical and legal issues. The Government's view is that both the encryption issue and the SS25 raise legitimate questions concerning Soviet compliance with the relevant provisions of the SALT II Treaty. There is a case to answer and the Government hopes the Soviet Union will take appropriate steps to respond to Western concerns and demonstrate clearly its compliance with the relevant provisions of this important Treaty. This concern has been reflected in communications from the Australian Government to the Soviet Government over a protracted period. Mr Hayden has written to the Soviet Foreign Minister about it and more recently, as I have said, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has written to General Secretary Gorbachev setting out Australian views on these questions.

As to the last part of Senator Sir John Carrick's question, Parliament has been informed of some of the US allegations in answers to a number of questions on notice which appeared in the House of Representatives Hansard on 30 November 1985. I understand that answers to a subsequent series of questions on notice placed on the House of Representatives Notice Paper on 20 March also on this issue will appear in Hansard shortly.

Finally Senator Sir John Carrick asked if the Prime Minister would be prepared to make public the texts of his recent communications to President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev on this important issue. I said that I would check whether this was possible. I have now been informed that, for familiar reasons going to the desirability of maintaining confidentiality in communications between heads of state, this will not be possible. But I am able to say that honourable senators can rest assured that the contents of those communications do fully reflect the concerns of the Australian Government, which I have outlined in answers to several questions on this matter in this chamber over the past week.

DEBATE.TITLE: CANBERRA COLLEGE OF ADVANCED EDUCATION: COURSE APPROVAL DELAYS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) to questions without notice asked by Senators McKiernan and Teague this day relating to the accreditation of courses at the Canberra College of Advanced Education.

Some controversy and dispute arose in respect of the answers given by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) to questions asked by Senator McKiernan and me today concerning the situation at the Canberra College of Advanced Education. Considerable concern has arisen at the College because of the confusion and disarray over the accreditation of the more than 100 courses offered by the College. Today's Canberra Times newspaper contains an article about the concern of sources within the College itself that the great majority of the courses are not accredited; that is to say, the courses are subject to periodic re-accreditation, and there are always some new courses.

During Question Time this afternoon I contacted the College to confirm the position. It was indicated to me that the College continues to be concerned despite the assurances that the Minister sought to give to the Senate today that things were going to be improved. The Minister did not say what specific measures would be taken to improve the situation. However, she did claim responsibility for the administrative failure which has led to the present malaise at the College. I am concerned that, while the Minister said that there were some inaccuracies in some of the facts set out in today's newspaper report-that is, that 88 out of the 115 courses are awaiting approval-she did not answer a number of quite specific and significant questions. She did not agree to come back to the Senate and to be accountable and to give answers to these questions. She tried to bluster her way through by initially giving an inadequate answer. She did not say whether or not there were accreditation delays of greater than two years in respect of some courses. I have been informed within the last hour by the College that there is a delay of more than two years in the case of at least 11 courses. Some of the students who have been undertaking such courses have graduated. They have been given a diploma at graduation ceremonies with the undertaking that the wording and title of the diploma would need to be changed and that the correct title and correct course subject would be inserted after the course became accredited; that is, after it became lawful to issue such a diploma. I have never heard of such a state of affairs in Australia before in tertiary education institutions. It was proper for Senator Lewis to rise during Question Time to ask that the Minister's answer, which lacked information, be noted by the Senate.

The Minister also did not answer whether or not other colleges of advanced education in Australia are suffering the same disarray. It is a matter of importance to the Senate that we ensure that Ministers of the Government are accountable to Parliament. Adequate answers ought to be given by the Minister in regard to bona fide questions that are of concern to us about the confusion that has led the administrators of a tertiary education institution to make statements which are publicly reported and which affect students.

Instead of answering my question and reassuring the Senate that the requests of Dr Parfitt, the Principal of the Canberra College of Advanced Education, and Dr Overheu, the Co-Principal of the College, are being met, the Minister chose to bluster through an answer and did not address herself to that question at all. The Minister's only reference to Dr Parfitt-a most capable and achieving Principal of the college-was to give a veiled threat towards Dr Parfitt insofar as he may have been involved in this administrative scandal for which the Minister is responsible and which is now being revealed to the public and the Senate. I believe that the Senate cannot be treated in this way and that the Minister for Education should not feel that, just because she admits to the Senate in a brief answer to a dorothy dix question from one of her colleagues that she is the Minister responsible for this administrative failure, she should not go on to answer these specific questions and to give reassurances that steps are in train to fully meet these inadequacies. I therefore believe that it is right that the Senate takes note of Senator Ryan's answers in Question Time today, because they are manifestly inadequate.

Finally, I refer to the needs of the students. The students of our tertiary education institutions should not be subjected to this kind of outcome from administrative failure. If there is to be a growing bureaucracy associated with the accreditation of tertiary courses, by all means let us make sure that it is workable and that courses are accredited within a 12-month period-surely that is achievable-so that the plight of students does not continue to be in the state of disarray in which it is now. It is the view of the Opposition that there needs to be considerable pruning of the bureaucracy associated with this kind of accreditation. I believe that, while all of us would want to ensure that courses which set out to offer some tertiary training are well accredited, that they offer what they allege to offer and that accreditation procedures are not just a matter of the Minister receiving a piece of paper and agreeing to it-that does not happen-it is manifestly not good for Australian tertiary education that there are delays of more than two years and that students are given diplomas that do not accurately describe the course in which they have graduated because of such administrative failure. The Senate, in taking note of the Minister's answers, rebukes the Minister and calls on the Minister to give full answers to all of the outstanding questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel I must make a brief response to some of these very outrageous and unfounded statements that Senator Teague has chosen to impart to the Senate this afternoon. The first thing I must say is that the answer I gave to Senator McKiernan's question was very full. It was not a short or inadequate answer, as Senator Teague is now claiming. If Senator Teague had paid attention to that answer, he would have heard me say--
—Let the Senate judge.

—He is not even listening now. It is very difficult to cope with an honourable senator who ignores information that is given, then gets to his feet and makes all kinds of crazy allegations. The first thing to be said is that there have been delays. The information provided by my Department is that substantially the delays have been at the Canberra College of Advanced Education end. I am not sure whether there have also been delays at the departmental end, but I am currently having that matter investigated. I would be surprised if the delays were only at the College end, but certainly the advice I gave in Question Time today was that considerable delays have been caused by the College failing to submit courses for accreditation.

SPEECH.PARA: I explained to Senator Teague that the accreditation procedures for the Canberra College of Advanced Education are different from the procedures for other colleges in that the college may introduce courses and take students into them prior to receiving accreditation. That decision was made for the convenience of the College, but it is then up to the College to submit those courses for approval. There have been some areas where the College has not submitted those courses for a number of years. The extent to which the College's administrative inefficiency has contributed to the present problems is not fully established.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you blaming the college?

—I am saying that I have had advice that the College in a number of instances has failed to submit the courses for accreditation-one case was cited of three years after the College took students-and for those cases the College must bear full responsibility. There may be other cases of delay, about which I do not yet have information from my Department, which can be sheeted to the Commonwealth Institutions Accreditation Committee for Advanced Education, the function and composition of which I described at Question Time.
—Do you undertake to get the answers?

—Of course I will get the answers and of course the matter is being further investigated. I do not think it advances the matter to have a matter of maladministration, for which the College is at least partly responsible, raised first of all in the columns of the Canberra Times-not always renowned for accuracy in these matters-and, secondly--
—What is inaccurate?
—I pointed out a number of statements.
—Which ones?

—Again I simply point to the difficulty that arises for Ministers when factual information is given in answers to questions, then an honourable senator such as Senator Teague says: `Where are the inaccuracies?'. I instanced the inaccuracies in my answer to the Senate and that answer is now with Hansard because there was a demand that it be treated as a statement. There were inaccuracies in the claims about the number of courses that remain unaccredited and the claims about the failure to complete the accreditation processes. One of the most distressing features of this is that Senator Teague somehow suggested, in the comments he has just made, that I, my Department or a committee which has responsibility to report to me, is trying to short-cut accreditation procedures, whereas in fact the answer I gave at Question Time was to the contrary; that accreditation procedures must be carried out very thoroughly because employers and educational institutions place great value on the accreditation being thorough and accurate. Contrary to the suggestion that we are trying to short-circuit or undermine the accreditation procedures, we are actually trying to strengthen them.

SPEECH.PARA: I said also in my answer at Question Time that there had been recent discussions between the Accreditation Committee and the college about improvements to the procedures. I do not have the details of what those improvements will be, but I will happily get those and set them out for the Senate. Again, that information is quite different from what Senator Teague was trying to claim when he said that there was no co-operation in respect of improving the procedures. Obviously there has been co-operation and there will continue to be. I simply conclude by saying that it is not in the interests of the College or the students of the College, if there is an administrative problem with regard to accreditation, that that matter is raised not by way of proper discussions with the Department, nor by way of direct representations to me-I am not aware of any direct representations coming to me on this matter-but by way of an article in the Canberra Times or by feeding an Opposition senator some criticism at Question Time. In conclusion, the matters that--

TALK.START.PARA: —The question was first raised by a Government senator. Senator McKiernan is worried about this and he is a Government senator.
