—Senator McKiernan's question related to the article in the Canberra Times. Senator Teague is now claiming direct communication with the College as the basis for the comments he has just made. I am saying that it is in the interests of the College to pursue these matters properly; namely, by discussions with my Department, or, if those discussions are not satisfactory-I can think of no reason why they would not be satisfactory-by direct representation to me. I do not think that direct complaints to an Opposition senator to enable that honourable senator to grandstand on a matter such as this is the proper way to proceed. If I am being unkind in simply accepting what Senator Teague says is true and if there is some other explanation I will be very pleased to hear it from the College authorities. In conclusion--
—Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: The College did not complain to me. Following the asking of questions, I rang the College.
—Order! That is not a point of order. That is a dispute over the facts.

—Senator Teague certainly gave the impression in the remarks he made that he had been the recipient of direct representations from the College. If that is not the case, I am pleased to have his correction on that matter. I repeat that that would not be the proper way for College authorities to proceed to have a difficulty investigated. There are proper pro- cedures and those procedures are always available to the College authorities to pursue. I hope from what Senator Teague has now said that they will pursue them. There is no doubt further information on the matter of the delays in accreditation. I have undertaken to have the matter investigated. In fact, I hope that as I speak my officers are doing just that, because I requested that they do so during Question Time. When the information is available I will be happy to make it available to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: REPORT OF DELEGATION TO THE CONFERENCE ON DISARMAMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In the short space of time-some five minutes-that one has to talk on such a subject, it is impossible adequately to deal with it. The subject-that of securing nuclear peace and, indeed, peace from conventional war-overrides all others. I draw the Senate's attention to the statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) because I want to refer to three or four points made by him. He stated:
Australia reiterated its proposal, originally made by me--
that is, Mr Hayden--

to the Conference in August 1984, that consideration be given to protecting from attack those satellites which maintain international security and contribute to the verification of arms control agreements and the ground stations linked to such satellites.

That is a very significant statement which, of course, relates to the attempt in Geneva to put together what is called an ASAT treaty-an anti-satellite treaty-and to get agreement throughout the world that those satellites which provide surveillance and basic guarantees against errors or basic war should be protected. Fundamental to that is the recognition that ground stations should also be protected. What is important is that this statement means that Nurrungar and Pine Gap, which are so vilified by so many for whatever reason, ought to be enshrined in and protected by world treaties. I repeat what the Minister said:
. . . and the ground stations linked to such satellites.

In other words, what the Minister is saying-and what I have said in the Senate previously-is that the best preventers of nuclear war or accidents are the verification satellites. The Conference on Disarmament is dealing with a treaty to ban the destruction of either those satellites or Pine Gap and Nurrungar. Fundamentally, therefore-and the Government has implied this-we have in central Australia some of the best international peacekeepers that one can have.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolute rubbish.

—That ought to be understood. The brain fever birds in the Australian Democrats who have been destructive this week are, of course, opposed to the ANZUS alliance and the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. They want isolationism in Australia. They want any strength from the Western alliance to leave Australia. Let them say that that is what they want.
—You are a good learner.

—Indeed, I would be very happy to keep saying to the Australian people what a danger to Australia, both in foreign affairs and economics, is posed by the Australian Democrats. They have proven how destructive they are by their attitude to the fringe benefits tax. They are now showing it in other ways. The Minister in his statement also said:

SPEECH.PARA: On 15 January Mr Gorbachev put forward a comprehensive set of proposals, the centre-piece of which was a call for the elimination, in three stages, of all nuclear weapons by the year 2000.

I applaud that, but what I do not understand is why this statement does not refer to the prior offer by the United States to have exactly the same removal of all nuclear weapons by the year 2000 on a three-stage basis. The same thing occurs when we mention chemical weapons and the laudable act of seeking to get a treaty to ban chemical weapons. There is no mention of the fact that for the past 20 years the Russians have been building up a stockpile of chemical and biological weapons, deploying those weapons and training their troops, while since 1970 the Americans have done nothing of the kind. It is a pity that what is on the face of it a good report and a good speech, ought to be unbalanced in those areas. I know of no place which is more important than the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva, which I have attended, to look towards the issues of peace. I know of no place where the dialogue for peace is more important. I commend all of the 40 delegates from both sides of the Iron Curtain who take part at the Conference. I wish them well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With all respect to Senator Sir John Carrick, I do not think we should make the error of the emperor's clothes with regard to this report of the Australian Delegation to the 1985 Session of the Conference on Disarmament. This report, when one reads it carefully-I take it that Senator Sir John Carrick has not done that-is a most painful document and a record of most terrible frustration. This is instanced very early in the report when it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Conference achieved some substantive progress on a few of its agenda items during the 1985 session but the gains were limited. As was the case last year, it was not possible to reconcile the differences of approach to the important nuclear items-nuclear test ban and prevention of nuclear war-to allow work on them to be got underway.

This situation was again a cause of deep frustration for the majority of members of the Conference. It reflected the extent to which the Conference remained subservient to the interests and state of relations between the United States and the Soviet Union.
Page 7 of the report reads:

While there was broad support within the Conference for the program of work advocated by the Western Group, the attitude of some key members of the Non-Aligned Group and the Socialist Group, who remained opposed to any solution which did not have a commitment to negotiation of a treaty as its central element, prevented adoption of the program.
Under the heading `Nuclear Test Ban', the report states:
. . . no substantive work was undertaken on this item this year.
The heading on page 13 is `Cessation of the Nuclear Arms Race and Nuclear Disarmament'. After all, this is what the Conference is all about. It reads:
As in 1984, no agreement was reached on establishing a subsidiary body of the Conference to consider this item.
Page 15 is entitled `Prevention of Nuclear War'. It reads:
The differences of view between the Groups once again resulted in a stalemate and prevented any structured consideration being given to this subject.

I do not in any way derogate from the efforts of Ambassador Butler and our people, who do what they can in this regard. They are trying to work in an almost impossible environment. I found that this was the case when I was present for a time at the Disarmament Session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York two or three years ago. I was struck then by two things: The proliferation of worthy statements about the issue of nuclear disarmament and, by contrast, the absolute failure of the session to do anything practical about it. This report confirms that view. If the world is to escape the horrors of nuclear war, it will not be done because of the efforts of government. The United States abandonment of the SALT Treaty and the Russians' part in that is a further ominous portent for the future.

If an effective disarmament effort is to be achieved, it will be by the efforts of individual human beings-a massive grass roots movement which will influence governments sufficiently. Such movements, of course, already exist, and I commend them. Many of them recently have come under considerable criticism. There have actually been objections in this country and others to the idea of teaching peace studies in schools. Presumably those who take that view want an uninformed and compliant new generation of cannon fodder to deposit in any even more destructive war. I cannot heap sufficient contempt on those people who put that point of view and who have made peace a dirty word. What greater crime against humanity could any- body commit than that?

It is vital that young people should have the knowledge to make up their own minds on the risks that confront their generation. That is a unique danger not faced by any other human beings who have come before us. There is need for deep understanding of the basic reasons for aggression in human beings and the risk that nuclear war could bring. There is no doubt that the Chernobyl disaster has contributed to this and I am interested that the dreadful consequences of that event appear only to have increased the resolve of those evil people who would try to diminish the cause of peace and diminish the understanding of these matters. Most people are not so stupid as to miss the connection between nuclear bombs and nuclear reactors. The deadly radiation that kills, maims and deforms is exactly the same. We all know that few, if any, of those exposed to heavy radiation at Chernobyl will survive. Indeed, it has been reported from Russia already that attempts at bone marrow transplants there have failed. There is no medical answer to high radiation doses and for hundreds of millions of people there would be no chance whatsoever of recovery from the consequences of nuclear war. I commend this report. The one thing I would not commend is the failure of support in the community, especially at the level of ordinary people, for the cause of peace and I utterly renounce and condemn the actions of those who attempt to make peace a dirty word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators who preceded me in noting this report of the Australian delegation to the 1985 session of the Conference on Disarmament have spoken on behalf of us all insofar as they have pledged support to every effort that can be taken by Australia to achieve multilateral disarmament and peace for the world. The disarmament conference is an important procedure, open to us, which works towards those ends. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in his statement accompanying the delegation's report on last year's conference has been rather overoptimistic about the way in which the conference, and our contribution to it, can lead to the desired outcomes. This is a most complex area and it is fraught with enormous difficulty, especially given the state of relations between the United States and the Soviet Union. However expert those members of the conference and our delegation led by Ambassador Butler may be, there is a danger in taking too literally any overoptimism that all these problems will be quickly solved. The optimism is confined at the moment to the areas of chemical weapons, radiological weapons and some movement towards at least an in-principle agreement by the nuclear nations on a nuclear test ban that is comprehensive.

SPEECH.PARA: Even though these are good signs and should be welcomed and even though there was progress in 1985 in dealing with all the matters on the agenda, the really difficult questions concern the deployment of nuclear weapons, especially between the two super-powers over each other's territory and the so-called intermediate nuclear weapons in the European theatre. Looking from the perspective of Canberra, progress towards real gains in this area has not just been too slow; it has been non-existent. From our various points of analysis we find various reasons for that. However much we may hope that there will be progress let us mark the 1985-86 years without any ambiguity and without being too overoptimistic about making some progress. There are still more than 10,000 warheads on each side. It still takes half an hour for intercontinental ballistic missiles to move from a super-power aggressor to the enemy's territory. It would take half an hour for the response to get back. Those times would overlap and within the space of an hour there would be vast destruction of the northern hemisphere which would result in consequences for the whole world. There has not been progress towards disarmament. We must lament that and renew our efforts by supporting any positive measures that the Australian Government and Ambassador Butler may take in concert with other like-minded nations-indeed, in concert with our ally the United States-to achieve that agenda.

In the report before us I see some useful progress and even the hope that chemical weapons may be banned within the next few years; that is, destroyed by all those who retain such weapons. I am also hopeful that there will be destruction of all radiological weapons and that there might even be an agreement that no nuclear electricity generating plant will be targeted by any of the silos of weapons on each side. There are important gains, but not gains in the area of greatest importance and priority. It is in the area of genuine disarmament-real cuts-that we must press for multilateral disarmament, not unilateralism or an act on one side alone. We want to see progress which leads to and wins disarmament from both super-powers alike and indeed, from the other three nuclear nations-France, the United Kingdom and China. We must press for that disarmament to be verifiable. It is no good having words on pieces of paper; we must have an action line. I share the disappointment that has been expressed by United States leaders that too often the bits of paper are not parallel with any action. It is in these areas that we look for real and significant cuts so that multilateral and verifiable disarmament is achieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —These papers deal with the most fundamental issue of our time, an issue that is transcended by no other-the issue of nuclear disarmament. Since this Government came to power it has been trying to push the super-powers into a position in which we can look at meaningful achievements in nuclear disarmament. We apologise to no-one for that. The fact that these papers reflect some frustration, as Senator Mason pointed out, signifies that we have been working hard and we are not trailing along behind the pack; we are out there in front trying to create real change. We pursue that goal based on what we understand to be a clear mandate for the Australian Labor Party resulting from widespread community idealism for nuclear disarmament. In the tabling speech of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) he referred to a statement by Mr Olof Palme, the late and unfortunately assassinated Prime Minister of Sweden, who said in this context that the `non-nuclears' must have a say; that is, countries like Australia which are not nuclear powers and countries in the unaligned group which are not nuclear powers must have a say in international fora to the super-powers about their agenda for nuclear disarmament. Australia has pursued those ambitions and its agenda through the appointment of an Ambassador for Disarmament, Richard Butler, through pursuit of a comprehensive test ban treaty, through the nuclear non-proliferation treaty review conference last year and the consolidation and further development of that treaty, and through its success in achieving a South Pacific nuclear free zone. This success was underlined recently when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) visited China and secured approval from that country that it too would support that initiative in the South Pacific.

SPEECH.PARA: Those are all positive and necessary moves that a government committed to nuclear disarmament must, and should take. I believe that our Prime Minister and in particular our Minister for Foreign Affairs are to be commended for their initiatives. Of course there are always people who will say that we have not gone far enough, just as there are people who will say that we have gone too far. We do not apologise for addressing, in a step by step orderly program, what we as a middle power under the umbrella of the Western alliance can do. As a middle power, we cannot vault a tall building in a single bound and achieve, because Australia wishes it, a nuclear disarmament regime across the world. We do not have that capability. We can use our influence and we can work hard, and that is what we are doing. I believe that is a proper use of our effort and of our lobbying power. If it be frustrating, it is because we are trying and we are working to push for much more rapid change.

Soon this Government will introduce legislation which will be aimed at outlawing the manufacture, production and acquisition of nuclear weapons in this country; research and development relating to the manufacture or production of nuclear weapons, possession and control of nuclear weapons; the stationing of nuclear weapons in Australia; and the testing of nuclear weapons. The Government will also introduce legislation which will make it an offence to do any act which facilitates the manufacture, production, acquisition or testing of nuclear weapons in this country. That will apply not only within the national borders of Australia but also, in certain circumstances, in areas beyond our national borders.

I believe that when this legislation is brought forward it will be widely supported. I hope it will be unanimously supported by both Houses. Again, it will be another significant step forward by this Government in trying to address the community's concern about nuclear disarmament that is rightly expressed in this country as well as doing something to consolidate the South West Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty in legislation in this country and to meet the objectives that we have been pursuing internationally as well.

To a large extent, Australia has been one of the pioneers of a comprehensive test ban treaty. It is the centrepiece of our move on the world stage in this area. It is a treaty on which we sought to make progress at the Geneva talks. It is a treaty with which we have not got as far as we would like. Certainly, through the Ambassador for Disarmament, it is an issue with which we will continue to persist in all proper forums around the world. It is not something that we will give up. Australia has indicated that it is prepared to make its seismic surveying facilities available to the world in order that such a treaty can be properly policed. We hope that we will succeed as quickly as possible, and it will not be for want of trying if we do not succeed. I believe our role internationally is a role about which we as a country can say: `Here is a government trying on the world stage and domestically to achieve a situation in which the people of this country and the world can look forward to a time in which nuclear disarmament does occur and people will be able to look back and say that the Australian Government helped achieve that aim'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Australian delegation to the 1985 session of the Conference on Disarmament shows once again that we are stuck on dead centre when it comes to disarmament. Page 8 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: However, generally the United States continued to adopt a cautious approach to the consideration of items on the Conference's agenda, and, in particular, had strong reservations about discussions of the subject of Prevention of Nuclear War and All Related Matters.
The next paragraph states:

The Soviet Union and its allies again adopted the approach at the outset of the Session of calling for negotiating mandates on all agenda items. They repeatedly admonished the Western group of countries during the Session for their inability to accept such mandates.

It is obvious that what we need is a strong approach to disarmament. Australia could exert that strong approach. It has not done so. In spite of the Bill which Senator Cook has told us about, which is in fact the Australian Democrats Bill which the Australian Labor Party rejected in an earlier sitting of the Senate, Australia is not well known amongst the world's nations in the nuclear disarmament field, unlike New Zealand, which, of course, is well known. If Australia were to take the stand that New Zealand has taken in banning nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered ships, perhaps we would have a voice. Perhaps then we could get this whole issue off dead centre. Most recently, President Reagan announced that it is his intention to abandon SALT II, the agreement which limits nuclear weapons. This has caused an outcry around the world. One would think that if in fact Australia were interested in disarmament it would have joined the outcry. On 29 May 1986, in this chamber, Senator Coleman asked Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, whether the Government would express its complete rejection of that unilateral action by the Unites States. Senator Evans replied:
The situation demands close and careful analysis, which the Government is undertaking as a matter of urgency.

At the same time that the Government was taking close and careful analysis the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation nations had shown their complete dismay that America would break SALT II. In fact, they had communicated in the strongest terms with the United States Government. While the Australian Government was considering the issues, the United States Congress was up in arms. I refer to an article in the Age of 2 June 1986, which states:
Washington, 1 June-President Reagan's apparent decision to abandon the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty is expected to provoke an uproar in Congress this week.
Aides for several senators, both Republicans and Democrats, were drafting a binding resolution that would require continuing United States compliance with Salt 2.

Yet in Australia we were considering the issue. The next day I asked Senator Gareth Evans whether the Australian Government would take immediate steps to inform the American Government of our concern and, furthermore, I asked, since SALT II was the underpinning for the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, whether we would consider withdrawing from that Treaty if SALT II were abandoned. We got the usual invective from Senator Gareth Evans. He said: `We feel it is important, but we are still looking at it'. He said:

The nature of the Australian Government's response-a constructive response, it will be hoped-is being very actively considered by the Government at the moment. But the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty has been perhaps the only but certainly the most conspicuously successful of the arms control agreements.
The Americans do not agree. Senator Dale Bumpers said:
Salt 2 is the only treaty, ratified or unratified that keeps the nuclear arms race under control.

The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty has not stopped the proliferation of nuclear weapons. South Africa, Israel and India now have the bomb. Pakistan will have it shortly. None of these are Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty members. Members who are in the nuclear club who are members of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty are exempt from any consideration. It seems that all that Treaty means to us and to this Government is an excuse to sell uranium. We have been told over and over in this chamber that under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty we have the moral obligation to sell uranium. If the Treaty does not work as a treaty to prevent nuclear arms and if it works only as a justification for selling uranium, Australia should abandon it. We should take the high moral ground of abandoning the sale of uranium and thus abandoning our support of any nuclear warfare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In welcoming the tabling of the report of the Australian delegation to the 1985 session of the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva and the text of a statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), it is important to state that the work of the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva must go on, but that on its own it is not enough to achieve nuclear disarmament, as we have seen. The first statement, in most of the eight sections which were dealt with by the Conference on Disarmament, blandly admits that no substantive work was done in 1985, which I think is a damning indictment of the pace at which things work at the diplomatic level. However, these diplomatic efforts are important. But the people at the grass roots level are tired of the rhetoric; they are tired of words, and they want action.

SPEECH.PARA: I am one of those people to whom Senator Cook referred earlier when he said that while people have welcomed to a certain extent the Government initiatives that have been made in this country, they do not go far enough. In particular, he mentioned the South Pacific nuclear free zone, which allows more nuclear activity than it bans. It allows 12 out of the 20 categories of possible nuclear activity in this region. Of course it does not go far enough, but it is an important first stage. Similarly, the anti-nuclear legislation which is to be introduced tomorrow in the House of Representatives by the Foreign Minister, will disallow any future activities with nuclear weapons and the permanent stationing of nuclear weapons on Australian soil. They are not here now-at least that is the commonly held belief. Of course, we cannot be quite sure because we do not know exactly what goes on at Pine Gap. However, that legislation will not change anything at all with regard to the ways in which Australia is currently involved in the nuclear arms race.

While those initiatives are welcomed, it is important to say that they just do not go far enough. Every effort that is made by the Australian Government carefully sidesteps offending our great friend and ally, the United States of America. The good efforts that are made in Geneva, on the comprehensive test ban treaty in particular, are constantly stymied at every turn by the United States Government's intransigence, especially on the issue of working towards a negotiating mandate on a comprehensive test ban.

I want to refer to Mr Hayden's tabling statement-one statement which he made which I cannot let go unchallenged. I cannot believe the statement that the Foreign Minister made when he said that the Soviet Union's temporary moratorium on nuclear testing was welcomed by Australia. After asking repeated questions in this place I got an answer from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who represents the Minister for Foreign Affairs, that the Australian Government did not view this initiative seriously; that the Australian Government was more concerned about working on a comprehensive test ban and that a moratorium was not a replacement for a comprehensive test ban. We were not suggesting that it was a replacement but that it was a jolly good first step and that it was an initiative that should not have been ignored.

When the Ambassador for Disarmament was speaking to the parliamentary disarmament group about this question, he said that the Soviet moratorium was a unilateral, empty gesture and we would not waste our time on it. Now that was said by the Ambassador for Disarmament, so how Mr Hayden has the gall to get up and say that the Soviet Union's temporary moratorium on nuclear testing was welcomed by Australia, I do not know. I do not think it was welcomed at all, it was absolutely ignored, as it was by our great friend and ally, the United States of America.

Looking at the report itself we see on page 8 that the Soviet Union and the neutral and non-aligned countries continue to press, as in previous years, for negotiations on all items on the conference's agenda, whereas we see that the United States was opposed to any mandate calling for negotiation of a treaty. It regards the CTB as a long term objective and not something which should be negotiated at present. Therefore, the western group was not able to agree to such a mandate.

DEBATE.TITLE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE STANDING COMMITTEE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Land Acquisition in New South Wales by the Army

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Senator McIntosh:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the intervening time the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities has been tabled, to my advantage to some degree, because a number of points made in the Dibb Review lend support to the Committee's position on Army land acquisition. Dibb recommended, for example, the shifting of more regular forces to northern Australia and he also recommended giving no priority to mechanised forces; reducing the number of tanks in service and putting some of those into reserve; and reducing the role of medium artillery; that is, 155mm guns. All these recommendations reduce the need for a large manoeuvre area by reducing the number of regular forces in south-eastern Australia and reducing the priority for armoured-mechanised forces and medium artillery. Dibb also recommended more light, air mobile, operational deployment type forces which would not require a Cobar manoeuvre area on which to train. The Committee recommended against the use of the Cobar area.

SPEECH.PARA: No priority is to be given to ground attack aircraft and helicopters. The Royal Australian Air Force requirement for Cobar included the need to exercise such aircraft. Dibb also recommended a program of sustained exercises in northern Australia which would include deployment of reservists from southern Australia. Given the limited time and resources of the Army Reserve, any increase in training in the north will result in a reduced training requirement in the south. Again, the Committee did not agree that the centre of gravity was in the south.

At the very least, the contents of the Dibb report support the Committee's conclusion that any further consideration of the requirements for a manoeuvre area in south-eastern Australia should be deferred until policy decisions which may flow from the Dibb report have been implemented. This is to be found on page 17 of the report. Further, it should be argued that if consideration of the manoeuvre proposal is to be deferred further consideration of Cobar should be ruled out in the interests of removing the blight on the area. I conclude by saying that we are looking forward to seeing the land acquisition Bill to find out whether it covers injurious effects or blight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence report on Land Acquisition in New South Wales by the Army. The Committee was formed because the Department of Defence and the Australian Army indicated last year that they were seeking two pieces of land, one to collocate a school of artillery and a school of infantry and the other for a major manoeuvre area. To get some idea of the dimensions, the original idea was for the collocated schools to occupy 160,000 hectares of land and the other area was to occupy some two million hectares of land. When the two areas were named there was, as one would expect, a large public outcry. Other areas had been named before but specifically Bathurst-Orange was named for the schools and Cobar was named for the manoeuvre area. One hundred-odd farming families with farming properties protested vigorously, as did many others in Cobar.

SPEECH.PARA: When examining the defence estimates last year honourable senators asked a series of questions and, in their view, they got unsatisfactory answers. As a result this Committee was formed.

Let me say that the Committee was unanimous in its report which is before the Senate. The Committee first of all went to Singleton where there exists an infantry training school. Singleton was given a user requirement for an infantry training school. That user requirement specified that the infantry training school would be for those coming out of Kapooka, having just been recruited, who would be doing their initial infantry training. One of the main requirements was that the climate should be such, both day and night, that, for at least ten months of the year, numbers of soldiers could use that area to do their outdoor training. Another requirement was that the area itself should be basically rolling, undulating, easy and lightly treed country so that these soldiers could do their initial training. Indeed, this was a perfect description of the army camp that we were in at Singleton.

I should interpolate that the Committee subsequently heard evidence from past commandants of that infantry training school, some of whom had done reconnaissance work in the Bathurst-Orange area, who were emphatic that the Singleton base ought not be changed and that the alternative was not suitable in any way. When we faced up to the artillery school we were told that there would need to be a massive impact area for the artillery to shoot upon and that it had to have particular environmental characteristics. Of course, when we looked at Bathurst-Orange we realised that, with all the compromise in the world, we could not fit the user requirement to a climate and a landscape that could not be more different from that described at Singleton.

Bathurst-Orange, with its extremes of climate in autumn and winter and with its fogs and rough terrain, was completely out of the question in justifying the user requirement. Originally an area of 160,000 hectares was envisaged and that was cut down to 70,000 hectares. The environmental impact study done by Dames and Moore said that the only impact area for artillery existed outside the 70,000 hectares. In other words, choice of the area would be wrong because it could not have an impact area. When the Committee saw the map showing the impact area covering the smaller area, we found it straddled the Macquarie River. We found that use of the area would deny to the people of Australia 30 kilometres of the Macquarie River and that the impact area would have artillery shells bursting on top of hills and pushing debris down into a river which was to flow into the Burrendong Dam. Time after time everything that we saw was totally against the use of Bathurst-Orange. Why was Bathurst-Orange ever dreamed of? The suggestion was that the New South Wales Government offered it because a proposed growth centre there had failed and was in debt to approximately $90m and this was some kind of an adjustment to suit politically. In any case there could not have been a more unsuitable area altogether, apart from the damage to some 100 families that have farmed there for centuries. Indeed, in the end the Government saw the impossibility of the situation and withdrew Bathurst-Orange. We decided that the infantry training centre should stay at Singleton, where upgraded facilities would make it quite suitable.

On the question of artillery, there is a school at North Head at present. There is an agreement between the New South Wales and Commonwealth governments that it should be ultimately removed from North Head. A tentative date of the 1990 vintage is there, but that could be renegotiated. In any case, there are other areas to look at-Puckapunyal and elsewhere-and, depending upon the Dibb report, perhaps areas outside this State. The manoeuvre area presented an impossible situation because the user requirement, as we were told, was for an armoured corps usage; that is, that some 3,000 troops with Leopard tanks and all the accoutrements of an armoured corps would move over this area in massive waves-digging holes, living there, cutting down fences and moving through the place. Yet here was a western land division which was created in order to preserve the area because it is so fragile. The very fragility of the area simply precludes the movement of large numbers of troops or large numbers of mechanised forces.

The more ridiculous situation is the one to which the Chairman of the Committee, Senator McIntosh, has drawn our attention. Here was an attempt at establishing a manoeuvre area in a place which in no way could fit any kind of environment, in which the troops were likely to be deployed in action, an area where there might be a threat. If there was to be a threat-Dibb has indicated northern Australia-one would need the higher rainfall, higher treed, more grassy lands in northern Australia, the sub-tropical and tropical climates, instead of this incredible area that was chosen.

We damaged the ecology with our ordinary vehicles. Topsoil of about nine inches would really be something around here, whereas there one could take a spade and push it into 17 feet of material that was really bulldust. We realised what an enormous and incongruous situation it was that this area should ever have been allowed to come under consideration. The report was very critical of the Department of Defence for the method by which it approached us, for its failure to be forthcoming in evidence, and for the failure to disclose evidence which was vital to us and which had to be secured by freedom of information. Above all, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had written to people in both areas and said that there would not be compulsory acquisition or forced dispossession of land. That would have been vital. Our Committee could have finished because nobody there was going to give voluntary possession. Over the months we could not get an answer from the Department of Defence as to whether that was the continued stated policy. So we were frustrated all the time. The Dibb report has made it abundantly clear that Cobar is the wrong place in every measure. The corps brigade movements are nonsense in training. The Government should now get out of Cobar and release the people from their bondage. They cannot sell or move at this moment; they are under a blight of forced dispossession. The fact is that the Prime Minister has said there will be no compulsory acquisitions. I take it that that is Government policy. If that is so, we should abandon Cobar today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence was considering two really quite independent proposals for the acquisition of land by the Army. The first was to set up a combined infantry and artillery school in the Bathurst-Orange area, an area in which, as Senator Sir John Carrick has said, it was asking for 73,000 hectares. But a quite separate requirement from the Army for land was for a new manoeuvre area. It had its eye on the western division of New South Wales and Dubbo. That was to allow one brigade to exercise. One brigade has armour, mobile infantry, artillery and combat engineers and, for training at brigade scale exercises, the Army was looking at one million hectares, a very large area indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: In considering these proposals the Committee really had to look at four hurdles these proposals had to get over before they could be justified. The first was whether a case for the need, which was strategic in the case of the manoeuvre area and training in the case of the combined school of infantry and artillery, had been made out. Secondly, if the case had been made out, were the requirements fairly stated? Thirdly, did the proposed sites meet the user requirements? Finally, and quite separately, were the land acquisition processes fair and reasonable?

I will deal with the land acquisition processes first. The Committee decided to defer this because the Commonwealth is making major amendments to the Commonwealth Lands Acquisition Act. It is appropriate that we should look at those amendments to the new Act when it is in force. The whole situation of acquisition was totally confused by the promises made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-admittedly, I think, in terms of an impending election; nevertheless he made promises which were stated publicly and were widely known in the area-that the Government had no intention of compulsorily acquiring productive land for Department of Defence proposals; secondly, that the Government had no intention of forcibly dispossessing people; and, finally, that the decision should be made very quickly, and this was in June 1984, regarding Defence Department requirements. We had a great deal of difficulty finding out whether the Prime Minister meant what he said and whether the promises still held. We had the impression that these, like many other promises made by Mr Hawke, were rather disposable promises. Nevertheless, they were apparently in force as government policy and we could not get a clear answer out of the Defence Department as to whether they were still in force. If they were in force, neither of the two proposals was remotely feasible. Both of them involved compulsory acquisition in the Bathurst-Orange area or forcible dispossession by taking over the leases in the Dubbo area. We could not get a sensible answer from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet or from the Department of Defence on whether this very clear promise made by the Prime Minister still stood. That subject of the acquisition processes has been deferred by the Committee, which will have another look at it when the revised Act has been produced.

I would like to look at the other criteria enumerated-first, the manoeuvre area, the one million hectares in the Dubbo area. I felt-I am sure the other members of the Committee felt the same-that the Defence Department made out no credible case on the need for such an area. Senator Sir John Carrick has dealt in some detail with that. I will not repeat it except to say that the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, which would appear likely to be government policy, confirms our feeling that the case for the requirement of such a large, mechanised training area for tanks and armoured personnel carriers, mobile infantry and so on has not been made out. Even if such an area were required it would seem most unlikely, indeed impossible, that the Dubbo area would be suitable. We want an area that is not so ecologically fragile and is much closer to the type of terrain on which this brigade, if ever it were deployed, would be fighting. On both counts Dubbo failed.

A point that made me curious when we were discussing this matter with the Defence Department was that the Department rather shifted ground on why the training area should be located there and made a great deal of the need for training the Army Reserve. In the user requirement, the requirement for Reserve training is barely mentioned. However, when we came to pin the Defence Department down why it was necessary to have it in that area and why the Department should pick an area that was so unsuitable, that was ecologically unsound and was nothing like the terrain over which there might be fighting, the main argument was that it was convenient for the Reserve for its short period of training. That may be so, but the user requirement did not fairly reflect what the Army later said it wanted. As for the question whether the area met the user requirement, quite clearly it did not meet the requirement-even as stated. It was a most unsuitable area from every point of view. It was ecologically unsuitable. It was not credible as a suitable training area for the terrain on which there might be fighting. I think the Department made no case. I think it has to go back and think through again exactly what it wants. I think there will be a great deal of re-examination and new proposals coming forward. I very much doubt whether it could make a case for that area at all. I think we should strike that area off.

The need for a new combined artillery and infantry training school really arises from the agreement that the Army School of Artillery at North Head in Sydney should move out. I think that is proper, but I would like to point out that, if we look at Australia's two biggest cities, Sydney and Melbourne, we see that the areas that have been preserved best are the ones that are in the hands of the Defence Department. If we look around Sydney Harbour we will see that the only large areas that have been preserved are the old Defence reserves-North Head, South Head and Middle Head. I am not saying that all the defence areas have been preserved, but without defence preservation Sydney Harbour would be a much poorer place. I do not think we should be in any rush to move the Army at great inconvenience out of North Head. I think the Army would probably preserve it very much better than the New South Wales Government would. I think eventually the School of Artillery will have to go, but the issue really is in regard to the argument for moving the infantry school from Singleton, which everyone regards as an admirable site for infantry training, at great expense into the new collocated school. We found no arguments for it.

We would like to see a new and separate requirement for a school of artillery. No good arguments have been produced for combining it at great expense with the infantry school. Secondly, we thought that the range and schools areas were very much larger than were really needed. The Department really was considering what it would need in extreme circumstances rather than what was adequate for training in a much smaller area. We thought that priority should be given to locating this school wholly on existing Army facilities-Puckapunyal is a possibility-or other Commonwealth land. We did not think that the examination of the sites for this new school of artillery should be confined to New South Wales. In the view of the Committee, both proposals failed. We thought that a case had not been made out in regard to the first point, that the case for the user requirement was not an accurate one, and that the sites selected were not themselves suitable.

I would like just to say something about the attitude of the Department of Defence. We found a great deal of difficulty getting information out of that Department. It seemed to conceal things that should properly have been put before the Committee. We know-it is fairly obvious-that there is a deep division between the Defence Department and the Army over the desirability of these training areas. The Department of Defence did not present a good case. It was not entirely frank with the Committee. A great deal of very relevant information was found by way of freedom of information requests rather than, as should have been the case, it being given to the Committee by the Defence Department.

Finally, I would like to say that this investigation and its results are an example of the importance of our Senate committees. If this Government controlled the Senate or if there were no Senate committees, that proposal would have gone through. It was only because of the possibility of public examination of the issues and the resulting revelation of the mistakes, inconsistencies and inadequacies of the proposals that we stopped what would have been a major error made by this Government. That is to the credit of the Senate and its committee system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like, first, to support Senator Sir John Carrick's request to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) to make an announcement immediately that the Army will get out of Cobar. In the light of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence there is no excuse whatsoever for continued shilly-shallying by the Army over this matter. The landholders in that area have every right to be put out of the misery to which they have been exposed for so long. I would also like to support what Senator Hamer said about the necessity for this investigation and to recall that at the time I sought reference of this matter to the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee it was utterly opposed by the Government. I was supported, as I recall, by all other Opposition senators from New South Wales. I think that is an almost unprecedented occurrence. I commend those honourable senators for their excellent judgment. Also I commend the Committee for its deliberations. Obviously Committee members have taken a great deal of time and trouble to unravel a very lengthy and tangled skein in the teeth of considerable opposition by the Department of Defence.

SPEECH.PARA: That section of the introduction to the First Report on Land Acquisition in New South Wales by the Australian Army which deals with the conduct of the Department of Defence makes very interesting and informative reading. It is obvious that members of the Committee had to use much torturous and convoluted questioning to obtain facts which they could use in their conclusions. Indeed, it is a tribute to them that in the end they did uncover all this information from a department which appears to have been influenced by the television series Yes Minister. This is a serious matter because it is intolerable that the large intrusions on public cost which this matter has caused over the years should be simply accepted and blinked away. It is not good enough for officials and for a government department such as the Defence Department to come forward with matters which in fact are not true and which are proven not to be justified and for them not to expect an examination of the enormous cost which they have caused the community and the taxpayer. I think that that is something that has to be borne in mind.

As I said when I proposed this reference to the Committee, I have seldom seen a better example of the saying `Kanson mimpi'-I am sure Senator Sir John Carrick will know that it is a Japanese Tokugawa samurai saying-which means `officially exalted people despised'. This extraordinary departmental evasiveness, double-talk and official shiftiness has been going on for a decade. It is very interesting to note that without the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act it might well still be going on, because the Committee found under that Act information that directly contradicted evidence given by departmental officers. That is a serious indictment of that Department.

There are important lessons in this matter for the future. Every time that the Army has favoured a locality with doubtful intentions it has had catastrophic effects on the people of that region. Land values have plummeted. Persons facing the need to sell for urgent and personal reasons have not been able to sell and farmers have seen little point in developing their properties by making constructive improvements. All these things are not good for the economy or for Australia. This especially applies in the Orange-Bathurst area where the land proposed to be acquired is a first-class fine wool area. This is a time when there is a very ready market for fine and super-fine wool. It is a time when we need every cent of export income we can get. This matter goes back 12 years ago to 1974 when the Army decided to acquire 200,000 hectares at Colo-Putty for relocation of the artillery and infantry schools and for a manoeuvres area. The matter dragged on until 1977 when the Army chose Dubbo as a favoured site for the new training facilities and Cobar as a favoured site for manoeuvres. There was a further hiatus, a very leisurely one-only five years that time-until February 1982 when Mr Killen, the then Minister for Defence, and the New South Wales Premier, Mr Wran, ordered further studies of the Dubbo and Cobar areas. But then New South Wales government departments suggested other areas, including Parkes, Forbes, Wellington, Broken Hill and, for the first time, Orange-Bathurst as possible schools areas.

The manoeuvres area requirement, it is important to recall, was no less than 2 million hectares-rather more than the 200,000 hectares suggested in 1974 and considerably larger than some major European countries. That was the Army's initial requirement. Yet it was a serious proposition put forward seriously by the Army and the Government at that time. At that stage, landholders in all those areas naturally became agitated and their position became insecure. The value of their property was immediately affected. In 1982, the Federal-State steering committee for Army training facilities decided that land south of Cobar would be suitable for the manoeuvres area. In May 1985 Singleton and Dubbo were rejected for the schools area, and Bathurst-Orange again became subject to a detailed environmental study as a site for that purpose. All this time, in all those areas, a catastrophic effect was being felt by the community and landholders concerned. It was a terrible lesson for the community.

The matter was further confused in 1984 when, as honourable senators will remember, we had an election. During that campaign the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was in the Orange- Bathurst area and, according to statutory declarations I have seen, he gave frequent assurances to the people in that area that whatever happened there would not be an Army land grab in the Bathurst-Orange area. A further complication and further uncertainty was then introduced. However, in spite of what the Prime Minister said at that stage and in spite of those clear assurances, we found in October last year that the Army's intentions again clearly were centred around the Bathurst-Orange area. It was at that stage that I felt that it was absolutely essential that the terrifying succession of events which were emerging, for anybody who had given them any sort of study, must be brought out into the clear light of day. It seemed to me that the only way the matter could be brought out into the clear light of day was by an investigation by a committee of the Senate. That has been the case. This report addresses that subject, not only adequately but also with great tenacity and clarity. In many ways this report will be seen as something of a yardstick for achievements of the Senate committee system. I agree with Senator Hamer on that point.

Of course, we have the happy ending. The Army has now withdrawn its bid to take over productive farm land in the Orange-Bathurst area. It must do the same thing immediately where Cobar is concerned. The decision has been noteworthy too because it has been a triumph for members of the citizens movement concerned. I commend them for their persistence, their organisation and the determination with which they decided to dig in and fight this bureaucratic attempt to virtually destroy them without reason, and to destroy elements of this country and its economy without reason which is an even more serious matter. It is a classic lesson on how vigilant the community has to be when it deals with some sections of the bureaucracy. People in the same area who have the same sorts of problems might realise that the Government is not always there to help them. It should be there to help them; that should be its function. That is what a public servant is supposed to be about. I hope that the Government-and I say that to the Minister sitting here now, Senator Gareth Evans, who is representing the Minister for Defence in this place-has taken some note of the lessons in this matter. The Government should get up and freely acknowledge that it was wrong on this matter and that it was wrong to oppose this reference in the first place. I hope it will curb the bureaucracy and take a much stronger and harsher view of bureaucracy especially the areas of land acquisition in the future as a result of the object lesson that this presents.

I look forward to subsequent reports of the Committee under this subject, because this is not the end of the matter. In particular, I will be most interested to read the conclusions of part (c) of the Committee's terms of reference which states:

. . . the adequacy and appropriateness of current procedures in protecting the rights of individual landholders and communities in areas where acquisition is contemplated, in providing for fair and prompt compensation, and in providing for appeal procedures.

That is a very important objective. If this Senate committee system can achieve that objective, if it can make suggestions to the Government, and land acquisition legislation can be amended accordingly, the Committee will have done a tremendous service to this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also commend this report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and congratulate the Committee for the speed and diligence which it has shown in bringing down this report so quickly. I would like to congratulate especially the Chairman of the Committee, Senator McIntosh, for the way he made his Committee work so hard in getting on with the job. I would also like to particularly mention the three honourable senators from this side of the House who I know worked very hard too, especially Senator Sir John Carrick. The Committee looked at the need for the Army training areas. It has looked at the availability of sites which have been subject to acquisition. I have been involved from the outset because of the possibility of the taking of productive farm land and the disruption to the community in the area subject to the acquisition by the Government which is in my State of New South Wales. That is the reason I have been very interested in this matter from the start.

SPEECH.PARA: The trauma and hardship caused to people in areas which are under threat of acquisition cannot be too highly stated. The Bathurst and Orange areas, of course, have already been relieved of the cloak that has been held over their heads for so long. Businesses, communities, property owners and employees have suffered because of this threat hanging over their heads. The Cobar area is still under threat. With the environment being as fragile as it is there I am quite sure that the environmental impact study will come up with the same conclusions as those of this Committee, that the area is not appropriate for an Army training base. The area must now be released in order to remove the trauma of the threat of acquisition from those people. The Committee has advised that the Singleton area is adequate and that it is a good area for the infantry training base. The people in that area too should be relieved of the worry that the base might have been taken away. That worry should have been taken out of the air straight away by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) making a complete and unequivocal statement that the base is to stay at Singleton. The Singleton area in the Hunter Valley has suffered for too long. I commend this report. Again, I congratulate the Senate Committee in being so quick and diligent in its actions and its findings, and for coming back to the Senate so quickly with its report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of the members of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which investigated the Army acquisition of land in both Cobar and the Orange-Bathurst areas, I would like to place my thanks on public record to Senator McIntosh, as the Chairman of that Committee, and of course, Senator Sir John Carrick, who put in so much work. I felt that it was a very worthwhile exercise to study the problems which the farmers in the Bathurst-Orange area were experiencing with the threat of acquisition on what was originally 173,000 hectares of land. Later that area was reduced to 73,000 hectares. We found that the overwhelming evidence pointed to the fact that 73,000 hectares in the Bathurst-Orange area would have been insufficient to allow the Army to take in all the facilities. The area would have been insufficient for what the Army required.

SPEECH.PARA: We then travelled to Cobar only six or seven weeks ago and investigated that area. We spent some time flying around the area. We then drove around the Cobar district in four-wheel drives. We met many people who expressed concern for their land. Many children who spoke to us expressed their fears that their farms and animals would be taken away from them. We also noted when driving around in four-wheel drive vehicles that the soil was deep and fragile. At one stage we moved off the track and even our four-wheel drive vehicles began to become bogged. It was obvious to us that heavy army vehicles would get bogged and that the big trenches left by them would cause erosion. I believe that the report that has been put down is a good one. It is certainly one on which a lot of time has been spent. I hope that the recommendations in the report are taken up by the Parliament and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an excellent report from the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. I would like to commend the six senators who conducted such a thorough investigation into land acquisition in New South Wales by the Australian Army. I trust that their further work on this matter will be as illuminating as is the current report. The report is a disturbing one for the Senate; it should be a troubling one for the Department of Defence; and I believe that it is a very important one for the Australian people. It is clear that the Department had not properly costed its proposals. Furthermore, the Department decided to withhold from the Committee information that did not advance its proposals. I believe that that is the most serious aspect which is covered in the introduction to the report. Even though the Committee pressed the Department of Defence for the relevant documents, it was basically fobbed off. The Committee was told that what was significant had been provided to the Committee. The Secretary to the Committee was told:

SPEECH.PARA: The other papers relate to the deliberative processes of government and are not of a kind appropriate for release.

This is Yes Minister stuff. It is Yes Minister type of activity at its worst. It is highly significant that private individuals eventually obtained the material under the Freedom of Information Act. The documents that were obtained in fact did not relate to the deliberative processes of government. Without the Freedom of Information Act, the Committee, and possibly the people of Australia, may have remained in the dark and a disgraceful miscarriage of government activity could have taken place. It is a disgrace that the relevant information had to surface in such a fashion.

The principles of open government will have to be enunciated much more strongly by the upper echelons of the Department of Defence and be reinforced by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). The Department has just come to us with a $290m request for additional estimates. This is on top of the allocation of $6,212m in the 1985-86 Budget. With that sort of expenditure, this Parliament must make sure that the best possible value is obtained for those enormous sums. It would be absolutely outrageous to cut down welfare and other expenditure and tolerate waste of the kind that has been shown to occur by the Committee and the waste which would have taken place had the Committee not acted effectively and had a group of public minded citizens not brought the matter to the attention of the Committee.

No department should be allowed to waste large amounts of money, time and resources blindly defending decisions that were absolutely inappropriate in the first place. I hope that the Minister and his advisers, the watchdogs in the Department's own internal audit section or people from the Department of Finance will quickly put an end to this type of misbehaviour. In this case, though, it was left to public indignation and the open processes of the Senate committee system.

The Committee has pointed out that the Department of Defence could not provide it with detailed costings associated with the development of the manoeuvre area. It could not tell the Committee what the cost of the Cobar proposal was. The Committee has pointed out that the terrain at Cobar was totally unsuitable for what the Department of Defence said it wanted to do. Factors such as environmental damage, dislocation for local grazing, dislocation of civil aviation had not properly been taken into account despite the investigation that had supposedly been carried out by the Department. In fact, the Department failed to make available to the Committee even the information that it did have. How can we allow millions of dollars to be spent on such unjustifiable pursuits? At page 28 of the report the Committee says:

The unpredictability of rainfall is a very significant factor in the lives of landholders and is potentially a serious problem for Army planners seeking to organise exercises months or years in advance.

The pattern of rainfall shown by these statistics also suggests that the claim by the Department in evidence to the Committee, that by exercising between March and November the Army would avoid the risk of having exercises washed out, was nothing short of wishful thinking. In fact, the statistics show that 70 per cent of the annual rainfall occurs in those months. The significance of the fact that very high rainfall can occur on single days is that creeks can rise very quickly, soil can become saturated and large volumes of water can accumulate in ditches and in vehicle tracks, thus impeding the movement of vehicles and people and as Senator Boswell said, there would be a significant risk of erosion. If this is indicative of the type of defence planning we have in this country, we should be examining the expenditure in the defence budget much more closely.

I believe that the proposal would never have got off the ground if people inside the Defence Department had in fact thought about it logically. I believe that this Parliament must take a keener interest in the processes and allocations to the Department. We must look at projects on an individual basis. We have not seen the figures in respect of a similar range which is planned between Port Gawler and Port Prime in my own State of South Australia. This project may well be worth investigating.

We should look at the purchase by the Army of Australian equipment. We should not just automatically buy overseas. Nothing seems to be done in this respect. Our offsets program is not taken seriously by people in the Department of Defence, to say nothing of the supplies. During an Estimates committee meeting I was told by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) that there are currently in the system $600m of outstanding offsets. This matter should be investigated as well. The enormous amount of money that is allocated to defence should be spent to ensure that we get a strong and independent Australia and we should not be left with very large bills as a result of the Department avoiding giving information to this Parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE BROADCASTING OF PARLIAMENTARY PROCEEDINGS

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings on its inquiry into televising and radio broadcasting of both Houses and their committees, together with a copy of the transcript of evidence and a copy of the Committee's minutes of proceedings relating to the inquiry.

INTERJECT.PARA: The report reflects deliberations of the Committee extending over 3 1/2 years and three parliaments. During that time the Committee received evidence and consulted with members of parliament, parliamentary officers, broadcasting organisations, other specific interest groups and citizens of Australia. There were changes in the Committee's membership during that time and the Speaker and I commend members of the Committee, past and present, for the effort they devoted to the task of forming recommendations to both Houses on the vital question of the electronic delivery of proceedings. I pay particular tribute to the work of the former Speaker and Chairman of the Committee, the Honourable Dr. H. A. Jenkins.

Among the principal recommendations of the Committee are that continuous radio broadcasting of the proceedings of the Houses should continue, with the allocation of the broadcast being determined by the Committee, as is the current practice. The Committee also recommends that the broadcast of proceedings be extended to cover adjournment debates. The report also recommends that a parliamentary radio network be established and that the proceedings of parliamentary committees, meeting when neither House is sitting, be available for radio broadcasting. The report recommends that broadcasting of recorded excerpts of proceedings be authorised on a permanent basis, provided that the trial period is satisfactory. When the Committee's special report recommending the re-broadcast of excerpts was presented in the Senate, an undertaking was given to inform the Senate of the results of monitoring of television and radio station usage. That information is contained in an appendix to the report.

In relation to televising of proceedings, the Committee has recommended against televising in the provisional Parliament House but that proceedings of the Senate and the House of Representatives and their committees be available for televising in the new Parliament House, subject to guidelines which were adopted for the televising of the Budget speeches in the House of Representatives. However, there should be no compulsion to televise proceedings. The Committee has also recommended the establishment of a Parliamentary Audio Visual Unit. The report contains a number of other recommendations relating to protection provided to broadcasters, the impact of access of the electronic media on parliamentary practices or conventions, control of access to the sound and vision signals and revision of the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Mr President, I commend you on the remarks you have made. The Australian Parliament was the second national parliament of the Commonwealth to introduce the broadcasting of proceedings. These broadcasts of proceedings are overshadowed, as it were, by the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, which is made up of members drawn from the two major parties from both Houses. The Joint Committee is required by the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act to report to each House on the general principles concerning the broadcasting of proceedings of each House and to determine the allocation of broadcasts in accordance with the general principles adopted by each House.

In 1982 the Committee was given a reference by the Parliament to look into a number of issues. Those terms of reference were widened in 1983 to include the televising of the proceedings of the Houses of Parliament and their committees in the present and the new Parliament House and the radio broadcasts of proceedings of both Houses of Parliament and their committees, including the continuous and simultaneous broadcasts of both Houses.

I take this opportunity to commend Dr Jenkins for his leadership through practically the whole of this very long and exhaustive inquiry. I pay tribute to you, Mr President, for your part and to my colleague Senator Ruth Coleman, because I think the three of us from the Senate were the only members who saw the inquiry through from beginning to end.

The Committee's recommendations are quite significant. As you mentioned, Mr President, the first recommendation is that the continuous broadcasts of the proceedings of the Houses of Parliament should continue. A number of honourable senators will be pleased that we have decided to recommend the inclusion both of the adjournment debate and of the proceedings of parliamentary committees, provided in the latter case that either House is not sitting. The establishment of a parliamentary network, I believe, is a forward move because it will relieve the Australian Broadcasting Corporation of the responsibility for parliamentary broadcasts. The new body will be under the control of the Parliament. It will undertake to establish a network Australia-wide for as little as about $1.5m. The establishment of a Parliamentary Audio Visual Unit is also an important recommendation because this will make available for transmission live or recorded segments for use in documentaries and news commentaries. While there will be a continuous broadcasting on radio, the televising of Parliament will be as required by the various networks. In other words, there will be no compulsion on the televising of Parliament; the networks can pick up the signal as needed. I think this is a significant recommendation. The report has only just come to the Parliament, but I commend its reading to all honourable senators.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The conditions for granting access to proceedings of the Senate and the House of Representatives for the purpose of recording and broadcasting excerpts, as contained in appendix 2 to the report of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, which I have just presented, were those in effect when the Committee agreed to the report. On 2 June 1986 the Committee agreed that guidelines 5a and 7 be amended as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: 5a. Excerpts of proceedings which are subsequently withdrawn shall be available for re-broadcast provided the withdrawal is also reported.
7. Events in the Galleries are not part of the proceedings and excerpts in relation to such events, as far as is practicable, should not be used.
The revised conditions for access are to take effect as from 5 June 1986 and copies are being circulated for the information of honourable senators.
