DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND THE ENVIRONMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment, I present a report on annual reports of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Department of Territories, together with a transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Committee held a hearing following the tabling of the Government's 27 November 1985 response to the Committee's report on the Preservation of the Abbott's Booby on Christmas Island. The Committee's report was tabled on 2 November 1983. The inquiry into the preservation of the endangered Abbott's Booby on Christmas Island arose out of the consideration of the annual report for 1980-81 for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service.

The transcript of evidence contains up-to-date information on measures being taken for the preservation of the Abbott's Booby, and matters relating to the future of Christmas Island once the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island ceases its mining operations. It was announced in October 1985 that the major A-grade mining operation would close down by the end of 1986. However, a working group has been investigating ways of maintaining the mine's economic viability. Currently it is uncertain how long the mine will continue to operate.

The Committee heard evidence on the Abbott's Booby Monitoring Program; on the extension of Christmas Island National Park; on measures being taken to rehabilitate mined out areas of the Island; and on alternative industries for Christmas Island once the mine closes.
Abbott's Booby Monitoring Program

The Abbott's Booby Monitoring Program established to monitor the breeding success of Abbott's Booby formally commenced on 1 July 1983. The October 1985 Report of the Abbott's Booby Monitoring Program Expert Panel, and the minutes of the meeting of the Expert Panel held on 9 October 1985 are incorporated in the Transcript.

Preliminary findings indicate that forest clearing does have deleterious effects on the birds' nesting success which diminish the value of the nesting habitat to at least 305 metres beyond the cleared areas. This is indicated by nests being abandoned at a greater rate near forest clearings, especially those clearings to the south-east of nest sites. If the tree containing the nest is also to the south-east, the situation is further aggravated. Areas within 305 metres of clearings have displayed a higher rate of nest site abandonment and have attracted proportionately fewer nests since 1979-80 than areas further away from clearings. Annual reoccupation of nest sites since 1979-80 has been approximately 86% within 305 metres of clearings, compared to about 96-98% beyond 760 metres. Birds occupying new sites have had lower nesting success than birds in familiar sites. Approximately 40% of the remaining known Abbott's Booby nesting habitat is beyond 305 metres, and approximately 12% is beyond 760 metres of existing clearings.
The Expert Panel's recommendations in the October 1985 Report are:
The study should run its full six years;
Clearing of intact forest within 305 metres of areas containing significant numbers of Abbott's Booby should be avoided, particularly when such clearing is to the South-East;
Rehabilitation of clearings near to and particularly to the South-East of significant concentrations of Abbott's Booby should be afforded priority.
The Expert Panel reported that the program is being satisfactorily jointly funded by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island.

The Abbott's Booby Monitoring Program is making a significant contribution to the understanding of the impact of clearing for phosphate mining operations on the breeding success of the Abbott's Booby. The findings are also relevant to any future activities on the island which involve clearing primary rainforest.
The Extension of Christmas Island National Park

In its 1983 Report on the Abbott's Booby, the Science, Technology and Environment Committee recommended that the inclusion of Block 22a and Smithson's Bight Terrace into Christmas Island National Park be investigated. Both are to the south-east of the National Park.

I am pleased to report to the Senate that two new areas were declared national park land on 13 January 1986. One area is 320 hectares of land adjoining the south-eastern end of the National Park, including Abbott's Booby habitat in or near Block 22a. The other is a 450 hectare segment of land at North-West Point, which contains significant nesting areas of other seabirds.
Rehabilitation

The need to increase the rate and area of the rehabilitation of mined out areas has been of major concern to the Committee. It was reported to the Committee that during the past two years the mining company has back-filled, top-soiled and planted areas comparable to those they have cleared. The areas where there are exposed limestone pinnacles are extremely difficult to rehabilitate. The cost of rehabilitation varies from $1,200 a hectare to $25,000 a hectare.

The Committee was told none of the current approved proposals for forest clearing endanger the Abbott's Booby nesting sites. However, if the full clearing program proposed the previous year went ahead, the nesting sites would be affected.

The main priority in terms of conservation is seen as maintaining the ecological integrity of the Island, and species protection. The other priority is to ascertain the extent which areas not of major ecological importance should be regenerated for non-conservation purposes such as market gardens.
The Committee welcomes the progress being made to rehabilitate mined areas and restore the Island's forests, and urges the continuation of rehabilitation and reafforestation measures.
Alternative Industries

The Committee also heard evidence on investigations into the feasibility of various alternative industries for Christmas Island once mining operations cease. The Department of Territories is interested in pursuing action on as many fronts as possible to maintain the future economic prosperity of the Island, and to enable a settled population to remain on the Island. The Land Use Study by the Western Australian Overseas Projects Authority completed in November 1985, is providing a basis for assessing proposals.

The development of tourism is one proposal. People interested in conservation or ornithology, in particular, are likely to be interested in visiting the Island. A proposal has been put forward to develop a hotel-style holiday village, which would include a casino. This is being seriously considered.

Another possibility is the establishment of a scientific research station. This is currently being examined by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Department of Territories, in consultation with various Commonwealth and private sector agencies.
Small agricultural and business enterprises should be feasible.
Conclusion
The Committee is generally happy with the efforts being made to preserve the Abbott's Booby, and to maintain the existing unique ecology of Christmas Island.
The Committee will continue to monitor the preservation of the Abbott's Booby on Christmas Island as part of its mandate to examine Annual Reports.
I commend the Transcript of Evidence to the attention of Honourable Senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement on a matter before the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter concerns the 1983-84 annual report of the Australian Capital Territory Parole Board. On 7 May I made a short statement, as the Chair of the Committee, about the non-tabling of the 1983-84 annual report of the Australian Capital Territory Parole Board. I mentioned in my statement the fact that the Committee had written to the Chairman of the Board in October 1985 and unfortunately and inexplicably had not received a reply, despite several inquiries. I sent a copy of my statement to both the Parole Board and the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) for their information.

SPEECH.PARA: I now inform the Senate that the Committee received an immediate reply from the Chairman of the Parole Board, Justice Gallop, informing the Committee of the reasons for the delay in preparing and tabling the 1983-84 annual report. The explanation seems to me to be rather weak-an oversight on the part of the Secretary of the Board; that person having other duties in the Attorney-General's Department-but the Chairman has indicated that the Board intends to remedy the situation forthwith, and that he will express his apology and regret to the Attorney-General. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter from the Board's Chairman.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator John Coates,
Chairman,
Standing Committee on Finance
and Government Operations,
Australian Senate,
Parliament House,
Canberra. A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Coates,

I am writing to you to respond, very belatedly, to your letter of 18 October 1985 and your statement to the Senate on 7 May 1986 concerning the failure of the Parole Board of the Australian Capital Territory to furnish its 1983-84 annual report. I apologise for the delay in answering your letter. It arrived while I was overseas and upon my return has been overlooked.

The failure to furnish the 1983-84 Annual Report has been rectified. The draft report and the 1984-85 draft Annual Report have been prepared. I am informed that it takes about three weeks to have them printed and they will then be furnished to the Attorney-General pursuant to s. 27a of the Parole Ordinance 1976 of the Australia Capital Territory.

The failure to furnish the 1983-84 Annual Report until now requires some further explanation. The Parole Board is comprised of a Chairman and four part-time members. It has no staff or premises of its own. The Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department kindly makes available an officer of that Department to perform the necessary duties as Secretary of the Board. Such duties are, of course additional to the discharge of his ordinary duties. Accommodation for meetings of the Board is provided by the Registrar of the Supreme Court of Australian Capital Territory.

The Chairmanship of the Board changed upon the resignation of Mr F. X. L. Connor, Q.C. as Chairman of the Board in February 1985. I myself was appointed by the Attorney-General as Chairman of the Board in May 1985, although I held an appointment as Acting Chairman prior to that date. The failure to furnish the 1983-84 Annual Report was, I am informed, due to an oversight on the part of the Secretary to the Board and the change in the personalia comprising the Board.

You mention in your letter of 18 October 1985 that there has been an apparent contravention of s. 34c of the Acts Interpretation Act. Section 34c relates to the requirements imposed by an Act of the Parliament. The obligation of my Board to prepare and furnish to the Attorney-General a report of its operations during the year is imposed by s. 27a of the Parole Ordinance 1976 of the Australian Capital Territory. I respectfully suggest therefore, that there has been no failure to comply with s. 34c of the Acts Interpretations Act 1901. I do agree, however, that s. 27a has not been compiled with and I shall be expressing my apology and regret to the Attorney-General.
I trust that the explanation herein is accepted and give an assurance that my Board's failure will be rectified at the earliest possible moment.
Yours sincerely,
J.F GALLOP
Chairman

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1986TAXATION (INTEREST ON UNDERPAYMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government I propose to move a technical amendment which has been circulated. The amendment is to clause 19 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1986, which proposes to insert a new section 169a in the Income Tax Assessment Act to facilitate the introduction of a system of self-assessment of income tax returns. In describing a taxpayer's income tax return, proposed new sub-section 169A (1) refers to a `return of the income' of a taxpayer, whereas other provisions in the Act refer to `return of income'. The amendment which I am proposing will do no more than bring that proposed new sub-section into line with other sections. As an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1986, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 25, clause 19, line 41, leave out `the'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the amendment is purely technical. The amendment is unexceptionable as far as the Opposition is concerned. Consequently, we see no problem with that amendment. However, I am a little concerned about the general implications of what the amendment means in relation to the clause, purely because the main thrust of the Opposition's objection to this part of the Bill-that is, that part dealing with the amendment of assessments-is very much tied up with our concern that there has been inadequate public discussion about the Government's move towards a system of self-assessment. This Bill has certainly sprung the system upon the community. Consequently, I do not think there has been a reasonable period for the community to discuss the implications of it. That is particularly evident when we consider the amendments that are proposed in this Bill to those sections of the Act dealing with the powers of the Commissioner of Taxation to amend assessments. Already there has been considerable community reaction to that matter. Consequently, that will be the subject of later debate. Subject to that being so, and there being no difficulty in terms of our debating those issues later, we see no problem with this Government amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1986, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 26, clause 19, after proposed new sub-section 169a (1), insert the following new sub-section:

`(1a) Notwithstanding sub-section (1), where, in a document furnished with a return of income of a taxpayer of a year of income and signed by or on behalf of the taxpayer, a question is raised that is relevant to the liability of the taxpayer to tax in respect of the year of income, the Commissioner shall give attention to that question.'.

I will refer briefly to that amendment. We are, of course, having a Committee stage debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1986. This piece of legislation introduces the provision for self-assessment, so it is a very important piece of legislation. The Australian Democrats generally support self-assessment. The present method of assessing tax returns is outdated and inefficient. Under the principle of self-assessment which we are now debating, each taxpayer will be charged with the responsibility of compiling his or her own return and assessing the amount of tax payable or the refund that should be received. The Australian Taxation Office will no longer examine every taxpayer's return. Instead, there will be a random audit of a percentage of the returns each year. If a taxpayer is found to be trying to defraud the system, taxes and penalties will have to be paid. On the other hand, if the taxpayer is found to have paid too much tax, there will be a refund, with interest, to the taxpayer.

Self-assessment is needed for a number of reasons, the Democrats believe, not the least of which is that the present system is falling down under its own weight. The job of vetting every individual taxpayer's return every year is a very difficult job for the staff of the Taxation Office. It is a soul destroying and very monotonous job. These highly competent, highly specialised members of the Office could be much better employed in random auditing and more investigative types of work. The self-assessment will free the staff of the Taxation Office to do just that. This is a good thing.

However, it is important to realise that under this legislation a period of three years can elapse before the Australian Taxation Office or the Commissioner of Taxation has to comment on an individual taxpayer's return. As we all know, tax law is extremely complex and it is very difficult for the ordinary taxpayer to be absolutely certain that his or her return, as filled in, complies with the principles of the taxation law. There could easily be all kinds of queries in the taxpayer's mind. The Australian Democrats felt that it was unfair for the Taxation Office to be completely freed of any responsibility to answer genuine questions, at least in principle, that a taxpayer may raise. That is essentially the thrust of our amendment. It requires the Taxation Office to reply to the taxpayer if that taxpayer furnishes a query with the return, indicating that he or she is uncertain about a matter of law, fact or principle. We believe that at least this will go some of the way to placing some responsibility on the Commissioner of Taxation and his office for the smooth introduction of self-assessment. The taxpayer, under this amendment, could reasonably expect to receive in due course an answer to his or her queries and would not have to wait for three years to be certain that the tax return, as filled in, was correct.

It is important to state that the Commissioner cannot be expected to give a ruling on a taxpayer's return. The principle currently used is that any problems, inaccuracies or attempts to defraud the Commissioner must be assessed on a case by case basis and it would be impossible to expect the Commissioner to rule on a query that a taxpayer could raise with his or her return each year. However, matters of principle certainly can be commented on and this amendment will put the responsibility on the Commissioner to do just that. I trust that all honourable senators will support this amendment. It will ensure that all taxpayers are afforded human justice by the Australian Taxation Office and that is the least that we can expect. This legislation is a move to update a procedure which is outmoded and therefore the Australian Democrats believe that self-assessment, which is practised in many Western countries, including the United States, is a very important step in the right direction. It will help to bring efficiency to the Taxation Office and it will free officers to carry out the important investigatory work into fraud which has so often occurred in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to get the issues clear at the outset in this debate. Firstly, the Opposition has no concern about the general principle of implementing a scheme of self-assessment followed by audit of taxpayers. I believe that that could help very greatly in assisting the efficiency of the Australian Taxation Office in the processing of returns. However, we must acknowledge that, as a result of even the present methods of audit of taxpayers, there is very considerable concern in the community about the way in which the Commissioner of Taxation undertakes that work. There are great concerns about the way in which there appears to be a very formal, computer-driven control of events that follow taxpayers' audits, really extending the power of the Commissioner very greatly. One wonders whether the rights of taxpayers are not being unduly infringed in several circumstances. I recall a recent letter from a constituent who evidenced that he had received no fewer than four summonses issued for the lodgment of a taxation return. Each time the summons arrived he replied that the return had been properly lodged and that there were no problems with it, but still the summonses kept coming. There appears to be no way of shutting off the bureaucratic machine once it cranks up and gets into action. That kind of thing engenders a great deal of concern in the community and, more than that, creates an atmosphere of bad relations between taxpayers and the bureaucracy which controls the Australian Taxation Office.

SPEECH.PARA: If anything can be done to improve that situation and build up a better relationship between the public generally and the Taxation Office, I am for it. However, it seems to me that now the Government is moving towards self-assessment, it is important that it carries the taxpayers with it so that they have a thorough understanding of what the Government is on about. It is important that at the outset the guidelines for the Government's investigation of people's affairs should be properly laid down so that people understand what can happen to them. It is important-and I am sure the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) would agree-that that kind of understanding should build respect for the tax system, but I am bound to say that at present there is clear evidence in the community of growing disrespect for it. I would hate to think that a brand new initiative, such as the self-assessment system, which has considerable merit, could lead to an increase in the degree of disrespect for the Taxation Office. In my opinion that disrespect is growing very rapidly at present. For that reason the Opposition has adopted what I believe to be the right position. We intend to move for the referral of the relevant clauses of the Bill, which I will come to in a moment, to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations so that there can be a proper examination of the self-assessment idea. Taxation Office officials can come before that Committee and give evidence and demonstrate publicly what the new system will be, how it will work and how people and their rights will be affected. I believe that is a reasonable proposition at this time when there is such concern in the community.

I will return to the question of assessment issues in a moment. I wish to address the points raised by Senator Siddons in his amendment which seeks to have statements given by the Commissioner of Taxation which somehow appear to be rulings in favour of particular taxpayers when those taxpayers seek them. I am afraid that this amendment is totally without merit in that it has absolutely no binding powers upon the Commissioner to provide information and clearly does not in any way assist the situation. For that reason we cannot support the Democrats in this move because we believe it will provide the taxpayer with nothing. It will give him no protection and nothing upon which he can base his decisions on future actions. Indeed, I go as far as to say that what the Democrats are proposing is nothing more or less than what the Commissioner already does in practice. He sometimes gives rulings in advance to taxpayers on what might be the outcome in a certain situation, but he then enters the caveat that that ruling is not binding upon him and that he has the right to change his view when he comes at some later time to finally assessing the proposition that is put forward in that income tax return. I believe that the Democrats are really trying to kid us, if they are not kidding themselves, with this amendment. There certainly is no merit in the proposal at all, as I see it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 20 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill is the crux of our problem with the Government's legislation. It is rather a shame that we are not debating this Bill cognately with a piece of legislation to be debated later on, the transfer of jurisdiction of taxation boards of review from within the Australian Taxation Office to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I say that because the number of issues before us-the introduction of a new system of assessment of taxpayers together with the new regime of penalties, the change to the way in which the Commissioner of Taxation can alter the assessments of taxpayers virtually at will and, of course, the change to the situation of the boards of review which undoubtedly could occur as a result of the transfer of their jurisdiction to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal-all represent a major change. I do not believe and the Opposition does not believe that there has been sufficient discussion in the community on the intentions of the Government and on how we might develop a sound and solid system for the future.

SPEECH.PARA: We start from the proposition that we are not talking about just one particular part of this Bill but rather that forces are at work which undoubtedly will seriously and fundamentally change the way in which taxpayers will be assessed in the future. I believe that gives even more force to the Opposition argument that it should move to have this whole area opened up for public debate. Consequently, at a later stage, we will move that the clauses in connection with the amendment of assessments be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.

I turn to clause 20 and our concerns in that regard. As the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) probably knows, the system that presently operates provides for the Commissioner to change the assessments of taxpayers within certain bounds and certain time limits. Basically, all that can happen is that the Commissioner has the power to amend assessments for reasons connected with the correction of errors and mistakes of law and fact. Now we find provided in this clause new powers for the Commissioner to amend an assessment for any reason which could include the correction of an error of law. Again, considerable disquiet has been expressed in the community about this provision, because the proposed extension of the powers of the Commissioner is really quite great. Most of the criticism concerns the lack of certainty that will result from a taxpayer not knowing his final tax liability, even if a full and true disclosure has been made by that taxpayer in his income tax return. Until now, a fundamental aspect of our assessment procedure has been that if a full and true disclosure has been made by a taxpayer, no amendment to increase the liability can be made to reflect a changed interpretation of the law but as I mentioned earlier, an amendment can be made only to correct an error of calculation or a mistake of fact.

It seems that these amendments will now empower the Commissioner to amend assessments to increase one's tax liability due to a change in the interpretation of the law. If an assessment were issued by the Commissioner, say, three years ago on the basis of the law in force at that time and subsequently, a change in the law is brought about as a result of a decision of a court, that new law could be applied to the earlier assessment and, consequently, that assessment could be reopened and a new one issued on the basis of that new law. We have considerable concerns about the effect of that proposal. The Liberal and National parties believe that, apart from anything else, that proposal should be subject to the wider examination of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.

We can understand how, from the Government's standpoint, that principle might be thought to be admirable in terms of the introduction of the new system of self-assessment and of audit. I believe that the problem is that we do not know how far it will extend, what will be the bounds of this new power for the Commissioner and, indeed, how he intends to administer it. When members of the public get to know just how powerful the Taxation Commissioner will be as a result of this law being enacted, they will become very concerned. As a result, we believe that the appropriate action which the Parliament ought to take at the moment is to expose the issues, to receive public evidence on the matter, and that taxation officials should explain their position and give proper evidence to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. As such, at some later stage, we will move that that matter be referred to the Senate Committee for inquiry and report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I heard Senator Messner when he first spoke on the Bill, but I think he was complaining about the Government's haste. I do not know whether he was talking about policy or the Bill, but I think the term he used was that it had been sprung on fairly quickly. It is true that the Bill may not have been available for a very long time. The policy was announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the Budget statement last year.

SPEECH.PARA: The only purpose of clause 20, about which Senator Messner spoke more recently, is to enable the Commissioner of Taxation to correct errors of law as well as errors of fact. I am told that precisely the same provisions are to be found in the taxation Acts of other countries which practice self-assessment-countries such as the United States of America, the United Kingdom, New Zealand and Canada.

It seems to have been overlooked by Senator Messner that the corrections can be made in both directions. The tone of his remarks was to the effect that corrections would be made only to the disadvantage of the taxpayer. On the question of changes to the interpretation of the law that may have been made in the second or third year of the three-year period, the policy of the Commissioner of Taxation will be not to amend assessments as a result of a change in the interpretation of the law. Where an assessment is made on the basis of the interpretation of the law existing at the time of lodgment of the return, an assessment will not be amended to increase a taxpayer's liability because of the changed interpretation of the law. It is the Commissioner's intention to issue a taxation ruling on this matter upon the Bill becoming law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Turning to clause 21 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill I want to draw attention to the fact that, where interest is to be paid by the taxpayer where there has been an amended assessment, that interest will not be tax deductible. In that way, the taxpayer will not be able to get the benefit of a tax deduction for it. But in the opposite situation, where the Commissioner of Taxation will be paying interest to the taxpayer, that interest becomes taxable. It seems to me to be incongruous, unfair and unjust that it works in the Government's favour both ways. Surely it would be reasonable to allow the tax-payer a tax deduction for interest paid to the Taxation Commissioner where, in the reverse situation, it is assessable to the taxpayer. I would just like some explanation from the Government as to why it has drawn the legislation in that fashion. It certainly seems to me to be an unfair part of this legislation and it gives even more force to our argument that the Bill should be stood over for examination by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.

—There are a number of reasons for that provision for non-deductibility of an interest payment being in the legislation. I do not think Senator Messner mentioned that it is not a penalty interest payment; it is related to the bond rate. I am informed that the intention is to maintain that relationship between the bond rate and the interest rate and that it can be changed by regulation. It would not require a subsequent amendment to the Act. But among other reasons, to allow deductibility in this instance would open up the question of deductibility of the penalty interest rates which are charged for inaccurate information, or evasion, I suppose. I do not place that much store on that. Given that whether an error is detected with a self-assessment system has elements of a lottery in it because the audit rate, if I remember correctly, even when the system is fully established, will only be about three per cent, and there would be an incentive for taxpayers to take their chances of not having the error picked up and, therefore, being able to claim a tax deduction for something which they otherwise would not be able to claim a tax deduction-
—That is, 3 per cent are audited every year.
—I will take some further advice on that. As I understand it, that 3 per cent will be thoroughly checked at the time they are received.
—Can the Minister confirm that it is 3 per cent?
—I am told that it is 2 per cent.

—I would like then to refer quickly to clause 11 which deals with the negative gearing aspects of this legislation. We had very considerable debate on the negative gearing aspects during the second reading debate. There is just one little point on which I would like the Minister's clarification. In the amendment to the Bill, which provides for a proposed new section 82KZC, sub-section (6), we speak of the net rental value of properties where those properties are owned by companies. As I understand it, the new law will provide that the net rental of the property must bear no more than a 75 per cent ratio to the net value of the company. The point I would like to make here is that we all know how difficult it is to assess the net value of a property or the net value of a company's assets. The difficulty that I see arising is how the Government will administer this when there are likely to be fluctuations in the value of the assets of the company. I think of the situation where good will could move up or down in a matter of days depending upon the fortunes of the company, or some legal action, or some subcutaneous occurrence which affects the welfare of the company. All kinds of factors could apply which would make it extra- ordinarily difficult for a company to be able to establish that it is within the law one day and outside the law another day. Consequently, I would appreciate very much the Minister's comments on that matter as I believe that it is a very real practical difficulty for those companies that are engaging in quite legitimate project development operations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer Senator Messner to an answer at the bottom of page 4 of the Bill where `net worth' is defined as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: `net worth', in relation to a company, partnership or trust estate, means the total value of the assets of the company, partnership or trust estate, as reduced by the total liabilities of the company, partnership or trust estate;
That is such as the assets, minus the liabilities, as I would expect them to appear on the balance sheet.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is saying that the balance sheet figures at any time are the point of reference at which the ratio is determined. I would like to know at what point of time that balance sheet is established because within a year of income there would be fluctuations in those assets depending upon the circumstances of the company.

—I am told that it is not necessarily a balance sheet figure; it may be the balance sheet figure, because there may or may not have been a revaluation of assets incorporated in the balance sheet. But it is the question of fact of what are the current assets less liabilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In other words, the Minister is confirming that an up to date valuation is required.
—Yes.

—Perhaps the point can be easily illustrated as follows: Let us assume that a company has shares in other companies that are listed on the stock exchange. Every day, no doubt, the value of its assets will be fluctuating according to the value of the shares which it holds which are listed on the stock market. As a result, the ratio which we are seeking to keep within-the 75 per cent level-could vary a great deal. But the Minister has answered the point that the taxpayer will be put to some considerable disadvantage as a result.
