TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speeches in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (FOREIGN TAX CREDITS) BILL 1986

This Bill will give effect to the proposal announced in the Treasurer's 19 September 1985 tax reform statement to replace the present double taxation relief arrangements of the income tax law with a general foreign tax credit system.
Since that statement, detailed consideration has been given to the most appropriate arrangements for a foreign tax credit system in Australia.
In this process, the Government has considered representations from many sources, and held discussions with interested business groups.

In the light of these further deliberations, the details of the system that I will shortly describe differ in some respects from those outlined in the September statement. These differences generally tend to lessen the tax impact of the proposal on Australian residents.

However, the information gained in this process has confirmed the Government's view that the present manner of treating foreign source income of Australian residents is not consistent with the general equity, neutrality and efficiency objectives of a sound taxation system.
As well, the present treatment encourages Australians to avoid tax by arranging to give their income an artificial overseas source.
The Asprey Committee, in 1975, recommended the introduction of a foreign tax credit system in the interests of equity and efficiency.
In 1978 the previous Government announced that it would introduce such a system but in the face of criticism from certain quarters, the measure was abandoned.

Such criticism overlooks the fact that foreign tax credit systems are common in developed countries-American, West German and Japanese firms, amongst others, have extensive overseas operations despite being subject to such systems in their home countries.
The direct gain to revenue from this measure is estimated at about $60 million per annum at 1985-86 levels of income, with the first revenue gains accruing in 1988-89.

In the longer run, however, the revenue gains could be substantially greater if followed up with initiatives against offshore tax avoidance activities which would be based on the foreign tax credit system framework.
I turn now to the details of this measure.
The new system will first apply to assessments in respect of the year of income commencing on 1 July 1987.

Under it, all foreign source income derived by Australian resident taxpayers-apart from certain salary and wages that I will mention shortly-will be subject to Australian tax, and a credit will be allowed against that tax for analogous foreign tax paid on that income.
Except for certain interest income derived overseas, foreign source income will be assessed on a worldwide basis.
This approach will enable excess foreign tax credits from high-tax countries to be offset against Australian tax on income from low-tax countries.

Foreign tax on the foreign income of an Australian company will be creditable against its Australian company tax on that income, but not against compensatory tax that will be payable as part of the proposed imputation arrangements.
Credits for foreign tax will be set against company tax before compensatory tax offsets company tax.

An Australian company receiving dividends from subsidiaries overseas will be allowed credit for underlying foreign company tax on the profits from which the dividends are paid, as well as for any foreign withholding or other tax imposed on the dividends.

The credit for underlying tax will be allowed for unlimited tiers of subsidiary companies provided that each company in the chain has a 10 per cent controlling interest in the company immediately below it, and the Australian parent has a direct or indirect interest of at least 5 per cent in the voting shares of each company.
As part of this mechanism, dividends received by an Australian parent from an overseas subsidiary will be treated as being first paid out of a pool of the subsidiary's accumulated profits.

This pooling approach, which is of an anti-avoidance nature, will apply on a prospective basis, and any dividends in excess of the pool will be treated as paid out of the subsidiary's profits of earlier years on a last-in-first-out basis.

The measurement of income for overseas branches or other overseas business, commercial or investment activities of Australian taxpayers will be determined in accordance with Australian income tax law.
For subsidiaries, book profits as disclosed in the accounts of the company will be used, with scope for these to be adjusted where that is appropriate.
Overseas branches of Australian life insurance companies will be taxed, under the new system, only on income remitted to Australia and not on all branch profits.
The Bill contains currency exchange conversion rules that are to apply to convert various categories of foreign income to Australian dollars for Australian tax purposes.

Salary and wages earned overseas by an Australian resident and liable to tax in the country of source are to be fully exempt from Australian income tax where derived in performing service overseas for a continuous period of at least 12 months.
A proportionate exemption will apply where the period is from 3 to 12 months, with a credit being allowed for foreign tax paid on any amount not exempted.
These provisions will not affect persons working overseas on approved projects to whom a specific exemption in the present law will continue to apply.

However, the foreign earnings of such persons, as well as salary and wages earned overseas that is to be exempted on the basis I have just outlined, will be taken into account in calculating Australian tax on other income derived by a taxpayer, so that exemption of the foreign earnings will not also reduce the Australian tax payable on that other income.

In most cases, the taxation treatment of foreign pensions received by Australian residents is governed by the terms of an existing double taxation agreement, and this position will not be altered by the foreign tax credit system.
The new system will therefore apply only to foreign pension income in the limited number of cases where pensions are derived from non-treaty countries.
As an anti-avoidance measure, certain foreign source interest income is to be assessed separately from other income, with separate tax credit limits.

Because of arrangements that might be designed to avoid this interest quarantining, dividends received from foreign subsidiaries will under certain circumstances be traced to determine whether interest income has been recharacterised and remitted to Australia as dividends.
Where necessary, dividends will be apportioned into an interest income component and other income, with foreign tax credits being allowed separately on each component.
Interest earned in carrying on normal business activities and interest received by banks and other financial institutions will be excluded from the quarantining process.

Although the Government has decided not to treat other forms of passive income in a similar way to interest, the position will be monitored to see whether there is a need to widen the quarantining measures.

Under the Bill, losses incurred in any year in respect of an overseas branch operation or other particular business, commercial or investment activity will not be offset against domestic income in the same year, nor against other foreign source income, but will be available for offset against profits derived in any of the seven succeeding years from the same branch or activity.
Taxpayers will have the option to carry-forward domestic losses for offset against later domestic income as at present or to offset them against foreign income.

Excess foreign tax credits will not be able to be carried forward or back, but will be transferable within wholly owned company groups for set-off against Australian tax payable on other non-interest foreign income derived by another group company in the same year of income.
The Bill also contains measures to recognise selected taxation incentives of a developing country.

In the absence of special measures-called tax sparing relief-a foreign tax credit system can negate incentives in the form of tax holidays or tax reductions offered by developing countries to encourage foreign investment to assist in the development of those countries.
Tax sparing relief is traditionally granted in the context of a comprehensive agreement for the avoidance of double taxation between the two countries concerned.
Australia has followed this approach, but the Bill will also enable tax sparing to be granted on a country by country basis by regulations made for that purpose.

Where tax sparing is granted in respect of income from a particular country, either by way of regulation or under the terms of a comprehensive taxation agreement, the tax forgone by the foreign country under the relevant taxation incentive measure will be deemed to have been paid by the Australian taxpayer before arriving at the income received.
The taxpayer will therefore be entitled to a credit for the foreign tax forgone in respect of the relevant foreign income.
Finally, in giving effect to the general foreign tax credit system, it is also necessary to remove from the income tax law those double taxation relief provisions that the new system will replace.

To this end, the Bill will repeal the existing foreign tax credit provisions that apply to foreign dividends received by individuals, to most classes of income derived from Papua New Guinea, and to foreign source interest and royalties subject to limited tax rates under Australia's comprehensive tax treaties.

It will also repeal existing provisions that exempt from Australian tax various categories of foreign income that will become subject to the new system. For the same reason the Bill will withdraw, in relation to foreign source dividends, the rebate provided by section 46 of the Income Tax Assessment Act that now effectively exempts such dividends from Australian tax.
An issue that the Government has under notice in the light of representations is whether to extend the capital expenditure deductions for mining companies to such expenditures on overseas projects.
A decision will be announced as soon as practicable.
A technical explanation of the provisions of this Bill is contained in an explanatory memorandum being made available to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986
This Bill will amend the income tax law in two major respects. It also contains several other amendments of the taxation laws.
The principal measures to which it will give effect are the proposals announced by the Treasurer in December 1984.
The first of these was to tax each year the income accruing to resident taxpayers from discounted, deferred interest and capital indexed securities.
The other was to strengthen the interest withholding tax provisions in relation to such securities held by non-residents, and other non-traditional financing arrangements.
The Bill will also exempt from tax certain allowances paid to recipients of the new Commonwealth Formal Training Allowance.
A technical defect in the rebate provisions of the income tax law that apply to certain employment termination payments is to be corrected.

The Income Tax Secrecy Provisions are to be amended to enable information concerning superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and similar funds to be conveyed to persons who may be responsible for supervision of the superannuation industry.
And finally, the Bill will amend the Income Tax Gift Provisions and make a number of purely technical amendments relevant to the recent changes to the Repatriation Laws.
I turn now to discuss in more detail the measures contained in the Bill.
Discounted and other Deferred Interest Securities

In December 1984 the Treasurer announced the Government's decision to adopt a new method of taxing income accruing on certain non-traditional securities on which some or all of the income yield is accumulated and paid only at maturity.
The gain to an investor from holding such securities is income that is akin to interest, and is taxed under the present income tax law only on redemption of prior sale of the instruments.

That deferral of tax gives rise to effects on budgetary revenue and advantages investors in those securities by comparison with investors in traditional securities having the same nominal before-tax yield.

These revenue and market effects are undesirable, and the income tax law is to be changed to correct that situation by taxing the overall yield on non-transitional securities on a basis broadly comparable to the way in which income derived from traditional securities is taxed.
Amendments contained in this Bill will ensure that income that is compounded or accrued in each year from a discounted or other deferred interest security will be taxed in that year to the investor.
This accruals basis of assessment will apply to the holder of an affected security whether it was acquired on issue or by purchase in the secondary market.

A gain arising from the sale of an affected security for more than its accrued value will be included as assessable income of the vendor, while a loss on sale will be an allowable deduction. With certain exceptions the securities to which these particular measures will apply include original issue discount securities, interest-at-maturity securities, and securities (such as Dingo Bonds) which separately market the entitlements to principal and interest on underlying securities.

However, such securities will only be subject to these measures if they were originally issued after 16 December 1984 with a term exceeding one year and where, at the time of issue, the deferred yield on the security can be ascertained and, for each year in the term of the security, exceeds 1.5 per cent of the redemption price.

Securities of the indexed capital type or those where the yield to redemption cannot be determined on issue will be subject to other measures contained in this Bill, provided they were also issued after 16 December 1984 for a term exceeding one year.

In these cases, the assessable income of the investor in any year will include the actual increase, by indexation or otherwise, in the accrued value of the security during the year, as well as any interest actually derived during that year.

Where these kinds of affected securities are also issued or purchased at a discount, the discount will be included in the holder's assessable income in a straight-line basis over the period the security is held.
This will be based on the term, or the remaining term, as the case may be, of the security.
If such a security is purchased on the secondary market at a premium over its accrued value, the premium is to be allowed as a deduction on the same basis.
The accruals basis of assessment will not apply to relevant securities held by non-residents or forming part of a taxpayer's trading stock.

Subject to certain exceptions, issuers of affected securities will be allowed deductions each year for the discount or other interest component calculated on a basis similar to the assessable income of the investor.
The exceptions, which are of an anti-avoidance and revenue protection nature, are securities issued after 22 May 1986 offshore or payable to bearer.
Deductions in those cases will continue to be allowed in the year in which the discount or deferred interest is actually paid.
By bringing forward the taxing point of income on these securities, the arrangements I have outlined will redress the tax deferral advantages of such securities.
This will result in some unquantifiable gains to revenue.
Interest Withholding Tax
I turn now to the proposal also announced by the Treasurer in December 1984 to strengthen the interest withholding tax provisions of the income tax law.
In recent years, there has been a move away from the more conventional means by which overseas finance is provided.
This has been with the aim of avoiding the non-resident lender's liability to Australian withholding tax.
Some of the arrangements involve the use of discounted and other deferred interest securities, including capital-indexed securities of the kind I have just spoken about.

A typical arrangement involves securities which, instead of being held by a non-resident until redemption-at which time withholding tax would apply to the payment of the discount or deferred interest-are sold to a resident just prior to maturity.

This means that, while the resident purchaser is usually liable to tax on the excess of the redemption price over the purchase price, the balance of the discount, which effectively passes to the non-resident as part of the proceeds from the sale of the security, is not subject to withholding tax. Further, the arrangements are often structured so that the profit has an ex-Australian source.
In these cases the profit derived by the non-resident cannot be taxed by assessment.
The proposed amendments will overcome this avoidance technique by ensuring that the tax will apply to the difference between the sale price of the security and its issue price.

Where a non-resident vendor has purchased such a security from a resident of Australia, the Bill provides that the withholding tax liability may be adjusted to bear only on the difference between the sale proceeds and the purchase price.

This measure will apply to relevant debt obligations and securities issued after 16 December 1984 irrespective of their term but, subject to certain safeguards, will only affect payments made on or after the date the Bill becomes law.
Techniques that result in the avoidance of interest withholding tax include hire purchase and similar contracts, such as `terms purchase' and `lease with option to purchase' arrangements.
The charges under these arrangements have not, in the past, been classed as interest for withholding tax purposes, although they are, in reality, the reward for the provision of finance.
Again, because the arrangements do not enable an Australian source to be attributed to the charges, the non-resident `lender' is not subject to tax by assessment.

The Bill will amend the income tax law to bring hire purchase and similar charges-that is, the excess of total payments over the cost price of the goods-within the scope of the interest withholding tax provisions.

This amendment will also apply to contractual obligations entered into after 16 December 1984 but, again subject to appropriate safeguards, only in relation to relevant payments made on or after the amendment becomes law.
The Bill will also remove doubts that may exist about the application of the interest withholding tax provisions to certain payments made in relation to bank accepted bills of exchange.

It is not altogether clear whether withholding tax is payable on the discount element of a bank accepted bill where a resident indemnifies or reimburses a non-resident acceptor for the face value of the bill at maturity.
This is to be compared to the situation where, if the resident drawer of the bill had met the face value of the bill directly, withholding tax would clearly be payable on the discount.
The Bill will clarify this by specifying that withholding tax is to be payable on any amount or amounts that constitute the discount or interest factor under a bill of exchange.
Similar provisions are contained in the Bill in relation to promissory notes.
These provisions will only affect payments made in respect of bills of exchange and promissory notes drawn or issued after the amendments receive the royal assent.
These changes will prevent a continued loss of revenue of an unquantifiable amount.
Allowances for Job-seekers

On 19 December 1985, my colleagues, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs, announced the introduction, from 1 January 1986, of a new system of Commonwealth training allowance.

The new allowance, called a formal training allowance, has a single age-related structure and is consistent with the aim of the Government's priority one strategy in improving education and training opportunities for young people.
The formal training allowance includes a living component which is equivalent to the social security pension or benefit entitlement for which a trainee may otherwise have qualified.

Recipients of social security pensions or benefits who are paid allowances because they have a dependent child, live in a remote area or require rent assistance, are exempt from tax on those allowances.

So as not to disadvantage persons in receipt of the formal training allowance, an amendment proposed by the Bill will exempt from income tax those allowances that may be paid to trainees that correspond with the non-taxable allowances paid to social security pensioners or beneficiaries.
An associated amendment will ensure that taxable payments of trainees are subject to regular pay as you earn tax instalment deductions.
The estimated cost to revenue of this measure is $100,000 in 1986-87 and $200,000 in a full year.
Employment Termination Payments Rebate

The Bill will give effect to the proposal announced on 11 March 1986 to remove an unintended effect of the income tax rebate provisions that limit the rate of tax payable on certain payments made on termination of employment.
Those payments are lump sum superannuation and kindred payments that relate to service after 30 June 1983 and most lump sum payments in lieu of accrued annual leave and long service leave.
The rebate provisions limit the rate of tax on such payments to no more than 30%.
In the case of the first $55,000 of relevant lump sum superannuation and kindred payments made to a taxpayer aged 55 or more, the rate is limited to a maximum of 15%.

However, a technical defect means that the provisions may not always allow the full benefit of the rebate where some part of the payments is subject to tax at the lowest marginal rate of 26.67% for 1984-85 and 25% for 1985-86.
Amendments contained in the Bill, which will first apply for 1984-85, will correct that defect.
The amendments are not expected to have any significant effect on revenue.
Income Tax Secrecy Provisions

At present, because associated exemptions and deductions are dependent on compliance with various provisions of the income tax law, the Commissioner of Taxation is largely responsible for the regulation of superannuation and similar funds.

The suggestion is made from time to time that the non-revenue aspects of fund regulation should be the responsibility of someone other than the Commissioner and the Government has that possibility under consideration.
Any transfer of this responsibility would, of course, occur only after consultation with appropriate representatives of employer and business groups, the ACTU and the Superannuation Industry.
If it is decided to transfer responsibility, it is most likely to be given to the Department of the Treasury or to a new Supervisory Authority.
In either event, it is anticipated that any decision in that regard would be taken prior to the Budget sittings.

Therefore, this Bill-the last relevant Bill scheduled for passage during the current sitting of the Parliament-proposes the amendment of the Income Tax secrecy provisions to permit the Commissioner of Taxation to communicate information to either the Secretary to the Treasury or any new authority for the purposes of carrying out any transferred functions.
The proposed amendment will have no revenue impact.
Gifts
The gift provisions of the Income Tax law are being amended by the Bill to make gifts to the Pearl Watson Foundation tax deductible.

The Pearl Watson Foundation was established to commemorate the considerable contribution to the Australian community of Pearl Watson, the late wife of Mr Justice R. S. Watson of the Family Court of Australia.
As honourable senators will be aware, Mrs Watson died tragically in a bomb explosion at her home on 4 July 1984.
The Foundation promotes education and information programs in areas such as marital breakdown, family law, and marriage counselling and conciliation services.
Deductions will be allowable for gifts, the value of which is $2 or more, made after 22 May 1986.
The cost to revenue of this measure is estimated at less than $10,000 in a full financial year.
Finally, the Bill will make formal amendments of the Income Tax Assessment Act made necessary by changes contained in the recently enacted Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.
A comprehensive memorandum explaining in detail the measures that I have outlined is being made available to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX (SECURITIES AND AGREEMENTS) (WITHHOLDING TAX RECOUPMENT) BILL 1986
This Bill will formally declare and impose tax, at a rate equal to the amount of withholding tax avoided, in two particular situations.

The broad effect of one of the measures contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, about which I have just spoken, is to subject to withholding tax the profit derived by a non-resident from selling a qualifying security to a resident prior to its maturity.

As a safeguard against arrangements designed to avoid or minimise the effect of these provisions-for example, by the sale of a security for less than its market or arm's length price-the Commissioner of Taxation will be authorised to adjust the sale price of the security to the price at which it would have been transferred by persons dealing at arm's length.

As it will be not generally be possible to collect the withholding tax avoided in these kinds of arrangements from the non-resident, the tax imposed by this Bill will be payable by the resident transferee.

I also indicated in my earlier speech that, subject to appropriate safeguards, withholding tax would not be payable in relation to payments subject to the new measures made on or before the amending legislation becomes law.

Those safeguards are designed to prevent arrangements under which interest that would normally be payable on and after the date on which the legislation receives the royal assent is in effect prepaid before that date.

Where the Commissioner of Taxation ascertains that such prepayments have occurred for the sole or dominant purpose of reducing the withholding tax otherwise payable, the person who made the payment is to be liable to pay the amount of withholding tax sought to be avoided.
This Bill will also impose that amount of tax.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
TAXATION BOARDS OF REVIEW (TRANSFER OF JURISDICTION) BILL 1986
This Bill reflects in large measure the Government's response to recommendations made in a report by the Administrative Review Council entitled ``Review of Taxation Decisions by Boards of Review''.
It proposes that, with minor departures, the recommendations of the Administrative Review Council be adopted.

In accordance with the council's recommendation, the principal function of the Bill is to abolish the Taxation Boards of Review and transfer the present jurisdiction of the boards to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
The changeover is to take place on 1 July 1986.
The present avenue of appeal under some taxation laws to a Supreme Court will remain.

The Bill also contains amendments of the sales tax law to give further partial effect to the decision of the former Government, adopted by us on coming to office, to revise the objection and appeal provisions of that law.

Other provisions in the Bill will make further amendments of the objection and appeal provisions of the various laws administered by the Commissioner of Taxation with a view to achieving a degree of desirable uniformity.
Finally, the opportunity is being taken to repeal some Acts that are no longer operative.
Mr President, I turn now to the more important features of the Bill.
Taxation Boards of Review

In deciding to accept the Administrative Review Council's recommendation, the Government was concerned to ensure that the complex and exacting task of reviewing taxation decisions was undertaken by persons with a high level of expertise in, and specialist knowledge of, the taxation laws.
A notable feature of this Bill, therefore, is the creation, within the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, of a separate division to review taxation decisions.
This new division is to be known as the Taxation Appeals Division.
Members of the Tribunal will be assigned to the Taxation Appeals Division after consultation between the Treasurer and the Attorney-General.
The separate division will ensure that the review of taxation decisions is undertaken by tribunal members having knowledge and skill relevant to that function.

Those of the existing Taxation Board of review chairman and members who so wish are to be appointed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal as senior non- presidential members and assigned to the new Taxation Appeals Division.
Additional full-time and part-time members will be appointed as appropriate.

I emphasise that the high standards set by the taxation boards of review over the past 60 years and the informal review procedures of the boards will be maintained by the Taxation Appeals Division of the Tribunal.

Under the more flexible procedures of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, a tribunal may, however, be constituted by a single member, although a 3-member tribunal may also sit, as the occasion requires.
A substantial backlog of requests for review by the taxation boards of review has developed in recent years, primarily as a consequence of the tax avoidance boom of the mid-1970's and early 1980's.
The extra hearing capacity provided by these more flexible procedures should enable this backlog to be dealt with more quickly than would otherwise be the case.
There is to be some modification, in relation to taxation reviews, of existing administrative appeals tribunal procedures.

Requests to have decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will, as recommended by the Administrative Review Council, be sent in the first instance to the Commissioner who will refer them on to the Tribunal.
This procedure will enable decisions to be re-examined by the Commissioner before they are referred to the Tribunal for review.

Another departure from the usual practice of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will be that all taxation review proceedings are to be conducted in private, unless the taxpayer requests a public hearing.
This follows the existing practice of the Boards of Review and is consistent with the principle that the taxation affairs of people are matters that ought to be kept confidential.

Also in keeping with this principle, decisions of the Taxation Appeals Division of the Tribunal will, like decisions of the Taxation Boards of Review, be prepared so as to ensure that, on publication, the identity of the taxpayer concerned is not revealed.

As recommended by the Administrative Review Council, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act is to be modified so that taxpayers will not, in the first instance, be able to obtain from the Commissioner of Taxation statements of reasons for decisions disallowing objections.

However, at the time a matter is referred to the Tribunal, the Commissioner will provide to the Tribunal a statement of reasons for the disputed decision and the Tribunal would make available to the taxpayer a copy of those reasons.

As a resource saving measure and to assist in making inroads into the backlog, the documents and a statement along the lines of those presently made available to the Taxation Boards of Review will be provided until 30 June 1988.
After that date the more detailed reasons and documents required under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act will be provided to the Tribunal.

Under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act, the Attorney-General on behalf of the Commonwealth, or any other person whose interests are affected by the disputed decision, may intervene in a proceeding before the Tribunal.

The Bill will modify the operation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act so that, consistent with the principle of confidentiality in taxation matters, the taxpayer concerned will have to consent to the joining of outside parties-other than the Attorney-General-in proceedings before the Taxation Appeals Division of the Tribunal.

While the right of the Attorney-General to intervene will extend to Taxation Review proceedings, I make it clear that it is the Government's intention that such intervention would occur only where an important question of public interest not concerning an interpretation of the taxation law is involved or where the interpretation of the provisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act is an issue.
Matters relevant to intervention by the Attorney-General could be dealt with separately to the review of the disputed decision.

In keeping with long-standing provisions of the taxation law, neither the Administrative Appeals Tribunal nor the Federal court will have power to prevent or restrain the collection and recovery of tax where an objection decision is subject to review by the tribunal.
All modifications of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act in respect of taxation review proceedings are to be enacted in a new part of the Taxation Administration Act.
Subject to transitional arrangements mentioned later, appeals from an Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision on a question of law will be to the Federal Court.
The Government has also decided to extend the appeal rights of taxpayers in certain respects.
The Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Supreme Court are to be given a discretion to permit a taxpayer to widen the grounds of objection in appropriate cases.
In addition, the Commissioner of Taxation will be permitted to extend the time in which an objection may be lodged.
A refusal by the Commissioner to grant an extension of time will be reviewable by the administrative appeals tribunal.

Consistent with allowing extensions of time for lodgment of objections, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Supreme courts are also to be given authority to grant an extension of time in which a taxpayer can request the Commissioner of Taxation to refer an objection decision to those bodies.
Transitional Arrangements
Transitional provisions will apply to requests for reference to a taxation board of review that are awaiting referral by the Commissioner of Taxation at 1 July 1986.
Special rules will also apply to references at the boards awaiting hearing or decision.
Requests that have not, at the changeover date, been transmitted to a board of review will be treated as requests for review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
These will be referred to that tribunal by the Commissioner.
Cases with a board of review at the changeover date where a hearing has not commenced, will be treated as being with the tribunal.
These will be reviewed by the Taxation Appeals Division of the Tribunal under the new arrangements.
In these situations an appeal from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will, in accordance with the procedure under its enabling act, be available to the Federal Court on a question of law.

Where, at the changeover date, a board of review has commenced,or completed, a hearing but no decision has been given, the continuation of the hearing or the decision will, where practicable, be by the Tribunal constituted by one or more of the former members of that board of review.
This will be deemed to be a proceeding by, or decision of, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
Such cases will be appealable to the Federal Court where a question of law is involved in the decision.
This means that the appeal may be by way of a fresh hearing before that court.
The $2 fee presently payable by a taxpayer before a reference or appeal is forwarded to a Taxation Board of Review or a Supreme Court is to be abolished.
Fees paid in all cases undecided at the changeover date are to be refunded.

The transfer of tax jurisdiction to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will have no direct revenue consequences although, to the extent that the Tribunal is able to reduce the backlog of review requests, there could be some earlier settlement of taxation debts.
Sales Tax

The opportunity is being taken by this Bill to give further partial effect to the decision of the former Government-adopted by us on assuming office-to revise the sales tax objection and appeal provisions.
Amendments in the Bill will bring the objection and appeal provisions of the sales tax law into line with the comparable income tax provisions.
Sales taxpayers will have a right of objection and review in all cases where a liability for sales tax exists.

In particular, they will from 1 July 1986 have the option of having decisions on the classification of goods and the refund of tax reviewed by either an administrative tribunal or a Supreme Court, instead of resorting to the unwieldly and inappropriate procedure of defending a recovery action before a court.
Objections, Reviews and Appeals

By this Bill, further amendments are to be made to the objection and appeal provisions of the various taxation laws administered by the Commissioner of Taxation to correct some deficiencies and achieve a degree of uniformity.
Under the various taxation laws the right of objection against an amended assessment is intended to be limited to matters connected with the particular item that is the subject of the amendment.

The Federal Court of Australia has decided, however, that the relevant provision of the income tax law imposes a monetary, but not a subject matter, limit on an objection against an amended assessment.
This decision could apply to the detriment of the revenue in some circumstances.
It may also unfairly restrict a taxpayer's right of objection in other cases.
Amendments proposed by this Bill are designed to restore the law to its intended effect.
As a result of amendments enacted in 1984, most taxation laws provide for an assessment of additional penalty tax payable by a taxpayer.

To simplify the objection and appeal procedure, assessments of additional tax and ordinary tax incorporated on the same assessment notice are to be treated as one for the purposes of the objection and appeal provisions.
Only a single objection or request for review will need to be made to cover the entire tax liability.

Under its newly acquired jurisdiction to review taxation decisions, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will have the power to affirm, vary or set aside decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation on objections.
Further amendments being made by this Bill will make it clear that the Supreme Courts will likewise only be authorised to make orders in relation to objection decisions.
The Commission will be required to give effect to decisions of the Tribunal or a court within 60 days after they become final.

To bring the objection provisions into line with provisions relating to requests for review of appeal, other provisions of the Bill will provide that objections must be lodged with, and not merely posted to, the Commissioner of Taxation within the specified time limit.

This time limit, which as earlier mentioned will be capable of enlargement, will be uniformly extended so that a limit of 60 days applies to both objections and applications for review or appeal under all taxation laws.

Other amendments will enable persons who have requested reference of an objection decision to the Tribunal or a Supreme Court to give notice to the Commissioner to refer the matter to the tribunal or court within 60 days.
This will bring all taxation laws into line with a comparable provision in the income tax law.
Redundant Acts
Finally, several taxation laws that the Commissioner of Taxation administered and which are no longer operative are to be repealed.
An explanatory memorandum comprehensively explaining the features of this Bill is being circulated for the information of honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like, firstly, to deal with several matters before coming to the foreign tax credits system which is the main part of this group of allied Bills. I draw the Senate's attention to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986 and, in particular, to clause 4 of that Bill. The Opposition has no general problem with other parts of the Bill. However, we do have major objection to clause 4 and we will be opposing that clause in the Committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill appears to open up a new procedure within the Australian Taxation Office which deserves some very considerable comment. As all honourable senators would know, there are very stringent secrecy provisions which bind the Commissioner of Taxation from revealing information about the affairs of taxpayers to any person or any government agency except for those which are specified in section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Clause 4 provides that there will be a provision of information by the Taxation Commissioner to the Secretary to the Department of the Treasury for certain purposes. The purposes are referred to as being those in connection with the supervision or regulation of provident, benefit, superannuation or retirement funds.

The point that is concerning the Opposition in this regard is quite obvious. First, there is a breach of the well-accepted principles of secrecy when it comes to the affairs of taxpayers. Secondly, there is a provision that the information, otherwise secret, can be made available to the Secretary to the Treasury in respect of the supervision and regulation of superannuation funds when we have no idea what the nature of that regulatory machinery might be. This brings us back to the arguments in the community now about the establishment of superannuation funds right across the community. We recall the recent debates about the union-based superannuation funds and their extension into the community. In fact, as I understand it, this is a matter which is before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission at this very time, with there likely to be a decision, known as a productivity grant, in favour of the establishment of superannuation funds. The point is that the opening up of this secrecy power seems to us to deserve further consideration by the Parliament, because quite simply the Government has not told us who finally will have access to the information. Clearly, if the Government is going to provide for some new supervisory or regulatory machinery for superannuation funds, I for one-and the Opposition supports this view-would not be prepared to open up the powers of the Taxation Commissioner to breach the long-standing principle of secrecy without knowing what that machinery is going to be. It seems quite clear that in the present climate, in which superannuation funds are likely to be subject to pressure from the trade union movement, and as superannuation, on union-based principles, gains momentum, there will no doubt be very considerable pressure on government agencies to provide information from the various superannuation funds currently lodging taxation returns with the Taxation Office.

If a regulatory authority is established, as no doubt it might be, with representative membership of the top body-for want of a better phrase, the board of directors-combining the interests of people from the trade union movement, from employer groups and so on, those people may have access to the secret information of superannuation funds. I think that that would be a matter for great concern. Consequently, we in the Opposition will be opposing that clause until we have a better picture from the Government as to what it intends to do about the establishment of a proper regulatory agency for the supervision of superannuation funds.

The next Bill I would like to mention is the Income Tax (Securities and Agreements) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1986. We have no particular objection to that piece of legislation. I turn now to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill 1986 and indicate immediately that the Opposition will be opposing the legislation at all stages, as announced on 12 November 1985. The proposed foreign tax credits system seeks to tax in Australian residents' hands all income which has a foreign source. That income is to be taxed at Australian rates. The object of the legislation is to allow credits for the tax paid in respect of that foreign sourced income in the country of its origin. When initially announced in September last year, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that indeed the credits that would be allowed to companies in that situation would be allowed only on a country by country basis rather than on a worldwide basis. Obviously this would have considerable impacts as no doubt there would be variations in treatment between various countries and Australia. I compare low company tax countries such as Singapore or Hong Kong, with company tax rates of 18 per cent, with very high company tax rate countries such as those in Western Europe. The difference of treatment might mean that companies would not be able to offset surpluses that were not taken up against Australian taxes against deficits from other countries in similar situations. As a consequence, there was some very considerable objection on the part of business to that concept of operating a foreign tax credits system. It is pleasing to see, notwithstanding that we oppose this measure, that the Government has changed the system so as to allow for a worldwide taxation system to apply.

Turning to our arguments against this system in principle, I believe that probably one major argument goes to the core of our concern. It is pretty clear that Australia's economy is in very considerable retreat. This is notwithstanding the long period over which the Government has been claiming the reverse. In fact, it has been claiming over many months that the economy has been getting better and better and that jobs are being created. We find now that indeed we are looking down the barrel and seeing considerable problems ahead.

It seems to me to be quite reasonable that if we are, as we should be, seeking to develop alternative markets for Australian products, we should be looking to those areas of the world near to us in which to develop those markets. Quite clearly we are thinking of the Pacific region and South East Asia. Clearly that is the area we should be developing our relationships with and seeking to do more business with. Many Australian companies already have done that and, in fact, have established branches and/or subsidiaries which are operating, for example, in the Philippines, Korea, Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, and so on. Obviously, seeking to extend the expertise of Australian businessmen and Australian investors to develop Australian interest in those areas and to earn profits which can be repatriated to Australia is a worthwhile objective.

Of course, many of those countries are low tax countries by the standards of Australia. Indeed, many of them in fact are the sorts of countries which provide enormous opportunities for the future development of Australian companies. That surely is a way not only of developing Australia's foreign image abroad, which is very important in terms of Australia's role in this area of the world, but also of providing a hedging, if you like, by giving Australian companies the opportunity of earning alternative profits and not having to rely on the very small domestic market of 16 million people in Australia. We have access to markets which represent literally hundreds of millions of people in these areas and which are developing rapidly both in affluence and in their capacity to develop technology. Surely that offers tremendous opportunities for Australian companies. We can see the foreign tax credit system, as the Government proposes, working against the interest of those companies seeking to establish themselves overseas.

Taxing all foreign-sourced income at Australian rates will mean that the tax rate will rise for Australian companies operating overseas. This will be a permanent and very destructive disincentive for people and companies to invest overseas. The obvious answer to many Australian companies will be to say: `We have the Australian market of 16 million people, but we have markets of billions of people nearby. Maybe a better answer is that we pack up and establish ourselves overseas altogether and pay tax at the local rates which apply in countries such as the Philippines and Thailand, and in that way avoid the impact of the Australian higher rate of company tax'. That is likely to occur as a result of the introduction of this legislation. Consequently, we can see that this will not only be a major destructive incentive but also it will be very destructive of Australian industry generally.

It could happen that companies, which are operating both in Australia and overseas, will decide to hold profits offshore instead of repatriating profits which would otherwise come to Australia. As a result, those profits will not find their way back into Australia and become the bases of further investment and support for activities in other parts of the world but not in Australia. That sounds like quite a silly proposition when we are seeking to develop the Australian economy to the degree that we are, or need to do, at this time.

By introducing a system such as this, the Government thinks that we will somehow overcome the problems of some companies perhaps less scrupulous than others which seek to utilise the so-called tax havens operating in some parts of the world. That seems to me-if that is an intention-to be totally ineffective because it will be in the interests of those companies which choose to do that type of thing to make sure that the Australian taxation authorities do not become aware of that kind of operation. Consequently, we will never know of those profits which are being stored offshore in foreign tax havens. This will be ineffective in bringing down that aspect of tax avoidance which could be a very large area in the operation of Australian companies.

The major point has to be made: Australia is still very much a country dependent upon the import of capital and we should be encouraging companies which are seeking to hedge their bets by spreading their markets broader than just in Australia to repatriate their profits so as to make sure that there is an even flow of capital back to Australia. This tax measure will have the opposite effect: Companies will have a positive incentive to go offshore, instead of developing alternatives overseas and repatriating those profits. It is hard to see that that is a very sound measure in today's world. The Opposition does not believe that this is a reasonable proposition, and consequently we will be opposing the matter at all stages during the debate in the Senate.

I turn now to the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill 1986. We have considerable doubts about the changes we were discussing a moment ago in connection with the assessment procedures for taxpayers as announced by the Taxation Commissioner. I mentioned that it is a pity that we could not, at that stage, have debated those assessment changes with the changes which are now being proposed for the transfer of the boards of review of taxpayers' appeals, which currently operate within the Australian Taxation Office, to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. We see a need to improve the performance of the boards of review in the Taxation Office because obviously a considerable backlog of cases is clogging up the system at the moment. I am told that at present there are something like 90,000 outstanding cases in the boards of review. This would mean that it would take some years before those cases could all be heard. Consequently, there will be very significant delays in people receiving justice.

We welcome some of the proposals which are incorporated in this legislation and believe they are good steps towards the improvement of the operation of the appeals system. For instance, the establishment of single member tribunals must speed up the work rather than having to rely on tribunals of three to hear cases which is the present system. Other streamlining methods being undertaken will also assist in speeding up the process of handling the backlog of cases. We have no objection to that at all. Our concerns are in more general terms and are related to how the new boards of review will work within the framework of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. All of us know that that has very considerable jurisdiction across the gamut of the Repatriation Appeals Tribunal, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and many other matters affecting government administration. The addition of new tribunals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which will arise from the transfer of boards of review will add significantly to the problems of administration of the AAT. We are worried about that aspect for a start.

Quite apart from that, a couple of points in the legislation worry us, and at some later stage the Minister may be able to help us understand those points. For instance, why is it that the Taxation Commissioner will not now be required to provide the reasons to the taxpayer for rejecting an appeal at the board of review level? I note that there will be a requirement that the Taxation Commissioner will have to provide those reasons to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. But that surely is a different kettle of fish because the taxpayer will not have access to those reasons.

Another point mentioned in the second reading debate which is of some concern is that in the hearings of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal the Attorney-General will have a power of intervention albeit at the request of the taxpayer-I will return to that point in a moment-in matters of so-called public interest. We all know how far that public interest can extend. It would not appear to me to be just or fair to taxpayers who upon the Tribunal's request should invite the Attorney-General to come to speak in their case and give evidence in the public interest, which would amount to giving evidence against the taxpayer. There seems to be an air of unreality about that. If I am misunderstanding the point that the Government is making, I would be only too pleased to have the Government point that out to me. However, it seems that that situation could lead to the very unfortunate position that the rights of taxpayers could, in effect, be very seriously curtailed and affected by the intervention of the Attorney-General. That situation, of course, did not apply, as I understand it, in the case of the old boards of review that operated under the tax law. To that extent, there is to be a serious change in the legislative framework and the way in which the legislation will affect taxpayers' rights.

We are concerned about the proposal to move from boards of review to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal because essentially-this is really the essence of our problem with this matter-we see that as a change from what is an effective informal system, under which people can have their appeals heard within the present framework of the Australian Taxation Office, to what is obviously a more legalistic and formal system of appeals operated within the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. When it is all boiled down, that is where our concern lies. Many people such as lawyers and accountants who practise in the tax jurisdiction seem to support that point of view.

I must say that, generally speaking, the moves to streamline the procedures appear to be welcome. However, we are concerned about the move from a system that I think has been well regarded-albeit a slow system under which it is difficult to get one's case cleared up quickly but one which provides an effective informal release which perhaps will not be available in a legal body such as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. We also note and recognise-perhaps this is a step forward-that, in future, appeals will be made to the Federal Court and not, as is the case now, to the supreme courts in the various States. That may or may not represent a curtailment of the rights of taxpayers. However, it is a matter of some interest in the general community.

Finally, I return to my first point, namely, that these changes together with the proposal in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1986 to change the system of assessment to one of self-assessment by taxpayers, with follow-up audits carried out at random which will touch 3 per cent of taxpayers each year, represent major and very extensive changes to the taxation system. I am aware that there has been very little public discussion on these individual matters, quite apart from the principles involved in the major change. So, we in the Liberal and National parties believe that we should be moving towards a further and wider examination of these questions. For that reason we will be moving at a later stage to refer this legislation to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for examination and report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a group of Bills which seek to reform the taxation system. The group includes the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill 1986, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, the Income Tax (Securities and Agreements) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1986 and the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats see a rational, equitable tax system as being necessary for the development of a strong and just society in this country. We will, therefore, be supporting the Bills now before the Senate. I do not propose to spend a great deal of time talking about these Bills in detail, particularly given the incredible amount of hot air and time wasting we have seen over the last few days in relation to the fringe benefits tax. However, I want to run over briefly what I see as being the major points in these Bills and comment briefly on some of the issues that will arise.

I turn first to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill 1986. This Bill will ensure that the income tax system is evened up within this country by taking out the bias that currently exists in favour of those who receive income from foreign sources where taxes are lower. This will have two effects: Firstly, it will discourage the use of tax havens and, secondly, it will encourage further investment in Australia. At present, a favourite form of corporate tax avoidance is to set up a subsidiary in a foreign tax haven and channel income from overseas sources through the tax haven. Profits can then be repatriated to Australia and the taxes will be deemed to have been paid on those profits and Australian tax will thus be avoided. This mechanism can result in very low tax bills and, thus, the burden of finding the revenue to run this country is put on the backs of the pay as you earn taxpayers. This is quite obviously very unjust.

Foreign tax credits will equalise the tax payable on local and foreign income and, therefore, will make it unattractive for companies to move off-shore purely for tax reasons. I am not saying that companies should not move off-shore. Indeed, in many situations it is very desirable for foreign subsidiaries of Australian companies to be set up. This approach can often help Australian companies break into foreign markets, particularly in South East Asia, and this results in increased exports for the parent company in Australia. However, we should not encourage companies to move off-shore purely for tax reasons. By doing so, we are merely saying: `Okay, stop producing and creating jobs in Australia; go and do it some place else where you can get a tax break'. We are just worsening unemployment in this country, further running down the Australian economy and Australian industry and, of course, worsening our balance of payments problem.

We cannot afford to encourage the further deindustrialisation of the Australian economy. Just look at the figures on capital outflow from this country over the last few years. In 1982-83 the capital outflow was $1250m; in 1983-84 it jumped to $2,262m; and, would honourable senators believe, by 1984-85 it rocketed to $4,932m. The fact is that foreign tax credits will help arrest this leakage of capital. Where this outflow is a result of a search for a low tax portfolio investment, the incentive will disappear. Where the outflow is a result of Australian companies moving off-shore purely for tax reasons, the movement will be slowed. No longer will companies be encouraged to close productive capacity in Australia and move to where taxes are lower. Now moves off-shore will be more likely to be fuelled by considerations of developing new markets. In other words, we still produce here in Australia, but it may be advantageous to set up plants in other Asian countries to assist export expansion plans. This type of activity is very desirable and it can add to productive capacity at home and abroad and increased export earnings for Australia.

I now turn to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2). The Democrats believe that this Bill will introduce desirable reforms. A tax will be charged every year to holders of deferred interest securities, which will take into account the fact that these people have received interest in that year which has been deferred in favour of capital growth. Under the present laws, people holding deferred interest securities are not charged income tax. Even under the capital gains tax legislation, shortly to be put through this House, holders of such securities would still gain considerable tax advantage, as capital gains are indexed for inflation whereas yearly income tax is not. It is reasonable to charge tax on deferred interest on a yearly basis and we support that.

This Bill also implements changes to the income tax secrecy provisions, which allow responsibility for the non-revenue aspect of superannuation fund regulation to be handed over from the Commissioner of Taxation to the treasury of a newly created superannuation body. The Democrats would like to see superannuation controlled by a body with a much wider brief than the Commissioner of Taxation. Superannuation funds and life insurance offices presently control over 50 per cent of the shares in Australian stock markets; a very large percentage. Once superannuation is extended to the 60 per cent of the work force which does not currently enjoy it, the control of superannuation funds over stock markets will increase dramatically. It is vital to the future of this country that these huge funds be regulated and channelled in such a way that Australia gains maximum benefit. I would like to see a new body set up to regulate superannuation funds which has to consider, as part of its brief, the effects on the wider economy of the investment of superannuation funds.

The present financial system, with its tax encouragement of unproductive takeovers and share market speculation, is misdirecting enormous potential for the good and development of Australia for which superannuation funds could be used. At the moment companies are encouraged to engage in takeovers rather than to invest in productive areas. This sends the stock markets into a frenzy, resulting in more and more money being sucked into the unproductive whirlpool. Superannuation funds are now competing fiercely with each other for contributors' money. Their investment performance is compared in charts produced on a monthly basis and those which perform badly lose business to high flyers making returns of up to 60 per cent per annum. Returns of this nature are in cloud-cuckoo land. One gets returns of that nature only by speculating and taking great risks. Consequently, superannuation funds are now being used to buy and sell shares to make quick profits, to move funds overseas, to play foreign exchange markets and to ride on the backs of the takeover entrepreneurs. If this bubble should burst the superannuation benefits of millions of Australians will be looking very shaky indeed. The Democrats would like to see a new regulatory body which is prepared to address these sorts of problems.

Superannuation can provide a way of funding Australians in retirement; a very desirable thing to happen. Superannuation funds can also act as a motor for genuine industrial development. Who can say that we do not need this right now, with the magnitude of the balance of payments crisis? However, if we wish to gain real benefits from superannuation we must ensure that the funds are used to fund real investment which will expand the productive capacity of this country and create jobs. We cannot afford to waste superannuation money by chasing speculative gains through buying and selling slices of an ever decreasing pie.

The Democrats want to see an end to the takeover rorts. We want to see superannuation funds regulated to ensure that monies are invested only in Australian companies. We want to see a percentage of the funds turnover put aside to fund industry with export potential, the development of Australian technology, the majority Australian ownership in important resources projects, and also for housing. These funds could provide money at concessional rates of interest. Of course, some people say that this will not work, that the returns to the contributors, if this were to happen, would be too low. The fact of the matter is that we must look at superannuation in the long term, not on a monthly or quarterly basis as is being done currently. If we use wisely our superannuation funds, which represent the savings of Australians to develop industry we can all live better in retirement.

In conclusion, I say that if we do not believe that this approach can work, let us look at Japan. It has prospered because it has used the financial system to fund growth in the real economy. We in Australia currently are strangling the real economy to give enormous speculative returns to those who manipulate the financial system. That is a recipe for disaster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

I understand that the motion cannot be put collectively because the Opposition will oppose one or more of the Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill 1986 be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after `That' and insert `the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill 1986 be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for inquiry and report by the first day of sitting in August 1986'.

During the second reading debate on this Bill I explained the reasons why the Opposition believes that it is important at this stage to refer this matter to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for report and examination. There are numerous matters flowing from this particular legislation, quite apart from the fact that it seems to be part of a package aimed at totally changing the taxation assessment system. The Government has announced that it will proceed with a self-assessment system together with an audit of 3 per cent of taxpayers. There will also be alterations to the system whereby taxpayers' assessments will be amended which, together with the new system of addressing appeals through the Administration Appeals Tribunal, seems to represent a considerable change to the rights of taxpayers and to the operation of the system as it applies today. We believe that that overall change has not been made the subject of enough public discussion; nor have all the issues been substantially exposed to the community for discussion. Consequently, it is our view that it ought to be referred to the Senate Committee on Finance and Government Operations in order to examine all the consequences of that decision. That is not to say that we oppose some of the individual measures that are incorporated in this legislation, and I pointed that out earlier. The fact is that numerous things can be done to improve and streamline the flow of cases regarding taxation matters through the appeals mechanism.

Certainly, the present system is totally unsatisfactory because there is a backlog of some 94,000 cases-I think that is the number-that have not yet been processed through the system of appeals and through the boards of review. Clearly, that is an injustice, if you like, upon the taxpayer insofar as those appeals have not been heard, and the Government's steps in trying to improve that situation are welcomed by the Opposition. We believe, for instance, that the move towards single member tribunals hearing appeals in these cases is a reasonable and welcome change. However, we believe that there ought to be an appropriate airing of all the issues to make sure that taxpayers do have a thorough understanding of the way in which their rights may be curtailed or affected by those issues. For that reason, we have moved this amendment at this stage to ensure appropriate exposure of all the issues to the public gaze. The total change, which is very substantial, which is going on within the administration of taxation law should be made clear to the people of Australia so that they can put their views forward and, indeed, take issue with the Government on certain matters, if they so wish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in a previous speech, the Australian Democrats will not support the amendment which proposes that this legislation be sent to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for the very good reason that the whole tax reform package was the subject of the National Taxation Summit in June of last year. Since that time, it has been subject to intense community debate and speculation. There is nothing worse than indecision; it creates nervousness in investment in this country and nervousness in the taxpayers. The worst possible thing that could happen to the Australian economy now would be for it to go through a further period of indecision on this whole tax reform package.

SPEECH.PARA: This package, by whatever measure one likes to take, is the most significant reform of taxation in this country since 1945. As such, it has naturally created all kinds of problems, concerns and worries. But the community has had the opportunity to debate it. The Government put out a White Paper which canvassed the options absolutely-in great depth and very thoroughly. The Democrats believe that while the detail of some of the Bills that the Government has introduced is by no means perfect, it has grasped the nettle. It has introduced a package of tax reform. The Democrats were a part of the Taxation Summit. We listened very carefully to the community debate at that time and read carefully the Government's White Paper on tax reform, and we came to the conclusion that the general thrust of what the Government was doing was right.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has nothing to do with this Bill.
—I say to Senator Messner that I am simply saying that to create another six or nine months of indecision on vital parts of that tax package would be the worst possible option.
—It has nothing to do with the tax package.
—I am sorry, but it has. It is a part of the whole subject of tax reform. To put it to a committee at this stage and to create further indecision would be the worst possible option available to us.
