TAXATION BOARDS OF REVIEW (TRANSFER OF JURISDICTION) BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 47, clause 138, proposed section 39A, definition of ``refund decision'', line 38, after ``a decision'', insert ``made on or after 1 July 1986''.
Page 48, clause 139, at end of proposed sub-section 40 (3), add ``or within such further time as the Commissioner allows''.
Page 70, clause 188, proposed sub-section 10 (5), definition of ``refund decision'', line 13, after ``decision'', insert ``made on or after 1 July 1986''.
Page 86, clause 217 (2), lines 17 to 21, leave out the sub-clause.
Page 86, sub-clause 217 (3), line 22, after ``1930'', insert ``as in force on 1 July 1986''.

Clause 138 proposes the repeal of section 39A of the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) and the insertion of a new section 39A which will define certain terms for the purposes of Part VII of the Act. The term `refund decision' is defined in new section 39A and is intended to refer to decisions made on or after 1 July 1986 in relation to applications for a refund of tax. The amendment of clause 138 will ensure that the term `refund decision' means only a decision made on or after 1 July 1986.

Clause 139 of the Bill will repeal sections 40, 41 and 42 of the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) and insert several new sections to deal with objections, reviews and appeals. Proposed sub-section 40 (3) will limit the kind of refund decision against which a person may object to a decision that is made in relation to an application lodged within 60 days of the transaction that gives rise to the refund entitlement. However, situations may arise where a person does not become aware of an entitlement to a refund within the 60-day time limit, and the amendment of clause 139 will allow the Commissioner of Taxation, in appropriate circumstances, to accept as valid an objection against a decision on an application for refund made outside the 60-day time limit.

Clause 188 proposes to substitute a new section 10 in the Sales Tax Procedure Act. Sub-section 10 (5) contains definitions to assist in the interpretation of section 10. The amendment of clause 188 will amend the definition of `refund decision' in the same manner as the proposed amendment of clause 138 referred to earlier.

Clause 217 of the Bill is a transitional provision dealing with sales tax matters. The amendment of the definition of `refund decision' in clauses 138 and 188 means that proposed sub-clause 217 (2) will become unnecessary. The amendment of sub-clause 217 (3) will correct a minor technical error in the Bill by making it clear that the section referred to in the sub-clause is the section in force on and after 1 July 1986. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just listening to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) speak and putting down the reasons for the Government's amendments makes one think that there are no problems with them. But I think it is absolutely beneath contempt that the amendments were not introduced earlier. In fact, a copy of these amendments was put on my desk when I was on my feet discussing an earlier part of this taxation package. I had no knowledge of these amendments coming and no possibility of being able to study their effect. We have had no apology from the Government for such action. I believe that the kind of peremptory action which has been undertaken tonight is typical of the way in which the Government has been treating this chamber in regard to this legislation. We have a package of a considerable number of pieces of legislation of great complexity which will have a great deal of effect on the business community generally and we are expected to put them through this chamber sausage fashion. The way in which the Government has treated us without giving us any notice of this set of amendments at all is absolutely beyond understanding.

SPEECH.PARA: In dealing with the Committee stage of the Bill let me say that we have sought to refer this whole Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. We believe that to be an appropriate course. We believe that this issue has not been exposed to the public in the way that it should have been. We believe that many concerns of the taxpayers are at issue and many people may have their rights curtailed as a result of the passage of this legislation. These matters have been referred to in debate in the House of Representatives at an earlier time. We believe that there are likely to be serious consequences and that taxpayers may well find that they have reason to complain to the Government about the passage of this legislation in such a hasty fashion.

I must say that Senator Siddons, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, led us to believe that this legislation is somehow part and parcel of the Government's taxation passage. Of course it is not and it has never been part of the package. We heard nothing of this until only most recent days-about 10 days ago-when this legislation was introduced in the House of Representatives. I can recall, as early as the first week in May, asking questions of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) about this matter and being told in this place that no decision had been taken about what might happen in this regard. Yet we have had a piece of legislation parcelled up in the dying days of this session, coupled with other measures with which it had no original relationship, and put before us as an issue which we have to decide upon, followed by a set of amendments which we have had absolutely no opportunity to digest.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the second reading debate I referred to two matters which were of concern to the Opposition in regard to the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill. One was in connection with the situation that would have arisen with regard to the requests from taxpayers for reasons which would have flowed had the original boards of review system applied. The point is that the Commissioner of Taxation has been obliged in the past to prepare and deliver the reasons for his judgment in taxation disputes to the taxpayer in the event of his appeal being turned down. That seems a quite reasonable proposition. However, with the system that will now apply because the boards of review will be incorporated into the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, what will occur is that reasons will not be given, except to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, by the Commissioner of Taxation. I seek leave to move my amendments together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 29, after clause 79, insert the following clause:
`79a. Section 186 of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end `and with a statement of reasons for that decision'.'.
(2) Page 75, clause 196, proposed new section 14ze, modified section 30,
(a) leave out paragraph (1) (c); and
(b) at the end of modified section 30, add the following sub-section:
`(4) Notwithstanding section 30a, the Attorney-General may not intervene in a proceeding to which this section applies.'.

The second amendment affects the ability of the Attorney-General to intervene in matters before the AAT where the public interest is called into question. This seems to us to be an interference in and a curtailment of the rights of the individual taxpayer insofar as that would not have applied when the old boards of review were in existence. This is an extension of the power of the Commissioner and a curtailment of the power and rights of the individual taxpayer. It is for that reason I have moved the amendment to clause 196.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Both amendments are not acceptable to the Government. I will deal firstly with the first amendment. That amendment would require the Commissioner when giving his decision on any objection to give reasons for that decision. By reason of section 25d of the Acts Interpretation Act, the amendment would mean that the Commissioner of Taxation would, with every objection decision, be required to give a statement in writing setting out his findings on material questions of fact referring to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based and giving reasons for that decision.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point that, in income tax alone, some 250,000 objections are lodged each year. If the Commissioner were required to comply with section 25d of the Acts Interpretation Act in each case the work load would be tremendous. An army of tax officers would be required to comply with the requirement. At one day per statement it is not unreasonable to assume that approximately 1,000 extra staff would be required. This aspect was clearly recognised by the Administrative Review Council in its report on the boards of review when it recommended against such a proposal as has now been moved by the Opposition. The Commissioner will give reasons to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and when the Administrative Appeals Tribunal gives a decision on these matters it will, in turn, give written reasons for its decision. The Opposition's amendment will just add an additional process, as it were, which would be costly in terms of time, staff and a whole range of issues. It was for that reason the Administrative Review Council recommended against it.

The second amendment would have the effect of preventing the Attorney-General from making submissions to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in respect of matters on which he has a special interest. The Attorney-General is responsible for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act and it is appropriate that he should be able to intervene, for example, to clarify important issues of interpretation of that Act. The Attorney-General's right of intervention extends to all Administrative Appeals Tribunal jurisdictions and there is no reason why an exception should be made in relation to taxation appeals. There would be a situation which was totally different from the general right of the Attorney-General to intervene.

The important point in indicating the Government's reason for opposition to the second amendment moved by Senator Messner is that the Attorney-General exercises that right of intervention very rarely in respect of any jurisdiction. The Attorney-General would not intervene, as has been said in the second reading speech, in order to interpret a taxation law or to oppose a taxpayer's claim on its merits. It is a general right of intervention relating to interpretation of the legislation which is sought by the legislation and which would be rejected if the amendment was carried. For those reasons, the Government cannot accept either of these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to get it straight. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce clearly was saying to us that the Attorney-General would not intervene in circumstances involving the particular facts of a case before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. In other words, it would be only on broad matters of principle that he would be seeking to intervene and to be heard on particular points. Am I right in understanding that the taxpayer's rights as such would not be affected by the intervention of the Attorney-General in those cases?

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

—The point then is that the right of appeal remains with the taxpayer to the Federal Court of Australia, as I understand it, through the changed arrangements although, because of this Bill, the taxpayer will have forgone his right to take up matters of fact through the present Supreme Court system of appeals.

I apologise to Senator Messner in respect of the delay in regard to the circulation of the amendments to the earlier Bill. However, I understand that the amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) have been in circulation for some time. Amendments numbered 1 to 5, 7 to 9 and 11 to 14 will correct a drafting error in the definition of a qualifying security as that term is to apply to the measures contained in the Bill to strengthen the interest withholding tax provisions of the income tax law. The definition of a qualifying security is contained in those provisions of the Bill that will implement an accrual method of assessment to eliminate the tax deferral that discounted and other deferred interest securities offer resident taxpayers.

As a drafting technique, that definition and others that are also relevant are imported into the interest withholding tax provisions of the Bill. Because deferral of tax is not an issue with securities having a term of less than one year, one of the tests contained in the definition of a qualifying security for the purposes of the accruals method of assessment is that the security is issued for a term in excess of one year. On the other hand, one of the interest withholding tax avoidance techniques being addressed by the Bill-broadly, the sale of a qualifying security before its redemption-can occur regardless of the term of the security.

Due to an oversight, the definition of a qualifying security, as it is to apply in the interest withholding tax provisions, was not expressed to do so omitting reference to the term of the security. The unintended effect of this is to exclude from the scope of the interest withholding tax measures relevant securities issued for a term of one year or less. These amendments will rectify that. Amendment No. 6 will remedy a technical omission in clause 25 of the Bill by incorporating relevant definitions from an associated measure inadvertently omitted from that clause.

The final amendment-No. 10-will omit clause 27 of the Bill. Clause 27 effectively provides that a person who relies in good faith on a false notice issued for the purposes of either of the measures applying to a qualifying security will not be liable for penalty additional tax which, by reason of other provisions of the Bill, is to be imposed in relation to the making of false or misleading statements. On further examination it has been concluded that those other provisions are so drafted that, in conjunction with the proper interpretation of the existing law in this area, the person concerned would not, in the circumstances I have described, be regarded as having made a false statement attracting penalty additional tax. Accordingly there is no need to specifically provide for remission of such tax as proposed by clause 27, and it is to be omitted from the Bill. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

The speeches read as follows-
INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (CAPITAL GAINS) BILL 1986
The Bill before the Senate amends the Income Tax Assessment Act to introduce a tax on certain gains and modify the current income tax measures relating to the taxation of employee share benefits.
Capital Gains Tax
The legislation will enact a fundamental reform to the Australian taxation system.
It will make the tax system much fairer by smashing the basis of much of the rampant tax avoidance that occurred under our predecessors.
And it will make the tax system much more efficient by encouraging investment that will generate growth and jobs.
For years a debate on this issue has dragged on in this country-a debate which unfortunately has too often been characterised by misinformation and hysteria rather than rational discussion.
This Government invited discussion on a Capital Gains Tax at the National Taxation Summit in July 1985.
We listened carefully to the views of the Australian people as expressed at that meeting, and the design of the tax reflects those views.
Capital gains contribute to taxable capacity no less than wages and salaries, interest and dividends, and business trading profits.

It has been particularly inequitable that those who receive their income primarily or wholly in forms such as wages and salaries have been taxed more heavily than those who have been able to arrange for much or all of their income to be taken in the form of capital gains.

The absence of a Capital Gains Tax has also undermined the intended progressivity of the tax system since the distribution of the ownership of capital is more heavily concentrated among the higher income groups.
In addition, it has been at the core of many tax avoidance arrangements involving the conversion or dressing up of income as capital gains.

The introduction of a capital gains tax therefore strikes at one of the foundations of tax avoidance in Australia, and makes a crucial contribution to the Government's efforts to stamp out tax avoidance practices.
The lack of a capital gains tax has also distorted investment choices towards less productive uses.
Decisions to invest have been determined, not only by the overall yield of a project, but also by the composition of that yield as between tax free capital gains and assessable income.
This has produced an inappropriate pattern of investment, preventing Australia from achieving the best possible economic growth rate.
Australia is a capital scarce nation-the last thing it should be doing is providing incorrect signals to the market as to how to allocate that capital.

By ameliorating this distortion, the capital gains tax will help to improve the overall productiveness with which capital is invested in Australia, improving our international competitiveness and lifting our economic growth rate. The design of the capital gains tax introduced by this Bill follows that announced in the Treasurer's 19 September 1985 statement on tax reform, as expanded upon in press releases which he issued on 28 November 1985 and 20 March 1986.
I now turn to the main features of the Bill.
Plan of the tax
The tax will apply only to capital gains realised on assets acquired after 19 September 1985.
Accordingly, assets acquired by taxpayers on or prior to that date will be exempt from the tax when disposed of by them.
This will substantially reduce the immediate impact of the tax and allow the community a lengthy period in which to adjust to its application.

Except where assets are acquired and disposed of within 12 months, the tax will apply only to real capital gains realised on the disposal of assets-that is to any gain remaining after removing the purely inflationary element.
To achieve this, the cost base of assets will be regularly indexed according to the movement in the consumer price index over the time from when the expenditure was incurred to the date of disposal.
This means that an asset which increases in value at no more than the rate of inflation will bear no capital gains tax.
Assets whose value increases at more than the rate of inflation will be taxed only on that part of the gain which exceeds the inflation rate.
Any real capital gain realised on an asset will be included in assessable income in the year of receipt and subject to income tax, but will receive the benefit of averaging.

Under the system of averaging adopted, a capital gain realised in any year will be notionally spread over 5 years for purposes of determining the rate of income tax applicable to the whole of the gain in that year.
Currently gains on assets are taxed if they fall within either section 25a or section 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

The former section will cease to apply for assets acquired after 19 September 1985 but section 26aaa, which deals with gains on assets bought and sold within twelve months, will continue to apply, where relevant.

Consistent with the equity and anti-avoidance objectives of the tax, gains on the foreign assets of Australian residents, as well as gains on their Australian assets, are to be included in the capital gains tax base.
However, relief from double taxation will be provided for any foreign tax levied on gains on foreign assets subject to the tax.
One design feature of the capital gains tax requiring elaboration is its application to non-residents.

Consistent with the principal that non-residents are subject to income tax on their Australian source income, the Government has decided that non-residents are to be taxed on a substantial range of capital gains.
Broadly, the following assets owned by non-residents are to be included within the capital gains tax base:
any asset used in carrying on a trade or business in Australia;
land and buildings, and specified interests in land, situated in Australia;
shares in Australian resident public companies or units in resident unit trusts, where the non-resident or his or her associates had at least a 10 per cent interest in the company or unit trust; and
shares in Australian resident private companies and interests in resident partnerships and trusts.

Because of the 10 per cent threshold test applying in relation to shares held in Australian public companies, it can be expected that the tax generally will not apply to purely portfolio holdings of Australian shares by non-residents.

Where arrangements apply for the crediting of Australian capital gains tax against the non-resident's liability in his country of residence, the total tax burden will increase only to the extent, if any, that the rate of Australian tax exceeds that in the foreign country.
This point is important to bear in mind when assessing the implications of the tax for the attractiveness of new foreign investment in Australia.
Where crediting arrangements apply, failure to tax non-residents on their Australian source capital gains generally simply results in us giving up revenue for the benefit of foreign treasuries.
An important general design feature of the tax is that the death of an asset holder will not be taken to give rise to a realisation of his or her assets for capital gains tax purposes.

An exception applies where the beneficiary receiving the assets is exempt from income and capital gains tax to ensure that any gain accruing over the period that the deceased held the assets does not disappear entirely from the tax base. With certain exceptions-broadly, personal use assets and assets subject to income tax depreciation and balancing adjustments-nominal capital losses on the disposal of assets will be able to be offset against capital gains of the current or subsequent years.
In calculating a gain or loss, any capital expenditures associated with the acquisition, improvement or disposal of an asset will be taken into account.
Exemptions and Rollovers
Honourable senators will recall some exclusions from the tax that have been announced previously.
The most important exemption relates to gains on the taxpayer's principal residence.

Also exempt is 20 per cent of the otherwise taxable capital gains on the sale of business goodwill wholly created by a taxpayer, where the net value of the taxpayer's business interests is less than one million dollars.

Other exemptions include gains made by bodies exempt from income tax, the proceeds of life insurance and superannuation policies, gains on certain motor vehicles, and gains on most kinds of personal use assets whose disposal value is less than $5,000.

Rollovers-that is, deferral of capital gains tax liability-are to be allowed for asset ownership changes associated with specified types of business reorganisations where no change occurs in the underlying ownership of the asset concerned or where the underlying assets against which the taxpayer has a claim do not change.
The specific situations provided for include, for example, transfers of assets between companies in the same group, provided the companies share 100 per cent common ownership.
The Government has considered the view that more general rollover relief should be available for business reorganisations on the argument that not to do so could inhibit desirable business behaviour.
It has rejected this argument on equity grounds.
Taken to its logical conclusion it is virtually akin to saying that it is only the capital gains of individuals not operating businesses which should be subject to the tax.
Rollovers are also provided for certain involuntary asset disposals.
These include the compulsory acquisition of assets by a government body and the theft or destruction of assets, where replacement assets are acquired within a stipulated period.
In addition, in order to avoid the possibility of undue financial hardship, rollovers will apply for asset transfers between spouses incident to the breakdown of legal marriages.

The Bill also generally provides for the continuation of capital gains tax exempt status where an asset acquired prior to 20 September 1985 is transferred in circumstances where it would have qualified for a rollover if acquired after that date.
Additional Matters

The Bill will give effect to the Government's decision to treat as new assets subject to capital gains tax major capital improvements made after 19 September 1985 to assets acquired on or before that date.

A major capital improvement will be taken to have occurred where the indexed cost base of the improvements at the year of disposal exceeds both an indexed specified value-$50,000 for the year ending 30 June 1986-and 5 per cent of the asset's disposal value.
To leave such major improvements outside of the capital gains tax base would significantly distort investment decisions as between the improvement of existing assets and the purchase of new assets.
The Bill also provides for the capital gains tax treatment of trusts to parallel their income tax treatment.

This will mean, for example, that where a beneficiary in a private trust or a unitholder in a public unit trust is presently entitled to a capital gain made by the trust, it will be taxed in the beneficiary's or unitholder's hands. Where this is not the case, it will be taxed in the trustee's hands.
Capital gains tax will also apply to units held in unit trusts, where the units were acquired after 19 September 1985.
Leases and leasehold improvements are to be treated as assets subject to capital gains tax.
Special provisions are to apply where a leasehold interest in land is converted to freehold after 19 September 1985.
Where the lease was acquired after that date, capital gains tax is not to apply until the freehold is disposed of.
Where the lease was acquired on or before that date, and had a term of at least 99 years, the tax will not apply to the disposal of either the leasehold or freehold interest.
Where the term was less than 99 years, the tax will only apply to any real gain accruing on the land from the time of its conversion to freehold.
Also subject to capital gains tax will be payments for the surrender of various rights.
An example would be payments under restrictive covenants whereby the recipient undertakes not to use specified assets or to trade only with the other party to the agreement.
Such rights are assets and gains made on their disposal are to be included within the capital gains tax base where they are not already subject to income tax.
The basic design features of the capital gains tax will apply to mining exploration and production rights. Their application is further explained in a press release issued on 22 May 1986.
The Bill contains a number of specific anti-avoidance provisions.
The general anti-avoidance provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act, Part IVa, will also, of course, have application.
The tax will be assessed annually as part of the normal Income Tax Assessment process and the existing income tax penalty provisions will apply for breaches of the law in the Capital Gains Tax area.
Finally, I would emphasise that, in designing the Capital Gains Tax, the Government has taken great care to ensure that it will not impact unfairly.

The restriction of the tax to assets acquired after 19 September 1985, the exemption for the principal residence, the concessional treatment of personal use assets including motor vehicles, and the non-taxation of inflationary gains, mean that, for most taxpayers, the tax will have little or no impact.

Groups such as farmers and small businessmen who have expressed concern that a Capital Gains Tax would be unduly harsh and lead to the break up or sale of the family farm or business upon their death have no foundation for such concern.
The exemption for pre-20 September 1985 assets means that there will be no tax liability for farmers and small businessmen in respect of their asset holdings as at 19 September 1985.

Further, the exemption for the principal residence and reasonable curtilage, the tax-free transfer of assets upon death and full indexation of gains for inflation, will mean that the vast majority of those who acquire farms or small businesses after that date are unlikely to face a substantial liability when they dispose of their assets.
The availability of averaging provides further protection to taxpayers.
Employee Share Acquisition Schemes

As a consequence of the introduction of the Capital Gains Tax, amendments are also to be made to those provisions of the Income Tax Law that relate to the taxing of benefits associated with shares and share rights acquired under employee share acquisition schemes.
Under the existing law, shares acquired under such schemes and subject to conditions or restrictions on disposal are taken to have been acquired when those conditions or restrictions cease to apply.
The excess of the value of the shares at that time over their cost to the employee is subject to income tax.

The result is that any unrealised nominal capital gain accrued between the date of issue and the date when the conditions or restrictions cease is subject to tax, as well as the ``Fringe Benefit'' element represented by the excess of the market value of the shares at their date of issue over their cost to the employee.

In relation to share rights, the present law subjects to tax-when the rights are either disposed of or are exercised to acquire shares-the excess of the sale price or the value of the shares, as the case may be, over their cost of acquisition to the employee.
Here also, an unrealised capital gain may be subject to income tax, in addition to any ``Fringe Benefit'' element.

In respect of shares or rights issued after 19 September 1985, the Bill will give taxpayers the option of being taxed on the benefit derived as calculated at the date of issue, rather than at the relevant later date.
Where that option is exercised by the taxpayer, the acquisition cost of the shares or rights for Capital Gains Tax purposes will be taken to be their market value at the date of issue.
Financial Impact

The estimated net revenue gain from the introduction of the capital gains tax and modifications to the employee share benefit provisions is $5 million in 1987-88 and $25 million in the fifth year of operation of the capital gains tax.
This Bill marks another important step towards a fairer tax system.
In revenue terms its direct yield is modest but it will make a significant contribution to protection of the income tax base.
A detailed explanatory memorandum is being made available to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX (RATES) AMENDMENT (CAPITAL GAINS) BILL 1986

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Income Tax (Rates) Act 1982, which declares the rates of tax payable by individuals and trustees generally, to implement the announcement of 28 November 1985 that a form of averaging would apply for calculating the tax payable on capital gains.

The accompanying Bill proposes to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to provide, generally that capital gains realised by a taxpayer, as a result of a disposal of assets acquired on or after 20 September 1985 will be included in the taxpayer's assessable income.

The amendments made by this Bill will, broadly, require the tax payable in respect of a net capital gain realised in a year of income (after taking into account allowable capital losses) to be calculated by adding one-fifth of the net capital gain to the pre-gain taxable income.
The additional tax attributable to that amount is to be multiplied by five to arrive at the tax payable on the capital gain.

This will mean for those taxpayers whose taxable income other than capital gains is not taxed at the highest marginal rate, that the inclusion of a net capital gain will not necessarily result in income tax being levied at a higher marginal rate.

This rule will be modified for primary producers and other taxpayers in receipt of forms of income receipts to which notional assessment procedures already apply to cushion the impact of crossing tax brackets.
In those cases, one-fifth of the net capital gain will be added to the average income or the notional income, instead of adjusting the taxable income.
The average or notional income in those cases will also be calculated without reference to the capital gain.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can all remember these words:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it, and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion-there will be no capital gains tax.

These are the words that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) used, as the Leader of the Opposition, at the launching of the Australian Labor Party's policy at the Sydney Opera House on 16 February 1983. He said: `There will be no capital gains tax'. Of course, we have it in this legislation.

Let us look over the history of this tawdry set of events. We recall the disastrous Taxation Summit that was called last year at which the Prime Minister laid down the so-called nine commandments of taxation reform. Amongst them was the edict that changes to the taxation system must help to smash tax avoidance. Yet any tax expert will tell us that of all taxes that we now have in this country-and God only knows we have far too many-the capital gains tax is the easiest to avoid. Capital gains tax, especially the capital gains tax which is the subject of this legislation, can be easily avoided by not selling one's assets. The long term effect of that is likely to be a stiffening-up in the market-place-financial arthritis, if you like-with people hanging onto their assets in order to avoid paying a capital gains tax.

One of the arguments of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for a capital gains tax is that it has an anti-avoidance effect when taxpayers clearly have been using capital gains as some kind of income. Clearly, that is a load of nonsense. In 1983 the Treasurer said that, in terms of revenue gain, capital taxes were `peripheral' and `marginal' and that they were not likely to produce revenue which the Government could use for the benefits of the people. If that is the case, how can it be a substantial tax which will improve the lot of other taxpayers? We recall those words well. They were uttered, I understand, at the Australian Labor Party's conference in 1983. Now the Treasurer would have us believe that this is some marvellous opportunity to improve the distribution of welfare in this community. This is utter nonsense.

Later in November of 1984, the Treasurer said that there was no certainty that any capital gains tax would have any beneficial effects. Let us just find out what it is the Senate is debating here tonight. The fact is that the only reason we have a capital gains tax is that the Australian Council of Trade Unions is demanding that such a tax should be part of the accord. The ACTU told the Government to impose this tax. The Government was given this direction in a smoke-filled room back in July 1985 when the Prime Minister did his grubby little deal with the union leaders.

Although this legislation will come into effect on 1 July, it will apply from 19 September of last year. The tax will be payable on all gains from 19 September at the taxpayer's highest marginal rate of tax. At present that rate stands at 61 per cent. The tax distinctly discriminates against low income earners whose marginal tax rates might be as low as 29 per cent. These people will have to pay an extra 32 per cent. The Government fails to recognise that it is the low income earners who worked the hardest to save and accumulate their capital assets. The tax will be far-reaching and has been described in the media as the toughest capital gains tax in the industrial world.

Let us look at a few examples of how the tax will affect particular groups. Let us look at the death duty effect. In the case of bequests, the estate of the deceased will have to pay capital gains tax on gifts to churches and charities, which will, of course, draw on the other assets of the estate in order to net down to the required amount of money to be delivered to these bodies. Clearly, that is going to diminish in future the opportunities of people who will be looking to help the disadvantaged in the community. Capital improvements which may have been entered into prior to 19 September last year, when the Government announced this measure, will be subject to the capital gains tax. That obviously will affect the modification and extension of premises of taxpayers who want to improve their rental properties. It will obviously affect farmers who want to do the same. The question remains of how improvements will be valued when the gain is assessed after many years have passed. There has been no clear indication yet from the Government about that. Obviously this is going to be a major disincentive to investment in the future. It is obviously going to be in the interests of businesses to make do with patching-up and repairing bits and pieces of their equipment, plant and buildings.

What is happening in the mining industry is another example of this financial arthritis that clearly is not going to assist development in this country towards the dynamic economy that we need in order to drag ourselves out of the industrial recession into which we are rapidly descending. Where either a lease or a right to take income from minerals is granted in consideration of a capital payment, the tax will be payable without any offsetting costs and irrespective of how long that land or mineral lease has been held. Let us look at the situation in normal business circumstances where there is a rollover of an asset towards the same kind of replacement asset that is needed in a business. In other words, when an asset is sold the capital is immediately reinvested in another asset. One example of this might be where a business person sells his premises to buy a larger office or factory which may be even more expensive. The capital gains tax will apply to the sale of the first premises and, as a result, add to the cost of the purchase of the second. Clearly, this is going to have a detrimental effect on the opportunities and the incentive of people to establish and develop new businesses, to become more efficient and to employ more people. The rollover relief will occur only in circumstances where there is 100 per cent ownership of the entities between the change. However, in other circumstances, the difficulties that I have described will arise.

Perhaps one of the most callous issues in this capital gains tax is the question of goodwill. We all know of the case of a small business person who maybe starts off with a small corner delicatessen and who works 60 or 80 hours a week over 20 years to build up that business. However, when he comes to sell that business, his goodwill, apart from a mingy 20 per cent discount that this Government will now allow-and remember that this person has built up his business over a 20-year working life-will be taxable at the top marginal rate. Twenty years of work will go down the drain in one tax year and this will obviously affect his capacity to reinvest and develop or even to retire. I realise that an averaging provision will apply as well. However, we might as well forget about that for all the benefit it will be to people in these circumstances.

The law provides for discounting for inflation. In other words, account can be taken of the cost and value increases of assets over a long period due to inflation. However, naturally enough, that will not apply in the case of goodwill because there is no cost base from which one can work. Consequently, inflation will not have any effect and the taxpayer will pay tax on the inflation component of the value of that goodwill. Should a person sell his business and at the same time enter into a restrictive covenant with the purchaser of the business, the same thing will apply to the purchaser of that business. The restrictive covenant that is entered into will have no cost base and, as a result, will not be indexed and, consequently, will in itself when resold become taxable.

All of these things will hit small taxpayers; people at the lowest end of the income scale. They are not the wealthy stock exchange speculators or the wealthy landowners who live on Sydney harbour; they are the ordinary people of Australia, the battlers, who are trying to do their best to build up assets in their own name so that they do not become a burden on society. This, of course, is typical of the Australian Labor Party's attitude. It is clear that all it wants to do is to smash the small business community because it knows that the small business community is likely to give it the most trouble politically in actively opposing the union movement.

We can go through the numerous examples of problems that will arise with the various aspects of this capital gains tax before us. There will be problems for people who are living in some kind of residence provided by a private company. Shareholders who owned shares before 19 September 1985 will hang on to those shares and so distort the stock market as a result, because they know that when they sell they will have to pay tax and as such there is no incentive to sell, thus causing prices to rise artificially higher than they ought. People who have built a holiday house on a block of land for which they have saved through their lifetime, who have put their own labour into the erection of that holiday house and who have spent their own money on buying the bits and pieces associated with it, will find that the labour costs that they have put into that holiday house will not be taken into account for capital gains tax purposes. The only costs that will be identified are those classed as directly associated with the materials on which they have expended money. Consequently, they will be paying tax on their own labour in that situation.

The question of the way in which this capital gains tax will apply to takeovers may be very interesting to people such as the Australian Democrats who have views about the current state of the takeover market, but I ask them to consider the situation of legitimate takeovers which are in the genuine interests of Australia by virtue of the fact that there will be a consolidation of assets and an improvement in the economies of scale which will ensure that the consumer wins out of that takeover. All of these things are incorporated in this piece of legislation. We in the Liberal and National parties oppose the legislation. We will be opposing it at all stages and will be seeking to repeal that legislation when we are returned to government at the end of 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the end of 1988?

—I am sorry, 1987. I thank Senator Walsh for reminding me that it will be a year earlier than that. It is hard to understand what the Government has in mind in introducing a tax such as this. Even the former Whitlam Government found it impossible to administer and very difficult to implement and dropped the whole idea back in 1974 when it sought to introduce similar legislation. When we look at what the Treasurer has been saying-that it is marginal and will increase the funds to the Government only in a very small way-quite clearly he must have had some conversion on the road to Damascus or some other place because now he has become convinced that this is the saviour for all mankind. According to Government's own figures, some $5m will be raised out of this tax next year and this amount might rise to a maximum of $25m in the space of the next four or five years. I discovered from a question on notice that I put to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) a few weeks ago that even in 1995, some ten years after the original announcement, it is expected that the Government will raise only $150m.
—But you are assuming that the legislation will not be amended, by removing the CPI factor and other indicators.

—Senator Crichton-Browne has raised a very important point. This is really only the sprat to catch the mackerel. What this legislation is about is getting a foot in the door. The Government, having established this kind of tax, which perhaps can be sold in a plausible way as being quite easy to live with, can turn to other factors and remove the advantage of inflation, for instance, and in doing so may well increase the amount of revenue that can be generated from this source. Obviously it suits the intention of the Government to get the legislation in place so that it can change it at will at some later stage. Clearly it is that which is behind its thinking.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is consistent, as we see it, with the Government's original statement. We objected to the Government's original statement. We believe that the introduction of a capital gains tax at this critical time of our national economy is absolutely stupid, crazy and in line with all of the other crazy issues that have been raised in this tax package in the past several months, which have been debated here in the past few days. The Government would have to be out of its mind to introduce at this time a tax upon incentives and investment, which clearly are so necessary to get the country out of the hole in which the Hawke Government has put it.

For the past three years this Government has faced enormous challenges and it has failed at every jump. The Government has had the opportunity, with a recovering economy and the drought having broken in 1983, to be able to deal with the deficit that obviously was not being reduced significantly and which could have been reduced further by its actions, yet it has failed to do so. Had the Government addressed itself to those issues and had it not continued the heavy program of borrowing overseas, fuelled by a very high interest rate policy, perhaps we would have seen a changed economy in Australia. Now we are about to pay the piper for three years of borrowings which have doubled the national overseas debt to a figure approaching $80 billion. The repayments on that debt are growing every day and we find that we are running into debt at the rate of $1,000m a month. Yet this Government sees fit to introduce a tax in a capital-short country such as Australia; a tax which will stop the development of investment in this country.

All the statistics that have been issued, particularly in the past few days, demonstrate that there is a crying need for investment in this economy, to create jobs, to get us out of the hole and to put us in a more competitive situation compared with countries of Asia such as Hong Kong and Singapore and countries of the growing nations such as India and China. Yet the Government sees fit to go in exactly the opposite direction. We have seen this with the foreign tax credits system, the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax.

What is wrong with this Government? When will it wake up to what is wrong with this country? Instead of imposing further costs on business, it ought to be seeking and finding ways of lifting those costs so that it can encourage business to become more competitive on world markets. Instead, it is going in precisely the wrong direction. One of the things that the Government can do to help business confidence in this country right here and now is to say that it will not proceed with the tax package. The Bills which have been passed against our opposition in the past few days can still be held up, if this Government wakes up to itself, by stopping the signature of the Governor-General from being applied to those Bills. Even now it can still help Australia by doing that. We challenge it to do that as part of a meaningful plan to turn around the Australian psyche, the confidence of Australians, so that we can encourage investment and not seek to destroy it in the way in which this Government is seeking to destroy it by the introduction of this legislation.

The capital gains tax is, I think, the fifth part of this Government's package. It has been a long time coming. It has been a disgrace that we have not known the details of this tax since September last year. We have been waiting while people have been incurring a tax liability during that time without knowing what it was that they were paying taxes on. It is only now that we see this legislation before us. The Opposition opposes it, and we will oppose it at every stage during the debate in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986. This is historic legislation and an historic debate. The Opposition is so blind that it cannot see it in that way. It is, of course, hankering after the golden age of tax avoidance and tax evasion-an age when taxation was voluntary for the wealthy; when paying one's proper share of tax was seen as aberrant; when decent and ordinary taxpayers lost faith in the fairness of the tax system. Of course, a fair tax system cannot be constructed from the values of the past. A new direction is needed. As a result of this package of tax measures, Australia's tax system is poised to enter the twentieth century.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's tax reform package will restore fairness and equity to the Australian tax system. It restores the ability to pay principle, not the ability to avoid tax. Under the old system, pay as you earn taxpayers were forced to shoulder an ever increasing tax burden, while high income earners were able to exploit rorts in the system and avoid paying tax. The tax package contains corrective measures designed to eliminate those rorts and restore equity. One of the most important corrective measures is the capital gains tax. Australia has been out of line with the other developed countries of the world until this point. We have few major taxes on assets, unlike other countries. In fact, there is a very compelling case for a capital gains tax, because the wealthy obtain increased economic welfare from increases in asset values, while ordinary taxpayers typically have assets which do not rise in value, such as bank deposits, building society deposits and the like. Yet they pay full tax on the interest income of those deposits. There is a case for a capital gains tax because realised capital gains represent an increase in purchasing power, an increase in wealth. There is a case for a capital gains tax because capital gains represent an increase in taxable capacity.

As I have indicated, under the old tax system in Australia capital gains were not taxed. This factor breaches the principle of horizontal equity-that is, those with similar economic circumstances should pay similar amounts of tax. Horizontal equity has been breached in Australia because wages and salaries have been taxed, but capital gains have not. Of course, the principle of vertical equity has been breached as well. Pay as you earn taxpayers have been taxed on every dollar they earn, while a minority in this country have received tax free gains. The ownership of capital in Australia is skewed to the wealthy. The fact that gains have been untaxed is blatantly unfair. The concession of no capital gains tax on the rich had to stop, because all taxpayers should pay their fair share of tax. The Government believes that it is only fair that those people whose economic welfare is derived from capital gains should pay their fair share of tax, like everybody else.

Australia unfortunately has been unlike the other developed countries of the world. Until now there has been no comprehensive tax on capital gains in this country. In fact, until the introduction of this legislation, of all the developed industrialised countries of the world, only Australia and the Netherlands have had no capital gains tax. Many developed countries-those with which we normally compare ourselves-have not one, not two, but three taxes on assets. They have capital gains, plus estate duties, plus an annual net wealth tax. We had no tax on assets at the national level until this point.

I would like to hark back to the Asprey report-the Taxation Review Committee-which was presented in the 1970s. The Asprey Committee was not appointed by a Labor government; it was appointed by a Liberal government. The Asprey report, when it came out, indicated that there were very strong arguments in Australia for a capital gains tax. In fact, it recommended a capital gains tax because it said it would make the Australian tax system fairer, and simpler and would help economic efficiency. That is a report which was published by a committee appointed by a Liberal government, not a Labor government. That report stated that Australia was somewhat out of the mainstream in thought and practice in this particular area. That was the report of a committee appointed by the Liberals. It said that we needed a simpler, fairer and more efficient tax system in Australia. It was totally ignored by the Party which appointed it. Until this time all we have had in the capital gains tax area has been taxation of gains where the purpose of buying assets was to make a profit-the so-called section 25a provision. We have also had section 26aaa, the so-called 12 months rule, which provided that assets bought and sold within the 12-month period were taxed at the full marginal income tax rates. That is what we have had in Australia. We have had absolutely no comprehensive tax on capital gains in this country.

In contrast to the hysterical claims of the Opposition, the capital gains tax is both sensible and moderate. The fact is that the capital gains tax will not affect the vast majority of Australian taxpayers. The family home will be exempt, despite Opposition scare campaigns that the principal residence would be taxed. The principal residence, as you will be aware, Madam Acting Deputy President, is the major asset of most Australians. It will be completely exempt from this tax. Only real capital gains accrued from the date of introduction of the tax will be taxed. That is very generous treatment, compared with the treatment of wage and salary earners. The fact is that the capital gains tax will be levied only on the real increases in the value of assets. Meanwhile, wage and salary earners are taxed on their money incomes. So it is a very generous treatment of capital gains. In fact, most countries tax the nominal gains; they do not tax real gains. They do not adjust asset values for inflation; they tax the money value of the gains. I indicate also that the capital gains tax is entirely prospective; it is not a retrospective tax. It applies only to assets purchased after a base date. In fact, it applies only to assets purchased or acquired from 20 September 1985, the day after the tax package was announced. All assets owned by taxpayers before 20 September will be exempt from the tax, both in respect of gains accrued to that date and all future gains realised on those assets.

As I have indicated, the tax will apply to real gains made on the sale of assets. That means that the owner of an asset which increases in value at no more than the general inflation rate in the community pays absolutely no tax, while owners of assets whose value increases at a greater rate than the general rate of inflation in the community will be taxed only on that part of the gain which is in excess of the inflation rate.

I believe the indexing of capital gains is a very generous concession; in certain circumstances one could argue that it is overly generous. I instance the case where asset purchases are substantially financed by borrowed funds. It is very well known in financial circles that inflation reduces the real value of borrowings anyway. People are being taxed on the asset values before borrowing, and I believe that is extremely generous. The capital gains tax will be levied at the taxpayer's ordinary rate of personal income tax or at the company tax rate and under this Government that rate will be 49c in the dollar. The capital gains tax will be levied on a realisation basis, not on an accruals basis as has been recommended in some reports. That avoids liquidity problems and also the need to have assets valued. There will be far fewer valuation problems as a result of having the tax levied on a realisation basis. Allowance will be made for realised nominal losses to be offset against capital gains in the current year or they can be carried forward.

Also, it is very important to note that negative gearing losses on rental properties will be allowed as offsets against realised capital gains; therefore, the negative gearing legislation which we have just passed is nowhere near as harsh as the Opposition would have us believe. The capital gains tax will give a complete exemption to the taxpayer's personal residence and, as I pointed out earlier this evening, that is the major asset of most Australians. That will be completely exempt from the tax. All motor vehicles will be completely exempt and other personal use items, such as furniture up to the sale value of $5,000 a year, will be exempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —One lounge suite.

—That might be so by Senator Parer's standards, but not by those of the vast majority of Australians. Capital gains with respect to superannuation and the proceeds of life insurance policies will be exempt from tax. Also expenditures incurred to improve the value of assets will be included in the cost base to be increased by the consumer price index before the real capital gain is calculated.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important to note that, despite the scare campaigns being waged in the community, the capital gains tax is not a death duty. The Government has decided that the deemed realisation at death proposal outlined in the draft White Paper of July last year will not apply, so it is not a death duty. Liability for tax in the case of death will be rolled over to successors and will be assessed only on any subsequent disposal. The tax will apply only when the rolled over asset is sold or transferred by gift. Hence, small businessmen and farmers should not be concerned that death will lead to the break up of farms and small businesses because it will not apply. The tax will be rolled over to successors. Our capital gains tax is also generous because only two other developed countries of the world which tax capital gains do not have deemed realisation at death. Most have deemed realisation at death. Those two that do not have it, have death duties.

As I have indicated, this capital gains tax will be levied on a realisation basis so that people will have cash available with which to pay the tax, unlike the situation which could apply if it were levied on an accruals basis. As it is being levied on a realisation basis at disposal, funds should be available to pay. This capital gains tax will be relatively mild, and that is reflected in the revenue estimates. I note in this context that the existing section 25A of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which raises revenue, is being abolished, so we must look at revenue collections in the context of an existing section of the Act being abolished. The capital gains tax will raise some $5m next financial year, rising to $25m in later years. It should be pointed out that most of the extra revenue will come as extra income tax, not as extra capital gains tax, because the existence of a capital gains tax shores up the base for the personal income tax. It cements in the personal income tax system. It reduces the scope to convert income, which is taxable, to capital gains, which are non-taxable.

I should indicate that possibly more revenue will be raised by the capital gains tax than has been budgeted for because the fact is that, since the Government announced its tax package, vast quantities of shares have been bought and sold on Australian stock exchanges. In fact, there has been a share market boom since the capital gains tax was announced by the Government. As a result of that boom, as a result of the buying and selling of vast numbers of shares, those shares have lost their tax exempt status. When they are resold, extra revenue will be collected by way of capital gains tax.

Clearly, those investors, those share market operators, who have been buying record numbers of company shares in recent months were not worried by the existence of a capital gains tax. They were not deterred from making their decisions to buy and sell shares. There have been record turnovers on Australian stock exchanges since this proposal was announced. The operators in the market have not been deterred by it. They have not been deterred by the nonsense of the claims from the Liberal Party of Australia that somehow incentive, whatever that is, will be affected. That has not stopped record purchases. On one day last week some $148m of shares were traded on Australian stock exchanges, after the announcement of the capital gains tax. So clearly investors on the share market see that they can live with this tax. Their record purchases day after day, week after week and month after month expose the Opposition's fear campaign for what it is. Investors are not deterred from buying shares in record amounts.

In fact, Opposition members have a pavlovian response to the concept of a capital gains tax. The mere mention of the words makes them froth at the mouth. The only exception is Senator Robert Hill, who in his 1981 maiden speech in this place supported the concept of a capital gains tax. Senator Robert Hill, the current President of the Liberal Party in South Australia, in his excellent 1981 maiden speech endorsed very strongly the notion that there should be a capital gains tax in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a principled speech.

—Yes, it was a highly principled speech, and I enjoyed reading it. It was an excellent contribution. Like other Government senators, during this debate I will be interested to see how Senator Robert Hill will vote on this legislation. In 1981 he told the people of Australia that it was time that we looked at the introduction of a capital gains tax in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's rantings about a capital gains tax usually centre on the claim that business incentive, whatever that is, will somehow be affected. If we are to believe some of the Opposition's more outlandish claims, the wheels of industry should come grinding to a halt overnight. I just point out that Australia is now joining every other Western industrialised country, with the exception of the Netherlands, in implementing a comprehensive capital gains tax. Does the Opposition seriously suggest that business incentive has been stifled in Japan? Does it seriously suggest that business incentive has been stifled in the United States of America? Does it seriously suggest that business incentive has been stifled in West Germany?

The United States of America, the home of small business and the country worshipped by the Opposition, has taxed capital gains for years. The home of free enterprise and business has taxed capital gains for years. Small business has prospered in that country. The Opposition has not even bothered to define what it means by incentive. It is not clear what specific incentive or investment it believes will be affected by the capital gains tax.

I believe that the capital gains tax will deter unproductive investment. Speculative property investment will no longer be so attractive. It will also deter tax avoidance and tax evasion. It will reduce the practice of income, which is taxable, being converted into capital gains, which are untaxable, through the use of many artificial devices. It will reduce criminal tax evasion schemes. Are these the kinds of incentives that the Opposition wants to protect? I refer to the incentive to speculate in unproductive land deals, the incentive to avoid paying taxes and the incentive to defraud the Government of revenues. I believe that the capital gains tax will channel investment away from unproductive areas to productive areas of the Australian economy.

At the National Taxation Summit last year, the Business Council of Australia, not noted for supporting the Labor Government, and the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures, not linked in any way to the Labor Government in Victoria, both supported the capital gains tax. They did not think industry would be hit by it. In fact, at the National Taxation Summit the capital gains tax was strongly and roundly endorsed by everybody as being essential for the reform of the Australian tax base. Many organisations supported the capital gains tax at the National Taxation Summit. I instance CSR Ltd, whose general manager Mr Kelman endorsed the capital gains tax. I instance the largest investment company in Australia, the Australian Mutual Provident Society, whose general manager, Mr Coates, endorsed the capital gains tax.

The buoyancy of national share markets since the announcement of the tax reforms contradicts Opposition claims of an imminent collapse in business activity. The share market index has hit record highs day after day, week after week and month after month. Contrary to the misleading allegations of the Opposition the Government's tax package will not raise the level of taxation in this country. It proposes a redistribution of taxation, not an increase in the overall burden. The tax redistribution will be based on the capacity to pay principle rather than on the ability to cheat. This is what the Opposition parties are objecting to.

The coalition parties are objecting to the elimination of unfair privileges that have allowed a wealthy minority to exploit the tax system. The capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax will tax those sources of income which for too long have benefited the wealthy minority at the expense of ordinary taxpayers. The revenue raised from the capital gains tax will be redistributed to help finance tax cuts for ordinary Australians. I simply point out that a relatively small group of people will pay this tax. The great majority of Australians will receive tax cuts as a result of the Government's package. The top marginal rate of income tax will be reduced from 60c in the dollar to 49c. The most common rate at the moment-46c in the dollar-will be reduced to 40c and the bottom rate of 25c in the dollar will be reduced to 24c.

Those tax cuts will be financed by measures such as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. The revenue from those taxes is vital to finance the income tax reductions for many Australians. The important thing to note is that under Labor the bottom marginal income tax rate will be 24c in the dollar. The best that Mr Howard, the current Leader of the Opposition and former Treasurer, could manage in five Budgets as Treasurer of this country was 30c in the dollar. Our bottom tax rate will be 24c in the dollar. Clearly, Labor is the low tax party in this country.

The capital gains tax will not have any of the dire effects predicted by the Opposition. Its claims are based on dogmatic assertion rather than on rational economic analysis. They are based on self-interest rather than on the public good. They are based on fear rather than on responsibility. The Government's intention is to ensure that all taxpayers pay their share of tax. That is what the capital gains tax is designed to do. It will bring Australia into line with nearly every other developed country in the world. It will redistribute the tax burden. It will reinstate the principles of fairness and equity to the very centre of the tax system. It will make the economy more efficient. It will result in better allocation of resources. That will be good for the future growth of Australia. The capital gains tax is a common sense measure. It is a long overdue measure. It is a twentieth century measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats believe that a capital gains tax is a necessity in any developed country, and it has been Democrats policy since the Party's foundation in 1977-a policy, I might add, that was directly voted in by all our members. Our members represent a cross-section of the Australian community. Australia is the odd country out in the developed world in that it has not had a capital gains tax. The European countries, including Great Britain, the United States and Japan all have such a tax. Both social democratic and conservative governments alike have seen capital gains taxes as a necessary part of the tax system.

SPEECH.PARA: Why have we not had a capital gains tax in Australia? I believe the answer to that is simple. It is that powerful interest groups could not think, and are not now prepared to think, on a truly national basis. Tax avoidance cannot be clamped down on unless we have a capital gains tax. In the early 1980s all sorts of distortions began to appear in the tax system and progressively more and more of the tax burden in this country was being placed on the poor pay as you earn taxpayer. The tax system which had developed essentially meant that if a person was on wages, the Government could get its hands on his income but if he was on a non-wage income, he may not have had to pay any tax at all. That attitude was encouraged in no small measure by the High Court of Australia at that time. This attitude of the late 1970s and early 1980s had its logical conclusion in the bottom of the harbour rorts. They were so blatant and costing the Government so much revenue that the Treasurer at the time, Mr John Howard, was forced eventually to act against them.

The only way we can have a fair tax system in this country is to have a capital gains tax. I believe this is basic, it is axiomatic and it is beyond dispute by any reasonable, fair-minded Australian. It is the only way that all classes of income can be treated in the same way. I congratulate the Government on implementing a capital gains tax at the relevant marginal rate of tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has happened to your promise to keep them honest?

—The honourable senator will get her turn later. It has long been Democrats policy that the capital gains tax should be levied at the marginal rate. It is something that the Democrats called for from the outset of the tax debate. To have a lower rate of capital gains tax is to encourage the conversion of income into capital. That is the very thing that a capital gains tax is designed to prevent. Interestingly, a part of the new tax package developed by the United States Senate is to change the capital gains tax in that country from one levied at a flat rate to one levied at the marginal rate.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that a capital gains tax will have many beneficial effects in this country. It will promote equity in the tax system by ensuring that all bear a fair share of the tax burden. It will end the opportunity to avoid tax through schemes designed to turn income into capital and it will encourage the very thing that I so often and almost tirelessly call for in this place-productive investment. At present, there is an incentive to put money into things such as land which returns tax-free capital gains. This simply pushes up the price of land and it encourages speculation. The investor and the speculator, of course, are very happy about this because what they want to see is the price of land rise at as fast a rate as possible. The only person to suffer under this scenario is the first home buyer. During the property boom in Sydney in the early 1980s prices were rising so quickly that an average couple could not save enough money for a deposit. Prices were rising faster than they could save.

TALK.START.PARA: —The demand was greater than the supply.

—In a country the size of the United States of America, with 15 million people? Let us be sensible. The Australian Democrats are very proud of the input we have had into the planning of this capital gains tax, both in our initial discussions with the Government before the National Taxation Summit last year, during the Taxation Summit, and during our negotiations with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in December last year. I believe that the Democrats' intervention has ensured that the capital gains tax is equitable and non-punitive.
—How did you do that?

—I am going to list no less than eight very important concessions that the Democrats gained to ensure that the capital gains tax, as we are now debating it and as it has been put in the legislation before us, will be non-punitive and equitable. The eight concessions that the Democrats take credit for are these: Firstly, we stipulated that the tax should not be retrospective. There was, in fact, no attempt to tax gains before the implementation of the tax. It is very doubtful whether that would have happened without the Democrats' initiative in that area. Secondly, we also said that the tax should be indexed to take into account inflation. In this way, only the real gains would fall into the tax net-not paper gains made purely as a result of movements in the consumer price index. Interestingly, most countries that have a flat rate capital gains tax, such as the United States of America, do not index that tax for inflation. This means that gains over a long period are taxed more harshly with a flat tax than will be the case in Australia with our capital gains tax at the marginal rates but indexed for inflation, which is a very important point. If there is an incentive to put money into long-term investments this is precisely what we want and precisely what we will have with an indexed capital gains tax at the marginal rate.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, we advocated that capital losses should be offset against capital gains and that any further input of capital after the purchase of an asset should be indexed and added to the cost of that asset. I am happy to say that this is part of the legislation. Fourthly, in the early stages of the debate on capital gains we spoke out very strongly, insisting that the family home should not be part of the capital gains tax. This is very desirable and it is fair since the home is not a traded asset in most cases; it is merely a place to live and, when we sell it, we have to buy another one. The fifth concession for which the Democrats take credit is that the Government initially was planning to deem realisation of a capital gain at death. As a result of our protests, the Government changed that approach. The sixth benefit that I believe the Democrats won from the Government, after the capital gains tax was announced, was to get the Government to consider the problem of goodwill for small businesses. In this legislation the Government has gone part of the way to meeting our requirements to take goodwill into account in the case of small businesses. The Government had said that it would give concessions on new businesses only. We felt that was not fair enough and was not in the spirit of our initial discussions on this matter. The Government has since agreed that all small businesses, and not just new businesses, will be subject to a reduction of the capital gains tax for goodwill. We will be moving an amendment in this area in the Committee stage. This concession is very important because small business people often work very long hours for very little money, preferring to put all their returns back into the business to enable it to expand. The goodwill component is the intangible human input into a business. By giving small businesses this concession we are encouraging hard work and recognising the often poor financial rewards of a proprietor as he or she builds up his business.

The seventh concession we gained from the Government, and which we believe is very important, is that employee share ownership will not be discouraged as a result of the capital gains tax. Under the tax as it was originally proposed, if an employer were to sell his shares he would have had to pay tax on the difference between the discounted price of the share and the sales price. That is reasonable. But the Government went further. It said that a capital gains tax had to be paid on the shares even before the shares were sold, as they had appreciated during the time they were being purchased. This would have discouraged employee share purchasing. The Government has seen our point of view and has eliminated the realisation of capital gains on employee share purchases before they are sold.

The eighth concession the Democrats negotiated with the Government concerns the averaging of capital gains over a period of five years. Farmers and other people often have incomes which vary substantially from year to year. This has been recognised by the Government, which has allowed people whose incomes fluctuate violently to have their incomes averaged over five years. This is a reasonable principle to apply in the case of a capital gains tax as capital gains are won over a period of years, not one year. To tax capital gains in one year at a very high marginal rate of tax in many cases would be very unfair.

I believe that we now have a capital gains tax which is fair. It makes no distinction between income earned personally and income which results from capital appreciation. It treats all income in the same way. It is very significant that we are introducing this legislation now, when the United States is only just beginning to consider doing the same thing. The US is now proposing to treat all income in the same way. We have a capital gains tax which undoubtedly will enable the Government to crack down on tax rorts. For that reason alone one would have thought that the Opposition would have been prepared to concede that something had to be done in this area. It escapes my comprehension how there can be an outcry such as we have heard tonight about a capital gains tax when we are the only country in the Western world which for so long has not had one, when we have gone through the disgusting spectacle of the late 1970s with the bottom of the harbour tax rorts, and when we see people making enormous amounts of money overnight from speculations in their shares and other areas while the pay as you earn taxpayer pays, in many cases, a marginal tax rate of above 60 per cent on the results of his personal efforts. We support this capital gains tax. We think it is as good now as it could be. We look forward to seeing after 30 June many of the tax rorts that have prevailed in this country for so long being eliminated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia does not need a new capital gains tax. We already have very effective legislation on the books against speculative capital gains.
