I suppose as the first advanced country to go back to Third World status we are entitled to have all the accoutrements of a Third World country. Certainly this punitive capital gains tax, the heaviest capital gains tax in the whole world, fits in with the Third World status that the Labor Party has taken us back to.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to spend very long dealing with the previous speakers who have supported the concept of a capital gains tax. The point that they do not understand when they talk about other countries is that the whole tax take in other countries is considerably less than it is in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What countries?

—I do not think that any of the speakers, including the Minister for Finance, who is speaking from profound ignorance at present, have ever lived outside Australia, let alone paid tax outside Australia. I have lived for a large part of my life outside Australia and I have paid tax in several different countries. I paid my full tax entitlement while I lived there. I have never lived in a country that taxed me more heavily than the Commonwealth of Australia. When we are talking about the United States of America, the academic armchair theorists on the other side do not understand that the actual personal income tax level and the other taxations that are placed on citizens in that country, particularly the man trying to raise a family, are very much less and are probably of the order of half what they are in Australia. That has to be taken into account when the Government is trying to milk the cow.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia already has very effective legislation against capital gains. Section 25a and section 26aaa provide all the legislative power if the Government and the Australian Taxation Office have the courage and the competence to apply the law, but they do not. That is why we have some evasion. But section 25a covers the intention when a person purchases something to make a profit. If he purchases it with the intention of making a profit on resale, it does not matter how long he owns that asset, he is obliged to pay tax under the law. Section 26aaa is even more stringent. It does not matter what a person buys, if he sells it within 12 months he has to pay capital gains tax on it. This legislation has been in place in Australia for years. It covers the objectionable part of speculation that the Labor Party is carrying on about. All we need is the will to prosecute the law.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating), in his second reading speech in the other place, makes a very great thing about people who take income in the form of capital gains and avoid paying income tax on it, but the legislation is there to prevent it. Apart from section 25a and section 26aaa, there are other more sophisticated and additional measures on the books and they are all that we need to cover the people who are beating their entitlement to pay tax.

Why do we not need a new tax? The very basic point is that Australia is short of capital. What we ought to do in Australia is guide and encourage people to a degree of frugality so that they look after themselves. But what does a Labor government do? Frugality is a dirty word for it. It encourages prodigality: Spend everything. Spend all one can. Spend everything every week so that at the end of the day one is dependent on the government. That way one will support the Labor Party; one will be dependent on it for everything.

Australians historically have a very low level of personal savings. Under this Government the personal family debt in Australia is the highest it has ever been in its history. It is about 50 per cent above the historical average levels. Why would we not be in debt at present when we are being hit with some of the heaviest taxes in the world-certainly some of the highest taxes of any of the advanced countries. We have lavish welfare programs. I do not mind-I support-welfare payments going to those in need, but we have fraud, incompetence in the administration and a Minister who is not prepared to police his Department, who gives money away without any sense of audit at all. Why should that be the case? To do that sort of thing we have to have heavy taxation.

If Australians do not save, how do we develop the country? We have to borrow money from overseas to bring money in. That is not good for us because we have to pay it back and we have to pay interest on the money we borrow. Why can we not encourage Australians to build their own capital so that we can do the essential development in this country? Let us look at this business of putting a disincentive on savings. If people do not save, if people do not put money in the banks, the banks simply do not have money to lend. In Japan, where there is the highest level of savings in the world, the Japanese banks are flush with money. In Japan if one wants to borrow money to start a small business one can get interest rates of around 5 or 6 per cent. In Australia, where we do not have a high level of savings and money is reasonably scarce, plus we have the positive policy of this Government to run a crippling high interest rate, Australian businesses have to borrow at 18 per cent, at best, but probably at 22 per cent or upwards to get going.

The very real effect of that in the commercial world is that a lot of businesses simply cannot start at a level of 18 to 20 per cent interest on borrowed money whereas they could employ people and they could prosper if they could get money at 6 per cent. But that is not the Labor ethos. Labor does not want people to look after themselves; everything that is an incentive to people's financial growth and independence has to be repressed and banned.

Earlier this week we debated the fringe benefits tax Bills. A direct effect of that legislation will be to depress economic activity in Australia and to lower the standard of living. We are going to get exactly the same consequence with the capital gains legislation. It will primarily affect small business and it will also depress the standard of living of Australians. The Government tells us it is introducing this legislation to get tax money and to prevent avoidance. One of the indirect consequences of this legislation is that there will be positive incentives put in the paths of people to beat the tax wherever they can because the law is getting so much more complicated. The Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill alone is 103 pages in its printing. Just imagine the feast the lawyers and the accountants are going to have trying to interpret this little section about capital gains tax. Just think of the loopholes in 103 pages, because quite certainly the Treasurer does not understand it and nor will the people in the Taxation Office. We will get an increase in tax evasion and in the black economy as a result of this legislation.

Another very important reason against a capital gains tax is that it kills off the entrepreneurial spirit in Australia. It does it in two ways. First of all, the small businessman who wants to get going, build up a family business with his wife and his children and employ people-a major area of employment in Australia-is discouraged from doing so. The other side of it is in the high technology field. The free enterprise system has been responsible for the great increase in the standard of living in the last 100 years of the Western democracies. It is not the governments with their welfare payments that have lifted the standard of living; the standard of living has been lifted because of the free enterprise system. It has been the profits that have been made, the employment that has been generated and the taxes that have been generated through these economic systems that have given us the lift in the standard of living that we enjoy today.

The free enterprise system is a two-way street. It gives people the right to make a profit and to retain that profit, but it also gives people the right to go broke. Under the one-eyed Australian Labor Party, the only right one has is the right to go broke. One does not have the right to make a profit, one does not have the incentive to make a profit and one certainly does not have a chance in the world of retaining the money that comes as a profit from the exercise engaged in. There is nothing wrong with working hard, taking risks and making a profit, except if one is a Labor voter. The ability to make money turns on two factors. First of all, there is one's personal ability and the economic environment in the society in which one is living and trading at the time. That is in part a measure of the individual qualities of the entrepreneurs and in part the legislation of the government of the day. The second part of the equation, the ability to retain profits, is purely a matter for the government of the day. The government of the day, by the tax legislation it puts in place, dictates the ability of someone to retain the profits from their entrepreneurial ability. Therefore, the Government has a very direct relationship to the incentives for people to strive and to grow economically, or not to grow.

All industrial countries recognise that new industries-high technology industries using modern science and technology-have great economic benefits. Those great economic benefits are not restricted to the owner-entrepreneur. They flow through the whole society and benefit everyone. The rising tide lifts all the boats. Those countries in the Western world that are doing best-and there are no countries doing well on the other side of the Iron Curtain with their socialist economies-are those with the greatest entrepreneurial freedom. It does not matter whether someone makes $100,000 profit or $100m profit through a company provided that person is paying the company tax and other taxes placed upon him. It is quite proper for such people to retain the balance of their profits after they have paid their company tax. However, it is not proper to the Labor Party. The Labor Party much prefers its takeover friends who support it with campaign funds and who borrow hundreds of millions or billions of dollars overseas in order to take over Australian companies. These people create no new jobs. They create no new export markets at all. They strip us of the profitability of the companies they take over because the profitability goes in interest payments, thereby denuding the Treasury of those funds. That is the sort of thing that the Labor Party in government has supported. In the history of Australia we have never seen such a rape of Australian industry by asset strippers as has taken place under this Government. It has taken place because this is the sort of policy that the Labor Party wants. The final reason why we should not have a capital gains tax comes from the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself. He said:
And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax.

The Prime Minister said that at the Sydney Opera House on 16 February 1983. Like every other promise from the bodgie king, it has been broken. Why did Labor change? Why did Labor break its promise? It did so because it is part of the Labor doctrine and part of the Labor ethos. The Labor Party wants to tax middle Australia out of existence. We are paying the highest taxes we have ever paid. We have the introduction of death duties in the guise of this capital gains tax. We have a fringe benefits tax. We have an exorbitant excise rate. We are paying a huge amount in excise now on petrol. What is worse, the damn thing is indexed. It is sneaking up surreptitiously every few months because the Treasurer excised the rate of excise duty. What is happening is that middle Australia is being reduced to mendicant status. We are seeing the independence of middle Australia reduced so that in the end we will all be dependent with our begging bowls on a Labor government for sustenance.

The second reason Labor has done this is that it is part of its mythology that there is a huge pool of unpaid taxes out there in the community just waiting to be collected. That is not true. There is no vast pool of money out there due to the Treasury. It simply does not exist. When the Labor Party looks at people selling capital assets at a higher price than they paid for them, it fails to understand that that increased price largely comes as a consequence of inflation. It looks at inflation and at the artificially reduced figures, the indices of inflation that it puts up under its regime. As any housewife would know, under Labor the actual level of inflation is probably 5 per cent or 8 per cent higher than the Australian Statistician's figures. It is the effect of inflation more than anything else that has increased the value of assets in Australia. The sad part about this is that it was the Labor Party which gave us this inflation. It was the mad economic irresponsibility of all those years of Whitlam, the wild spending, which set the fires of inflation burning in Australia and which we have been unable to control for over 10 years. That situation has been eclipsed by the Hawke regime, because now we have the biggest deficits, the highest taxes and the highest borrowings ever to occur in Australia's history.

What is in this Bill? We have a capital gains tax of which the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats are so proud. However, what they did not say was that it is the most savage capital gains tax in the world. It is at the highest level ever. Why do we need this tax, when other countries in the world are retreating from capital gains tax? Senator Siddons referred to the situation in the United States of America. I have news for him. The United States has never had a capital gains tax as high as Australia's proposed capital gains tax. The United States has progressively reduced the level of its capital gains tax and I believe that in the fullness of time it will have no capital gains tax. It has had the opportunity to experience its operation and to assess the negative effect of such a punitive tax on economic activity. But we are going to have it, and we will have the highest in the world.

It is a tax that will be punitive on small business. Such businesses often involve the battler who perhaps undertakes to start a business with his wife. He works for many hours a week, perhaps 100 or 120 hours a week, trying to make a living. He does not have a 17 1/2 per cent annual loading on his holidays, because he does not have holidays. He does not have four weeks annual leave that the unionists such as Senator Maguire have. He does not have penalty rates when he works a Sunday or a Saturday night. He does not have a 38-hour week, or a nine-day fortnight so dear to the union movement. He does not have redundancy deals and a golden handshake if he cannot earn a living. He never gets maternity or paternity leave. He does not get the national wage increases, and he will not get the superannuation carve-up that the unions are going for. The little guy in small business works his fingers to the bone building up an asset that he can sell at the end of his working days so that he and his wife can retire and look after themselves, and not be a penalty on the Australian taxpayer. That poor little guy will be hit with a heavy capital gains tax at the end of 30 or 40 years hard labour. Is that justice? Is that the sort of society we want for Australia? It is certainly not one that I want.

The Labor Party has excluded the family home from these provisions, but it has not excluded the farm. It has not excluded the properties in the country, the cattle properties and the sheep properties. The great earners of export income for Australia through this form of death duty will be subjected to crippling imposts. But the family home will be free. I am happy that the family home is free, but I would like all capital and assets to be free. By introducing this freedom for the home a great perversion has been introduced into the taxation scheme. People will build an extra wing or storey on their house, thus overcapitalising the asset, because that asset will be free of a capital gains tax. There will be a huge distortion in the market-place, but the Labor Party does not understand that. When the Government has a Treasurer whose economic background before he came into the Parliament was selling solid gold watches in Kings Cross at midnight, one can expect the sorts of policies that we have.

We have policies which will hit not only the shopkeepers and the tradesmen but also the little people, such as the guy who keeps some stamps, who keeps some coins, who potters around with old cars. When he comes to sell those assets he will be hit with this savage tax. But more than that, he will have the incredible worry of trying to establish what he paid for it, what he has put into it, what the market value of it is now, and deal with all the mindless insensitivity of the bureaucracy-all for no purpose whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fellow who does some paintings.

—Yes. The nastiest of all, of course, is the attack on the charities. The spirit of humanity, the spirit of benevolence in the Australian community is now being taxed in the most appalling way possible. When I die and leave a house or an asset to a church in order to help them look after people in need, my estate will have to pay capital gains tax on that asset. There will be a total prohibition on people doing that sort of thing. But from a government which only this week gave us a capital gains tax on charities, and the savage and inhuman way it did this, at least this is consistent.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is totally unnecessary because there is adequate legislation on the books at present. It is stupid legislation because it places no reward for effort in the Australian financial or commercial world. It is grossly unfair and inhuman in the way it operates against charities. The 103 pages are extraordinarily complicated. Once it is in place the Australian community can look forward with absolute certainty that as this Government spends itself deeper and deeper into debt the rates will go up savagely year by year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard from Senator MacGibbon in his usual robust style a speech in which he analyses how this tax will affect certain people in the community. He said-and this is correct-that the impact on people of any taxation is not nice. That is a statement with which many of us, including those people listening in, would agree. Nobody likes paying taxes. Nobody likes paying anything, I suppose, if they can hold on to the money.
—I don't.

—As Senator Tate says, he doesn't. That tax is bad, that tax falls on particular people in certain instances and that tax is harsh is something we all acknowledge. The Opposition, with great respect, is saying: `We don't like taxes'. Of course, nobody likes taxes. But if we are to live in a community, if we are to have a defence force, if we are to run education and all those sorts of accoutrements of civilisation of which we are all so justly proud, somebody has to pay. The people who have been paying in the past have been the pay as you earn taxpayers; they are the people who have shouldered the burden.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider the person who is out in the morning on the job and comes home to his wife and children; perhaps even the wife has to work. There they are, trying to make their way in life in the city or in the country. And what happens? They pay their taxes which are due. They say: `Why doesn't my neighbour pay tax?' We say: `He does not have to pay tax because he had, or she had, the ability to transfer that income into capital. We have made capital sacrosanct'. Those opposite say we can prey upon-rip off if one likes-and tax the wage earner, the person who goes out and by the sweat of his or her brow works up a job, a career, but throughout that career pays money from the earnings that he or she makes; but the person who has the means and ability to live by capital is exempt and has to pay absolutely nothing. It is not fair at all. Senator MacGibbon said that it was not fair. He pointed out, and quite correctly-and approved of, as I understand it-that a capital gains tax already exists under section 25a and section 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Senator Crichton-Browne, a man of great fairness, whom I see sitting opposite, also agrees with that. So the fact is that everybody approves of the capital gains tax. Indeed, Senator MacGibbon says that we should go back and make section 25a and section 26aaa work. We say that that is exactly what we are doing by introducing this legislation. We are doing what the Opposition has demanded we do. Not only do we say that; we say that if we go along with the Opposition we are a little concerned that its approach to the capital gains tax may be too harsh. We say that our provisions will not have the effect that sections 25a and 26aaa would have. We say that would include the family home, and because our Government has regard for the family and has a great passion to see that the ordinary family man is justly treated, we say that we will not tax the family home. Sections 25a and 26aaa, as they now stand and as the Opposition want them to remain as the way of gathering taxes on capital advancement, are not the sort of thing we want. We will exempt the family home because we regard the family as sacrosanct.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about a bachelor's home?

—I would say to Senator Tate that this Government even goes so far-and I think that perhaps we are wrong in this-as to exempt bachelors from having to pay tax on capital gains on their home. That is a matter of some concern.

SPEECH.PARA: No doubt Senator Parer, Senator Brownhill and Senator Boswell will speak in approval of sections 25a and 26aaa. Senator MacGibbon has already done so. They will say they feel that there should be some sort of tax on increments from capital, but they will also say that the way in which this Government is tackling the matter is wrong. The general thrust, I believe, of what they are saying-and they can correct me if I am wrong-is correct. If it is not correct, are they saying that they will deny the ordinary working man and woman, the person who battles his or her way through life, the tax cuts that this Government has so desperately sought to put on the books? That is what this Government is all about. It wants to make those tax deductions and it has been prevented from doing so because of the efforts of the Opposition. I cannot discover what the basis of their opposition to this argument is.

Opposition members have asked what the Government intends to do about the small business person. We are doing plenty, and indeed we are doing two positive things. We shall reduce the rate of his or her income tax and we will leave more money in the pockets of more people who can expend that and increase consumption. The other aspect will be to ensure that instead of money being put into land to lie there fallow waiting for land values to go up so that people can gain, without tax, money they have made no effort to earn, it will go into productive factories, farm lands, shops and industries throughout the country. Because of the redirection of money people will have more jobs, Australia will be more prosperous, and this country will get under way as should have happened many years ago.

Because no proper consideration has been given to a capital gains tax, investment has been poor. Not only was there no capital gains tax during the 1970s, but because of bottom of the harbour schemes money was available in big lumps and in great proportions for people to invest in industry. But what did they do? They did not invest that money. They went on overseas trips, they bought luxury cars from overseas, and they did all sorts of things that did not help industries here. The people who enjoyed that great advantage in the 1970s did not invest in the ways in which this tax will induce them to invest. It is all very well to come along and talk about some person who may be affected by this. But what about the thousands and thousands of people on the other hand who are going to benefit from these tax cuts? Of course, as Senator Maguire so eloquently pointed out, it is not a matter of raising extra taxes; it is a matter of redistributing the taxes that already are gained.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak tonight about a film which has had a lot of publicity in the last few days. I think I am unusual in that I am one of the very few Australians who have actually viewed that film. The film is called Hail Mary in Australia. However, the original title of this French language film is Je Vous Salue, Marie, which is not quite the same thing in that it can also be translated as `I greet you Mary'. So, in fact to call the film Hail Mary is perhaps to give a false impression in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I saw the film last year. I found that to be a pleasurable, exciting and moving experience. A year later, I am appalled to find that that film is being attacked by a number of people in Australia. As far as I can determine, very few, if any, of those people have actually seen the film. I find that horrifying in itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you see it in French?
—I saw it in French, which I speak, with sub-titles.
—Do you mean you speak French with sub-titles?

—Yes, I can. The honourable senator should try me some time. Concern about this film has been raised during Question Time in both the Senate and the other place. Also, I understand that it was the subject of speeches during the adjournment debate last night in the other place. In every case the matter has been raised by people who have not viewed the film and who are acting in response to a rather hysterical campaign whipped up, again, by people who, as far as I know, on the whole, have not seen the film.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Film Censorship Board unanimously decided to classify the film-in other words, to pass it for showing in Australia. I understand that the only disagreement among the nine members of the Board was whether it should be classified `M' or `R'. I think the lack of agreement in that case indicates that the film is certainly not pornographic, as some people have claimed. It is said that the film is blasphemous. I do not claim to be an expert in what people perceive as being blasphemous. However, I would have thought that other films which have been freely available in the past would be more likely to come into that category. One example would be the Life of Brian. This could also be said about many television shows such as the Dave Allen Show which has recently been on television in Melbourne and Monty Python which might be perceived as being far more blasphemous than this film.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are your standards of blasphemy?

—As I said, I do not claim to be an expert in blasphemy. However, I certainly feel that I have more right to speak about this film than those who have not viewed it. I think that people who are likely to be offended by it would have been more offended by the Life of Brian, which I have also seen. One of the interesting things about the current furore over this film is that at least the majority of those protesting have not seen it. Yet, they are willing to pass very vocal judgment. I saw the film in a school hall in Locarno in Switzerland last year where it was a part of the world famous Locarno Film Festival. I stress that Switzerland is a country with a very predominantly Christian population. It probably has a higher average church attendance, both Protestant and Catholic, than is the case in this country. Indeed, a large monastery in the town virtually overshadows the place where the festival was held. I read the reviews in the French language papers from both France and Switzerland in the week following the initial showing of the film. There was certainly no criticism of the sort that we have heard here. There was no outcry from the people who, again, had the opportunity to see the film. I add, too, that being able to read the French newspapers was an advantage. I was with my son at the time, who speaks German, and he read the German language papers. Again, there was no outcry there, either, and why should there be?
—Did he see the film?

—Yes, he saw it with me. First, it was made by a renowned director. I do not know how many people here are film buffs, but those who are would have certainly heard of Jean-Luc Godard, himself a Christian and, according to some sources that I have not been able to check out completely, and I have not been able to ask him myself, a Catholic. I found it a thoughtful and sensitive film and I find it hard to imagine that any sensible person could read into it what it is alleged to show. Before I say anything more about it, I would like to read a few reviews that come from Catholic sources so that I cannot be accused of picking my reviews with bias.
—Is it Catholic?
—It is from Catholic sources.
—What about the Anglicans?
—The Anglicans do not seem to have been inflamed by this in the same way as the Catholics have. Hugh Kay of the British Catholic paper, the Month, writes:

SPEECH.PARA: At a time when the virgin birth is under fire as never before . . . this film re-asserts it. It is a plea for the ideals of chastity, for recognition of the primacy of the spirit, and of the mysterious ways in which God deals with men and women. Mary is presented . . . as a very attractive girl . . . confused and uncertain, whose act of faith and submission is extremely costly to her.
Dorothy Fothergill, writing in the same Catholic paper, the Month, says:

Mary (Myriem Roussel) is shown as a young girl of great integrity, deep awareness of unseen reality, moral strength, imagination, serenity-a quite credible outfit for Mary of Nazareth. Like Joan of Arc, she hears her `voice' that supports her. She has a certain nobility even when, out of sympathy with Joseph's agony in mind, she acts with a degree of today's sexual freedom that may well be a shock to the sensibilities of the faithful, east and west, accustomed to revere the Mother of Christ as the Mother of God, and it was undoubtedly the reason for the film's `18' certificate.

That is a certificate allowing the film to be shown only to those over 18. It is the equivalent of our `R' certificate. The International Catholic Organisation for Cinema and Audio-Visual issued this statement at the announcement of official awards at the Berlin International Film Festival on 26 February 1985:

Aware of the difficulties due to the originality of its form and subject, the OCIC jury unanimously wishes to state its interest in Jean-Luc Godard's film Je Vous Salue, Marie, and in particular to mention its revolutionary approach to this theme. Godard delicately uses an ancient creed in his attempt to solve the inexplicable mystery of life and love, illustrating the connections between sensuality and purity, the physical and the metaphysical, the reconciliation of the mundane and the spiritual. The OCIC jury urges an unprejudiced approach to the film.
Peter Stanford, writing in the Catholic Herald, states:

Godard's modern Mary, as she has been inaccurately dubbed, is the basketball-playing daughter of a petrol station manager. In many ways she is surprisingly orthodox for one who has caused such a furore across the continent of Europe. The central concepts of the annunciation and the virgin birth are upheld and in fact adorned with a reverence that is all the more immediate for its contemporary setting. The fact that Mary serves petrol and Joseph drives a taxi are modern day equivalents of what ordinary people in Galilee might well have done 2000 years ago. After all, are today's school children not encouraged to fashion their productions of the nativity around modern settings?

They are just a few of the reviews from those sorts of sources. Some critics have given the impression that the film has been widely banned overseas. This is, in fact, not so. Action has been taken, for example, in Versailles in France, which seems to be the place where all this furore came from originally, but it was action taken on grounds of blasphemy and it was rejected by the court. Similarly, in Pesaro in Italy the film was taken to court, which again rejected the application. Director Godard himself withdrew the film from exhibition in Rome in deference to the wishes of the Pope-he said he did that with some pain.

I would like now to refer to some of the allegations that have been made about this film, specifically some remarks made in the other place last night. A comment was made that it `portrays the Virgin Mary as a foul mouthed woman'. I would say that it is only in the eyes of the viewer that this character Marie represents the Virgin Mary; it is not stated in the film. She is certainly not foul mouthed by the current standards of the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose standards?

—The standards of the Australian community-your standards. It has also been said-I have read this in a number of places-that Mary derives pleasure from the infant Jesus fondling her. Again, viewers may have identified the child as Jesus Christ, but it is not stated that the child is and I regard that allegation as a very sick interpretation of the normal actions of motherly affection. I hope that everyone, male or female, derives pleasure from the affections of their children. There is nothing wrong with that. As for the Angel Gabriel being portrayed as `an unshaven child molester', I have no memory of such a character in the film behaving that way or of any character whom I identified as the Angel Gabriel, but perhaps that is a reflection of the fact that although I attended a Christian school I have not maintained an absorbing interest in biblical details.
—He was a baddie.

—Senator Crichton-Browne will have to tell me about him. Allegations have been made about shocking nudity. The only nudity I can recall in the film was a totally non-erotic scene where Marie is looking in wonder at the changes to her own body brought about by pregnancy, which is a feeling I am sure all women who have had children would share; certainly not what has been implied about it. I mention a few of the other phrases which have been ascribed to the film, all by people who have not seen it: `A gross piece of rubbish', `trash', `a hopelessly boring art film', `offensive' and `porno blasphemous'. The last remark was made in this chamber yesterday. Again, all those people had not seen the film. I have received no letters of complaint, but maybe that is because the film festival where, I understand, the film will be shown for the first time next week is in Sydney. It is interesting that that sort of interest has not been shown elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, speaking as a psychologist, I find it clinically interesting-perhaps that is the politest way to put it-that people have interpreted the film and have made quotations about it such as `trash', `porno blasphemous'-whatever that might mean-and so on. I am also very disappointed that so many Australians could be so easily misled into canning a film about which they have obviously very little knowledge and certainly no direct knowledge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the past 12 months or so I have met some people who have gone to Queensland but have returned to their home States because they could not find work. As a senator for Queensland this distresses me. Those people have seen Queensland as a State of opportunity, but have been disillusioned when they have reached there. Queensland is a State of opportunity, but it is being held back by the current National Party Government in Queensland. This evening I wish to outline to the Senate how the mismanagement of the State's economy has resulted in a loss of jobs in a Commonwealth instrumentality.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been informed that at least 100 jobs will be lost in Telecom Australia over the next financial year in Queensland. Telecom has planned not to fill 107 technical positions in Queensland during the next financial year, due principally to the decline in the Queensland economy. More than 100 jobs in the technical section alone which will become vacant through natural wastage will not be filled. As the jobs will be lost through natural wastage, no one who has a job at the moment will be in danger of losing his job, but because those 100 jobs in the technical section will not be filled, job opportunities will be severely limited for the remaining employees. Naturally, this is a matter of some concern, both to Telecom and to the principal union, the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association. The ATEA has taken up this matter with Telecom and is committed to maintaining existing staff levels.

It is my information that ATEA is recommending to Telecom to take on additional work to compensate for the decreasing demand for Telecom services in Queensland. This decline is directly related to the precarious and uncertain state of the Queensland economy. It is not often mentioned, but the rate of new telephone connections is widely accepted as an indicator of economic performance. Keeping that in mind, for the three months to March this year Queensland had a decline of 19.4 per cent in new telephone connections compared with the figure for the same period the year before. This was by far the worst result of any State. The rate of new telephone connections is just another indication of how Queensland is lagging behind the rest of Australia in economic performance. It is because of this that Telecom has been forced to look at not filling the 107 technical positions in the next financial year.

The ailing nature of the Queensland economy has been documented for some time. It has been documented in this chamber and in public statements in Queensland by a number of people, including most recently one of the National Party's own trustees. Queensland businesses and employees are now beginning to feel the effects of an economically illiterate State government. Queensland residents should not assume that Telecom is the only employer affected by the State's sick economy. The effects of the Bjelke-Petersen Government's economic ineptitude are widespread and becoming more apparent. No employer in Queensland can remain unaffected by factors such as Queensland suffering a record number of bankruptcies, a dramatic increase in industrial disputes and unemployment rising against the national trend.

I mention this matter tonight because it is not often recognised that the economic situation in Queensland is reaching into businesses and now into Commonwealth instrumentalities. It is a matter of concern to the Commonwealth instrumentality and the union that covers people in Telecom that this sort of thing is happening in Queensland. I am not sure what we, as a Commonwealth government, can do to arrest the situation that has occurred in Queensland, quite against the trend throughout Australia. However, I urge the National Party Government in Queensland, in its dying days in office, to look at what is happening in Queensland to see whether, in the few months that it has left in office, it can reverse those trends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Zakharov on her very level headed and sensitive contribution on the subject of the film Hail Mary as to which she is infinitely better informed than any other parliamentarian and most of the ecclesiastics who have so far contributed to this discussion. She is better informed insofar as she alone it seems, among all those who have raised their voices or the ones we have heard about most noisily, has actually seen the film. I think her speech was a very useful antidote to some of the conspicuously ill-informed, foaming and frothing that we have heard on this subject and I hope that it will be very widely read, although I suppose it is not likely to be any more evident to the public eye than any other speech that is made at this hour of the night.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, I hope that Senator Colston's speech, a compassionate account of yet another devastating inadequacy on the part of the Queensland Government, will also be widely noticed. The deterioration in the quality of government in that State is all too conspicuous and Senator Colston is to be congratulated on drawing it to public attention, as he regularly does.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.50 p.m.

The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Building Manual currently available for purchase; if so, what arrangements can people from outside the ACT make to purchase a copy, and to receive an update service automatically; if not, when was the ACT Building Manual last available for purchase, and what additional arrangements have been made since then to assist those needing detailed building information.
(2) When is it expected that the Manual will again be available.
(3) Where may copies of the ACT Building Manual be inspected.
(4) What restrictions are there on access to the Manual in these places.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The 1986 Edition of the ACT Building Manual has been available since 8 May 1986. People from outside the ACT may purchase a copy through the Australian Government Publishing Service Bookshops in all capital cities or through the mail from the AGPS Mail Order Services, GPO Box 84, Canberra ACT 2600.
The 1986 Edition of the ACT Building Manual includes all previous published amendments made to the Manual since 1974.
The Manual is to be republished each year and consequently an update service is not required.

(3) Copies of the Building Manual may be inspected at the public counter of the Building Section, Department of Territories, First Floor, North Building, Civic Offices, London Circuit, Canberra City. Other copies are available for reference at branches of the Canberra Public Library Service.
(4) No restrictions are placed on access to the Building Manual at those places.
The cost of answering this question is estimated at $21.00.
